div.head:
Bishop Halls Observations in his
book of Meditations
And vowes.
div.p:
These things be comelie & pleasant to see
And worthy of honnor from the beholders;
A Young Saint. An Old martyr; A Religious
Souldier. A Conscionable States-Man; A
Great man courteous; A learned man
humble. A Silent woman; A Child
understanding the eye of his Parent.
A mercy compannion with out vanitie;
A friend not changed with honnour; A Sick
Man Cheerefull: And a departing Soul
with Comfort and Assurance.

div.head: A Prayer.
div.p:
O most great and gracious God, who
art Lord of Heaven & Earth; look
down from the Throne of thy majesty
And be merciful to me thy poor &
unworthy Creature. Lord lead me by
thy Power through the Red Sea of this
World, into the Land of Promisse.
Pardon I humbly beseech thee my Sin
which standeth as a Cloude betweene thy
Most gracious goodness and my most
extreame Misserie. for our Lord Jesus.
Christ, his sake.
Amen.

div.head: The dedication.
div.l: Ile dedicate my Soul unto my God.
My Childhood, non-Age, youth is by his Rod
To be directed. his Staffe to uphold,
My Age, & riper years; till it has told,
The gracious goodness of our blessed God.
What he has don for me, who by his Word,
Raised my droopeing Spirits often times
Pardoned my Sins, delivering me from crimes.
And by his Blood Shed purchas't Heaven.
For humblest Souls. his Grace has given.
The guift is free, nor can wee mirritt.
Ought of our selves for to Inheritt,
But what by the fall is made our own,
The wages of Sinn's, Damnation.
Then oh my Soul doe not decline,
This Heavenly Pilgrimage divine.
Rise up my heart to Heaven above,
And let thy Lord, now prove thy love.
Spring up a maine & let his holy Spirit,
Give thee a Crown of Glorie to Inherritt.
Then flie a loft on wings of faith,
And doe what thy Redeemer saith.
Oh follow him stay not behind,
For to be drove by every wind.
Of triffeling foolish Childeish toyes
To interrupt thy Sollid lasting Joys
Which are ever living. never Ending
There are pleasures worth Commending
Come on my Soul hoist up thy highest sails
And creepe not still on, like wearie Snailes
Power out thy soul by prayer to God on high
Lay thou fast hold on him untill thou die.
Then guide me Lord, give my Soul, directions.
Subdue my passions, curbe my stout Affections
Nip thou the bud, before the bloome begins
Lord ever keep me from Presumptuous Sins
And make me ever chuse what you Seest best
Lord lead me by thy hand into thy Rest.

div.p:
Alice Wandesforde the fifth child of
Christopher Wandesforde Esquire late
Lord Deputy of Ireland. Was borne at
Kirklington in the County of Yorke
the thirteenth day of February being on a
munday, a bout two of the clock in the
afternoone in the year 1626. Baptized the
next day. The wittnesses were Mr
Lassells Minister of Kirklington.
Mrs Anne Norton. & Mrs Best.

div.head: Proverbes.
div.p:
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of Wisdom
and to depart from evil is understanding.
Remember now thy Creator, in the days of thy youth,
While the Evil days come not, nor the years draw
nigh, when thou shalt say, I have no pleasure in them.
And thou Solomon my Son, know thou the God of thy
Fathers, & serve him with a perfect heart, & with a
willing mind: for the Lord searcheth all hearts,
& understandeth all the imaginations of the thou-
-ghts: if you seeke him, he will be found of thee, but
if thou forsake him, he will cast thee off for ever.
A wise son maketh a glad father, but a foolish son
is the heavinesse of his Mother. Pro. 20: 22.
Children obey your Parents in the Lord for this is right.
Favour is deceiptfull, & beauty is vaine, but A
woman that feareth the Lord she shall be praised.

p.quote:
As a jewell of Gold is in a swines snout, so is a fair
woman with out discression.

Keep thy tongue from lieing, & thy lips from
speakeing guile.

Fear God, & keep his commandements, for this is
the whole duty of man.

Be thou faithful unto death, And I will give
Thee the Crown of Life.

div.head: A Preface to the book.
div.p:
For as much as it is the dutie of every true Christian
to remember, & take notice of Allmighty God our,
Heavenly Fathers, gracious Acts, of Providences,
over them, & merciful dealings with them, even from
the womb, untill the Grave burie them in silence, As
also to keep particular remembrances of his favours
both Spiritual, & temporal, together, with his remarkable
deliverances of their Souls & Bodies with a true and
unfeined gratitude to his Glorious Majesty for them all.
I therefore his Creature, & unworthy handmaid.
who have not tasted (only) of the dropping of his dew;
but has bin showred plentifully upon, my head, with
the continued Streames of goodness, Doe most humbly
desire to furnish my heart with the deep thoughts
& apprehensions, & sincere meditations of and
thankefullnesse, For his free Grace, love, mercies &
inconceavable goodness to me his poor Creature.
Even from them first beginning.

And with a most Cordiall, & sincere heart thankefully
doe return him the Glory of all. First,

For my Birth & baptizme in the name of the most holy
Trinitye: my strict Education in that true faith of the
Lord Jesus Christ, by my dear & Pious Parents
through whose care, & precepts I had the principles
8
A preservation in the Meassells.
Of grace, & Religion instill'd into me with my milk.
Therefore. shall I begin with the first mention of my
deliverances, that presents it self under the notion of
my first knowledge & remembrance; which are most
worthy of perpetuall memmorie.

And which I hope shall not end with this life, but spring
up in my soul, to an Eternity of Haleluias, of praise
& thankesgiveings to the Blessed Trinitie forever.
Amen. Amen.

note.p:
Remember to putt the Relation of my delivrance from Death
by a fall cutting my forehead at 3 yers old

div.p:
[+]
The first deliverance of that kinde was in the year
1630. When I was left at Richmond under the
care, & dear, love of my beloved, Aunt Norton.
upon my father & mothers going to London.
It pleased God to bring me into a very dangerous
weakness, & sickness, upon an accident of a
Surfitt, by eating some beefe which was not well boiled
, this causeing an extreame vomitting, whose vi-
-olence drove me into great fever, & that into the
meassells, & both, brought me so low & weak that
my Aunt. & Sarah Tomlinson (our maid) almost
dispaired of my Life.

But it pleased the Lord my God in great mercy, to
hear the hearty prayers & requests, of my Aunt for me.
9 From the Small Pox.
That I was spared from death at that time, and
by his blessing, upon the use of good means was
recovered of my health perfectly again.

Oh that I may have my life given me for a blessing.
and that I may live to the Glory of his holy name, who
hath saved me from death.

And that I may grow in Grace, & in the knowledge of Jesus
Christ our Lord. being a comfort to my dear Parents
& relations. And that I may dedicate my Childehood
youth. middle. & old Age, (if he shall spare me
so long) to his service & praise, yea even to my lives
end. & that for my Saviours sake alone. the Alpha &
Omega. Amen. I was about 5 years old. then:

div.head: A preservation in the Small Pox, 1631.
div.p:
Being removed to London by my Fathers order with
my brother Christopher. I fell into the smale-pox have-
-ing taken them of him. both of us was sent into Kent
where we lodged at one Mr Baxters. being kindly usd
with much care in that house. & by the blessing of God I
recovered very soone, nor was I very ill at that time.

I therefore will praise the Lord our God, for my preservation
that did not suffer that dissease to rage, or indanger my
life, but raised me soone again, O set forth his goodness
forever. Amen.

div.head:
London 1631.
The first dawning of Gods Spirit in my heart.
div.p:
After this, it pleased God to come into my Soul
by some beames of his mercy in putting good thoug-
-hts into my mind, to consider, his Great & miraculus
Power, in the Creation of the Heavens, the Earth, & all
the Hosts of them. I was moved to this meditation
upon the reading of the dailie Psalmes for the months
happening that day to be Psal. 147: v. 4th

He counteth the starres & calleth them all by their
Names. From whence there came into my heart
a forceable consideration, of the Incomprehencable
Power, & infinite Majesty of Allmighty God, who
by his Wisdom made all things, in Heaven & Earth.
being above all his Creatures in the world.

knoweing what is in man, & searching, all their
ways. Seeing my heart & thoughts, & knew also that
I was but a child both in Age & understanding.
And not able to doe any thing that was good. which strooke
me into a deep fear, & great awe of his Glorious
Majesty. least I should offend him at any time by
sin. against him or my Parents. & he would punish all
Sinness; were they never so manny, as the Starres, yet
he was as well able to keep an account, & finish for them
as to tell the Starres & give them names.

This, with other, the like meditations of his omnipotencey.
11
And Greatness. And that he out of his love made man.
did so move my heart, that it caused in me a Sincere
love to him, for his goodness, to me his poor Creature.
whom my Creator had made to serve him here. & to
take us up to Heaven when we die And Crown us with
Glory. Giving him my hearty thanks for his great
& particular love & favour to me a little Child, in
giving understanding & Reason to know there is
A God that Ruleth in Heaven & Earth & doeth what
ever he will, and to reward them that Serves him truly
with Joy in Heaven that should never end. Amen.

div.head: A deliverance from a fire in London 1631.
div.p:
There was a great fire in the next House to ours in St
martens Lane in Lond. which burned a part of our house
being near to have burnt it down, but through
the care of our Servants it was prevented. this was don
at night when my father & mother was at Court.
but wee were preserved that time of fright at my Lady
Levestones house being caried by Sara our maide.
This fire seemed to me as if the day of judgement was
come causeing much fear & trembling. yet we were
all delivered from perishing though my father had
much loss. But blessed be the Lord my God who gave
us not over to perish by this fire, but preservd
our Persons from Evil at that time.

div.head: My Mothers going into Ireland 1632.
div.p:
It pleased God to give my dear Mother, my two
younger brothers & my self a safe passage into
Ireland, about the year. 1632. My Father being
there a year before, & my Eldest brother George
In which place I enjoyed great happienesse and
Comfort dureing my hon.redhonoured fathers life having the
fortunate oppertunity in that time, & after, when
I stayed there, of the best education that Kingdom
could afford. haveing the advantage of Societie in the
sweet & chaste company of the Earle of Straffords Daughters
The most virtuous Lady Anne. & The Lady Arbella
Wentworth. Learning those qualities with them which
my father ordered. Namlie,

The french Language. to write, & speak the same;
Singing. Dancing. Plaieng on the Lute, & Theorboe.
learning such other accomplishments, of Working
Silkes. gummeworke. & Sweetemeats & other
sutable huswifery. As, by my mothers vertuous
provision, & care, she brought me up in what was
fit for her qualitie, & my fathers Child.

But above all things I accounted it my Cheifest
happiness where in I was trained in those Pious
holy & Religious instructions. Examples, admo-
-nitions.
13
33, 34, 35.
Teachings. Reproofes, & Godly Education, tending to
the wellfaire, & Eternal happiness, & salvation
of my poor Soul. Which I received from both my Hon.rd
Father & Mother. with the Examples of their Chast
and sober, wise & Prudent Conversations in all
things of this World. for which things, and infinit
-ly more opportunitys of Good to my wellbeeing
then I can express. I Render my uttmost Capacity
& Therefore doe I most humbly, & heartily acknowledg
my bounden duty of thanks & praise to the great
God of Heaven, & Earth, from whence comes every
good & perfect guift, who is the Author, & finisher
of our faith, that he has put such good things into my
Hon.red Parents hearts to bring us up in the fear of
the Lord. Next I humbly acknowledge, my faithful
thanks & gratitude to my dear & Hon.red Parents
for their love, care, affection & sedulity over
me from my birth till this present, & for their
good performances towards my education in all
things. Begging of God to give me the grace of the
means, as well as the means of his grace, afforded
me. that so I may walk in all holy & strict obedience,
in thy Laws, & their precepts, according to all thes
goodnesses of God, & theires, performing my cordiall
duty to them in all godlynesse & honnesty, obeying my
Parents in the Lord to the end of my Life Amen.

div.head: A deliverance from a fire & other remarkables.
div.p:
While we were in Dublin there was a fire in
our House. but by the providence of God it was
soone discovered. & so quenched with out much
harm don. Blessed be the name of our good God;

About the time I was 12 years old in the year 1638.
I was readeing of the great wisdom of our Saviour.
in the Gospel of St Luke 2d chapt. 49 v. where he was
disputing with the Docters with so much power that he put them
to silence.

In the reading of which passage I being that daye 12 yeres
old. I fell into a serious & deep meditation, of the
thoughts of Christs Majesty, devinity & wisdom,
who was able to confound the learned Doctors & confute
their wisdom, who were Aged, he being so young
himself. but then 12 years of Age.

And then I considered my own folly, & Childish,
Ignorance that I could not scarse understand, meane
and low things, with out a great deal of teacheing
& instruction, & although I daily read the word
of God, yet was of a weak capacity to know the way
to Salvation. And therefore in my heart begged of
my dear Saviour to give me knowledge, wisedome
& understanding to guide me all my days. Amen.

div.head:
1639
A deliverance from Ship-Rack in A Passage into
Ireland with my Mother, brother, & 2 Nephewes.
Thomas & Christopher Danby. In the year 1639.
div.p:
Having come over into England, when my Mother
came for her cure of the dissease of the Stone to the Bat-hes
& Bristoll water, St Vincents well; (upon which Rose
hanging over it, is got your Bristow Diamonds.)
in
her return back into Ireland, she carried my
Sister Danbies 2 Elldest sons. for their better
education, When we came to Nesston. at the Sea
side we stayed for a winde a week; And in that time
there was a great Storme on the Sea in so much as
there was 5 Ships cast away upon the Shore before
our Eyes. so nigh were some of them, that, the maine
mast, did almost touch the window of that house,
where we laid. yet the night proveing calme
and winde fair We took Ship for Ireland in
one of the Kings Ships new built. Upon the 22th of
August. 1639 with in one hour's Saile. A most
Tirrible Storme & tempest arose. So fiercely. that
we were drove on lee all night & with in lesse then 10
hours we were 12 miles beyond Dublin. lieing at
Hull, and Anchor all day. And but for a fisher botte
sent from Mr Hubert to assist the Kings Ship in distress
16
Wee had undoubtedly perished, being drove by
the force of Tempest back in to the cross Seas. &
10 hours were at Anchor, beaten on the Sandes
before that fisher man could come near to help us.
at the last, about 8 a clock at night, we got Safe
To harbour
through the infinite mercies of our great, & Powerfull
Lord God, we landed safely at the shore of the Skirries.
where the same Hubert with all his family, & friends
mett us with great Joy, entertaining my mother &
All hers, with abundante affection, & kindenesse.
Which he did upon the account of obligation, to show
his gratitude for an Emminent peice of Justice
don him from my father. who had decided a
grand controversie in Law suites, which was depending
20 years, almost to his utter Ruin. his adversary
being so potent. that he could not get his cause heard
till that time; when through the uprightnesse of the
Judge, & honnesty of the man his cause rightly de-
termined. & he preserved.

This providence was the more remarkable. that God
so ordered our ship to this shore, where my Mother
found all manner of relief for us all which we wanted
And on the next day, Came My father from Dublin
in the company of many noble friends in Coatches.
17
To carrie us home to Dublin where my dear Mother
was received with all Joy & gladnesse. living in
much peace & happiness till the death of my Hon.red
Father. When about a year after his death. she
was forced to flie into England, upon the Rebellion
which brake out in Ireland.

But I must not forget a second preservation of
my own Self from drowneing. out of that Ship, at
that time, when a cable from the bote that came to
carrie us to land, & being tied to our Ship. by it's
force, had like to have pulld me out of the Ship in
to the Sea. Which it had don, but that by Gods providence
a Shipman coming at that minuite from under the
Decke pulled me back, & saved me from falling
into that Tempestious Sea, when I was half over
borde. This great & wonderfull mercy, & my Single
deliverance must not be forgotten but had in a
perpetuall remembrance of me forever & therefore
will I humbly set forth the mercies of the Lord to me.

div.head:
A thanksgiving for our deliverances.
after our dangerous passage by Sea:
August the 23d 1639. into Ireland.
Psallme 107. 1st v.
div.p:
O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is gracious: &
his mercies endureth for ever. Let them give than
-ks whom the Lord hath redeemed, & delivered from
the Stormes, & mighty tempests. he has delivred
us from this distress, when the deep had opened
her mouth to swallow us up. then was the hand
of the Lord mighty to deliver, & preserve us from
drowning, Oh that we would therefore praise the Lord
for his goodness, & speak good of his name, &
declaire the wonders that he hath don to us Children.
We called on him in our disstresse, & he heard from
Heaven his habitation, for he brought us out of
the shadow of death. & brake our bands of fears a
sunder. Our soul abhorred all manner of meate,
& we were even hard at deaths dore, they that go
down to the Sea in Ships, these men see the works of
of the Lord & his wonders in the deep, for at his
word the Stormy winde arriseth. which lifteth the wave
I was carried up to Heaven, & down again to the
deep, my Soul melted within me, for verie trouble
so when I cried unto the Lord in my distress he deliv
-ered us out of our trouble. he made the Stormy wind
to cease. so that the waves thereof were still. Then were
our hearts glad with in us. because he brought us safe
19
To a resting place, & to a haven where we would
faine be, & likewise sent us an unexpected relief
amongst strangers, making them helpefull in that
danger. Also the Lord his name be glorified for
his gracious favour to me in preserving me from drow-
-ning, when the cable had pulld me almost into the Sea,
then did, his mercy bring me help when I might
have perished alone. O dear God write this de-
-liverance with the other upon the Table of my heart, that
I may never forget what thou Lord hast don for my Soul
And oh, that, I & all that was in the Ship might praise the
God of Heaven, for his great & unsearchable goodness
, & declaire the wonders that he has don for us in perticuler
I and they may exalt him that rideth on the Heavens
, & praise his Excellent greatnesse in the congregate-on
of the people, & magnify him in the seate of the Elders
Which made the stormes to cease: & for the glory of his
majesty, the God of Jacob, preserved my dear Moth
from perishing in the gulfe, with her Children, & Grand
Children, and spared us from this destruction.

The Lord most high, grant us thy grace, that we might
live to thy Glory, & magnify thy name to all gene-
-rations. he bringing us with Joy to my dear father
from the bottom of the waves where millions had perished
in those depths. Lord I beseech thee let me,
20
Be wise & ponder these things, & several other
Providences in these miraculous Delivernces,
to my self, & relations. that the Righteous may know
, & consider the goodness of the Lord, & his loving
kindness, & rejoice in him for ever.

Therefore to the Lord most great, & gracious, be all
Glory, thanksgiving, dominnion, & praise, in
heaven & Earth, the Sea & all places of the world
for ever more. Amen. & Amen.

note.p:
My L.d Straford took Ship for England w:th my Lord Raby his son
on good friday the year. 1640. gaue my father the Sword then.

div.head:
Observations upon several accidents
happening in Ireland upon the Earle of
Strafford, &c. in the years. 1640, 41. And
on his fatall murder: may: 12 1641.
div.p:
After my mothers return from the Bathes, &,
Bristoll, where she found much good as to the
cure of the stone.

The Earle of Strafford was sent for by the King in
to England. upon the complaints of some factious
Spirritts, weary of a lawfull, & Peaceable govern--ment
both in England, Scotland & Ireland, whose
Spirits, & ambitions could not indure a subjection
to their most Pious & good King, nor his Lieutenant
which ruled them in Ireland with a wise & prudentiall
government, to the preservation of His Majesties Crown.
21
And dignities. The Settlement of the Church, & State
upon the right foundations of truth, & peace. Which
these People had no such intentions, as was too
apparent, in the following Rebellions both in England
& Ireland. The Irish being heard to say. That their
Religeion would not prosper as long as Straffords
head stood on his shouldiers. which saying strongly
proved that this noble Earle was no Patteron of the
Romish Church, although falsely accused so, by
his Seditious Enemies; & his own inncocency was
cleared upon the Scaffold in his speeche made then
But all the discontented parties too well agreed in this one
point, to strike the roote, of the foundations; the King
being aimed at to succeed in this tradegie, As God
knowes to sadly followed;

The Earle of Strafforde haveing far different designes
then those Secret plotters of Rapine, & Ruin.
could not longer be endured, because he stood in the
way to hinder, & prevent by his wise Counsel. So
that till he was removed, they could not prevaille either
in Ireland, or England to compasse their ends.
Nor could there be found, a better expedient for their
purpose then to make a cloake of Religion, that under
such a Populer, specious, pretence, Their horrible
practices might not be found out.

The Irish thirsting, after the blood, & lives of the
English, pretended oppression. to be made subject
to the Laws of England. & the other of that nation could
not be subject to our Church Government, & orde
ers, but affected a loose libertaineissme to their
own pernicious ways, joyned with the Irish in
their complaints against this wise & noble
Person; whom indeed they were not worthy of
under whose jurisdiction, that Kingdom had in-
-joyed 7 years of peace & Plenty. All his
endeavours ever tending for their good, the
True Establishment of His King, & Religion
The Hon.or peace & wellfaire of the English Nation
And the due ordering of that Barbarous People
& their Civilizeng them to our good Laws &
government. but this was against all their
intrests of Rebellions, & close couched Treacheris
which lay hatched under so specious, Pretensions
that he would subvert the Church & State.

Theires was for the Establishment of Heresies, Popery
& destruction, of Church & state, to advance
23
Horrible Paricides & murders. breaking forth
first in Ireland to the destruction of millions of the
Poor protestants Christians who suffered martyredom
for their God, & his Religion.

And in England many 1000 suffered by the sword
both with their King, & for him, & the truth of
Religion there Established. & for the Laws.

But to returne to my Lord Lieutenant, while the
Pretences of Religion, so filled the eares of the Parliament
of England then sitting in the year 40 and false
suggestions of oppressions against this Noble
Earle. he was called before them to give an answer
to such Articles as his Enemies of all factions
had unjustly laid to his charge.

The whole transaction, of this business, was prose-
-cuted, with so much malice, & Rigour of his Enemies
side. And so much, wisdom, prudence, & galantrie
on the Earles. that all the world (save his Enemies thirsting
his blood,) did admire his incomparable Wisdom &
Abilities, in his clear, & brave defence, he made for
himself, notwithstanding they gave fresh charges each
day, which he had never heard of, nor had he any time
Spared, to give in his answer, but was set upon with
new blood hounds, as their fancies pleased,

Neither was he allowed, the benefit of his wittnessces
only, there was that in his trial don, which was never
heard of before, for want of full eveidence against
him, (which was sc'rud to the hight too,) an invention
forged of Accumulative Treason, and a Perticuler
Act made in that Parliament to confirme the same
till they had got his life.

And then another following Act after his death, to ab-
-brogate & disannull the other for ever, that it might
never be in force against any other. Person.
The world may by this judge the truth & Legallity
of these proceedings, against this brave Person.
But the truth is, he had so much of wrong and
injustice don, in all the prosecution, as no man,
but of infinite abilities, which God had wonderfully
given him, could have withstood those Mastives
, & blood hounds, in the quick retorts, & vindication
of his innocent Actions, returning their malice
on their own false suggestions.

So that least these Articles, & other artifices in
the house should not prevail with the King, who did
clear him in his own judgement. there was the
invention of abundance, of Lies, & callumnies
cast about. & instilld into the eares, & hearts of the
25
vulger meaner Peopple. such as had ignorance
& pride to be their leaders. which being told a
fallsehood, that the Lord Leuetenant did councill the King
to Subvert the Laws, & bring in Popery, gathered,
together in infinite numbers of Prenticies of London
& head strong Seperates, & Schismaticks.

The great numbers meeting at the Parliament House
daily clamoured & cried out, against my Lord, &
the King, did so increase, that the Tumults had nighto
have pulled his Sacred Majesty in Pieces, as he
removed from White Hall to the Parliament, still
crying out for Justice against Strafford.

So that to sattisfie their Cruell Malice, & to give
them all content, there was no other expendient
would doe, but this innocent Earles Life to be
taken from him.

This the most Pious King could very hardly be
drawne to, being pressed to signe the bill he still
declaring his innocency in his conscience he was not
worthy of death. But the King being constrained
for the Saveguard of his own Life. Passed that fatall
Bill. with 2 others that day. which proved as destructive
to him, & the Church, & Kingdom, as this of Straffords
, That of excluding the Bishops out of the House of
Parliament. And the other, of Trieniall Parliaments
26
Which were preludiums of this most Excellent
Kings own destruction; when the Commons had got
the Reines of Power, by this in to their own hand
& the better capacitated, to fight against their
Lawfull Soveraine; Albeit they pulled upon them
-selves & the Kingdom a fatall Ruin with in a few
years after, but Principally against our
Sacred Majesty which was the Marke with the Crown
which they Aymed at.

But this galant Earle so much desiring the
Peace & happiness of his Majesty, & Kingdoms
did acquitt the King constrained. & chearfully
submitted to that sentance, with so much Serenity &
tranquility, of thoughts as is immaginable. Only
did justifie his innocency to the death. as maybe
seen in his papers, & last speech. he forgave his
Adversaries, & wished as he was the first that had
laid down his life in this way, for the preservation
of the King & church. so that he might be the last inno
-cent bloodshed. but he much feared it.

He put up prayers for the King, & the whole Kingdom
as it may be seen in his triall. written by an Eye &
eare witness: And upon the 12th of May. 1641
he suffered martiredome. being beheaded on
27
Tower hill. The fall of this brave man, was an
infinite Loss, to the Church of God; his King, and the
three Kingdoms. Who through his wise counsell.
(the same) had bin fortunate to the preservation of Peace, & truth,
for several years; but, now the Scottish faction
began to breake out again, that had Apeared in the year 39.
And our Sins, contracted in so long a peace: was Ripe
for Judgements. Gods Sword was drawne, out a-
-gainst us to fight his quarrell, till by our punishments
he humbled the pride of our hearts.

When the Just & wise men faile, & are taken away
the Cittye will be left in darkenesse. & destruction.

div.head:
A Relation concerning my Hon.red father. the
Lord Deputy Wandesforde, & of his
Death. December 3d 1640.
div.p:
Upon my Lord Lieutennants of Irlands going
for England. the King was graciously pleased to
send his Commission under the great Seale of England
to my Father. to succeed my Lord of Strafford. in that
weighty Place of Deputie-Ship.
In which he actted with so much Piety, Loyallty,
Candor, & Justice. that his memmory is Blessed to
many Generations.

In his time there were many causes determined
& decided, of great concernment betweene parties
which had depended. some 10. 20. 30. years. & the
cause of the widdowes, & oppressed, strangers &
the fatherlesse, was rightly adjudged & deter-
-mined.

Which through the imbesility of the Parties. the Power
of the adversaries. or corruption of the under Officers
, had bin till then neglected. but to the comfort
of the injured was rightly settled. & also to the sattisfa
-ction of the other parties. who being convinced
by the pains, & Christian, advices, & wise Just
mannagerey of his government. they confessed
the equity of his determinations, to be Just
Legall & right.

Yea such was the sweet affability, & prudence of
his carriage, in general. that none which went from
England gained so much upon affections of that
Nation. & all whom he lived amongst.

His Life was given for a Public good, to that Kingdome
as well, as to be a bllissing in his own Family.
Who was exceeding happy in such a Father &
Head. His dear & beloved wife, most blessed in
such a comfort, support, & Husband, as the world
could not paralell. in all chaste. pious. dear
29
love and, conjugall affection. with temperance,
meekenesse, & sobriety. They both injoying many
years of happiness together in that holy band of
a Loyall wedlocke. even to the admiration of all.
for their godly & Righteous conversation.

All his children infinitly happy, & blessed, in such a
Father & guide, in their youths. his Relations
friends & Tennants, were all blessed in him, doing
them what good he could. Let his raire & Excellent
Book of advice to his sonne George, Speak his great
Endowments. his Piety, knowlidge in Parts, Divinity, &
Religion. his Wisdom & paternall care &
prudence, tender & dear love to his whole Family
& generation.

A grand Patron of the Church, & incourager of all
ingenious Schollers of what Age or degree soever. An in
couragement. & exemplear of Learning. Sobriety
Temporance; chastety; holiness, patience; humility
Charity; Justice & clemency was thys Heroicke
Soul replenished with all.

Rich in good workes. lovely & desirable in his life
a dear & loving Brother to his brothers & Sisters. taking care
for their advantage in Education, & preferrment
as branches from the same stocke with himself. he had
A wise & prudentiall love, towards all his Children
30
For their Pious & religious Education with
fair & noble provissions for them in his Last
Will & testament.

His life was spent in great Sedulity & watch
-fullnesse, to discharge, a good conscience towards all
, towards God, & man. A true Labourer in Gods
Vineyard, in which he plaied the good husbandman
And God at last gave him his wages, even
the Crown of Glory for ever.

And guiding his ways with discrestion of God gave
him a foresight of those changes was coming
upon Church & State. And offt in my hearing
would he say to my dear Mother, in his health
, that, who so should live to see it; should see
great changes, & Evils, both upon the Church
& State. Such was the Sins & Pride of those dais
that there hung a cloud over this Kingdoms.
he praied God to divert the same. and Establish
the same upon those Excellent foundations on
which it was built.

Acc.t of
the Lord
Deputy
Death
It pleased God to vissite my dear father, with a
fever, at the latter end of November. which kept him
about a week or 10, days in the house. but finding
him self some what better. went to Church, being
31
Attended home by the Earle of Ormond the Lord
Dillon. Sir George Ratclife & many other persons
of quality. as the usuall custome was to waite on
the Deputy to dinner.

When he came into the dining roome, & perceived
himself not well, craved leave of the company to
rest himself a little in his bedchamber, intending
to have satt at dinner with them. but still he grew
worse. & sent word he found himself, so ill that he
went to bed & desired the pardon of that noble company
And after dinner the company parted. calling to
mind the Sermon, my father told my mother.
That he had that day heard the best Sermon, that
ever he had heard in all his life, & blessed God
for it, saying it was, as if it should be the last.
he knew not what it might prove.

But if he lived. he would reward that minister
plentifully, & he should not want the best preferment
he could help him to.

The fever still increasing, seized on him stronggly
, but he full of patience, & Christian magnanimity
was prepared for the Lords dealing with him in his
Providence, either for life, or Death.

About tuesday the 29th of no. 1640 he called for his
Will; commanding my Co. wandesforde one of his
Executors to the said will. to read it it being Signed, Sealed
32
And finished a good while before. he had it then
all read over to him in the presence of divers Persons
of qualitie. as my Lord Bishop of Derrey an Executor
the Earle of Ormond; the Lord Dillon, & several others
Before, whom he Ratified & confirmed the same
declairing it publickly to be his last Will &
Testament.

Commanding his Executor to see it fullfiled, & per
formed, to my mother, & all his Children. & that
all his Just debtes, whether by bill, or bond, &
justly proved, should be paid; again charged
them to be cairefull of his wife, & children.
About wednesday, my mother desired the Phisicians
to give her a true state of his condition, whom
she perceived grew weaker. but they would
not deal truly, nor acknowledge his desperate
case. Albeit they found by his blood that it was
corrupted, & most fatall signes.

That night Pigeons cutt, was laid to his soles
of the feet, when my father saw it, he smiled, &
said, are you come to the the last remidie. but I shall
prevent your Skill. for all along this sickness
he expected his change, although he would not
acquaint my mother for increaseing her grief
All the time of his Sickness, till the last period.
33
He had the perfect use of Reason, & clear understanding
as, in all his life, which was an infinite mercy afforded
him. most quick & acqute
in all facculties, as in
perfect health.

The entertainement in his sickness was full of
divine medittations, Ejaculations, & praires, with
praises to his God. & preparations for death.

he gave many instructions to his son George, to be
diligent in the service of God, obedient to his comm-andent
obedeint, & dutifull, to his dear mother. who had
bin a faithful, tender, loving wife to him & his
Children, he commanded him to love; Hon.or obey her
in all things, all his days, due to her for her wisdom
& vertue. & doing this God would bless him the beter
charged him to suffer his will to be performed, which
was just & equall, there being right don to him
& all persons else. ending with many good advices
to fear & love that dreadful Lord God. & he would
bless him. & provide for him as he had don to him-selfe
When he laid slumbring, still would he be, as if
discourseing in judicature, that he would doe uprightly
to all in his power. if the poor mans cause be right
he should not suffer for his poverty. nor the Rich, gaine
for being so. if his cause were bad. neither could
he respect the persons of the Rich or poor. but doe up-
-rightly according to the Laws of God, & man.

Many such like expressions I have heard him
my self, then would he call on me, to his bed
side, & stediely lookeing on me, would sighe
& say. Ah poor child, what must thou see
& thine Eyes beholde. And praing for me,
turned away with a great grone.

Which expressions stucke so deep. that I never for
-gate them, but has sadly experienied
those
miseries which he prophetically foresaw.

The Bishop of Derrey being called on thursday at
night, who told him he perceived he grew weaker
in body, that he would doe well, to declaire in
public his faith, & hope in God. not that he qu-
-estioned the same, he being fully satisfied.
but that it was usuall in those cases; for the comfort
& instruction of the companie.

Immeadiately my dear Father raised up
him self with all his force. And stedfastly fixe-
ed his Eyes to Heaven. then made before many
Persons of qualitie (with my mother.) A most
Heavenly, & Pathetically confession of his faith
hope, & confidence in God. And that his heart did
fully relie upon the all saveing mirritts of Jesus
Christ his Redeemer. in him alone hoped for pardon
&, remission of all his Sins, & for Salvation through
his blood which was shed for him.

And that in him he hoped for Eternall Glorie, of his
own free Grace, & mercy. he desired the Lord to for
-give All his Sins, as he freely forgave all the
world. And declaring that he died in the faith
which was proffessed in the Church of England at that time
being most pure, & holy, & agreeing with Christs
Institution. Praing to God long to continue it
flourishing.

Many other praires for himself & his wife &
Children. desireing to be accepted of the Lord in
Mercy, according to the Sinscerity of his heart.
After devout praires for him by the Bishop & the solomne
pronounciation of absolution, in order to the Churc
-his
command. This dear & sweet Saint freely
yealded up his precious Soul to God, with these
words, into thy hands oh Lord, I commend my Soul
Lord Jesus receive my Spirit Amen.

With which he fell asleepe. Which blessed end of his life
being a happy close of his holy Life has I hope receavd
a full reward of Joy in the Kingdom of Heaven &
strooke a most deep impression upon all that knew
him. I pray the Lord continue his memory fresh in
my heart to imitate his virtues, graces & Piety
he departed this life on Thursday the 3d of December
1640 at his own house in Dammaske Streete in
Dublin beeing in Ireland.

His body being imbowelled, was afterwards
Imballmed, & all the noble parts was very Sound
& perfect saveing the heart which was decaied
of one side. It was thought tis proceeded from
much study & business, which his weighty &
great imployments called him to.

Great watchfullnesse & pains in the faithful
discharge in his Offices.

He was the Maister of the Rowles in Ireland 7
years. One of his Majesty privey council. A
Judge in the Kings Bench. once Lord chief
Justice of that Nation. And Lastly he died the
Lord Deputy of that Kingdom of Ireland.

being the only Man in that place (as was observd
which died untouched, or peaceably in their beds
He was found faithful & so beloved of his
Prince & countrey. A most generally lamented
Person in that Kingdom who had found the swete
nesse of his Government in much meekenesse &
clemency. He was also the Last Deputy for
many years, being the last in King Charles the
firsts time, the warres following after his death
The next Lawfull governer there was the Earle
of Ormond in King Charles the 2ds time of Restora
-tion. into England.

The Corpes of my Hon.red Father was carried from
the Castle of Dublin in a Stately manner. according
to his Dignitie & Place, being interred in the
chief Church. Christs Church under a fair
Marble. before the Deputies Seate of Estate
on the 10th day of December 1640

The Bishop of Derrey Preach't his funeral Sermon.
Text Matt. xx. 8.
And I am sure amongst the multitude of People
there was not many drie Eyes: Such was the love
that God had given to this worthy Person. that the Irish
did set up their Lamentable: hone as they call
it, for him in the Church. which was never known
before for any Englishman don.

His funeralls charges, did amount to above 1300l
dieing in that capacitie of a Deputy. which so in-
-creased the Debts upon his Estate. as proved very
heavy. in the times of trouble succeeding: the King
did give order that this should have bin dischargd
out of his Treasury. As also that my brother Georges
wardship was given him by his gracious Majesty
both in regard of my fathers faithful service in that
place & his dieing Deputie. But the Parliament
seising upon the Kings Treasury & power. these
charges fell Sad upon all my Fathers Estate, & his
Children. being charged for the wardship by the Parliament
with the Summe of 2500l which never came to the King.

This was the beginning of troubles in our Family
after which followed the breaking out of the Rebellion of
Ireland, being about 9 months after my father
died in October 23d 1641.

div.head:
Meditations & Prayer upon the Death of my
Hon.red Father the Lord Deputie Wandesforde.
div.p:
Isaiah
57
v. 1st 2d
The righteous perisheth & no man laieth it to
heart; & the merciful men are taken away, none
considering that the righteous is taken away from the
evil to come.

He shall enter into peace: they shall rest in their
beds, each one walkeing in his uprightnesse.

Death is the common lott of all mankinde, since that
fatall fall of Addam. & so none can be exempted, can
be free from that sting of Sin, which comes into this world.
A Land of troubles. & a place for tears, & sorrows,
yea A Chaos of confussion. Job: saith Man that is borne of
a woman hath but a short time here. It is Appointed
for all men once to die &c. Again, death passes upon
all men. So then it is not in anys Power to be immortall
here, be they never so Great, & Eminent, full of Honore
Wisdom, Riches. graces, and indowments.

All must leave these things behind them, & pay that
common debt common Debt of death, they owe to
God, and Nature. Seeme it never so harsh to our
39
Affections; or cross to the desires of our Relattions, & frinds
this change must be, not only patiently submitted to,
but entertained with delight, & Joy, by every true Christian
As a gate, or Portall, to let out our Souls into Paradice
Where we may fully enjoy God, our cheifest happiness:
And bllessed, are such, which are in a preparednesse fit to
entertaine this messenger of God (Death). by a Holy,
Pious, & Religieous, conversation amongst men.

That this death may be appassage leading them to
Eternal Life; out of a misserable, wrettched world.
But yet the Scripture takes notice of a great Evil
that befalls the world, when the Righteous perish from of the Earth
& no man laieth it to heart.

Allbeit by Gods determination all men must die, yet , are
the days of the Righteous prolonged for a blessing to them
selves, and others where they live. And Good Kings &
governours, with men in eminent Places, & virtues when
they are cut of from the land of the living. prove an ar-
-gument of the grand displeasure of God towards those
Kingdoms & places for Sins not repented of.

When he shall see cause to Rob those people of their
Jewells. & bindes up their souls in the bundles of
life, from scorching fires of miseries & infilicity. then
let the wicked bewaire, who laies not their death to
heart, nor amend there lives, least such warning pieces
be sent to tell them that they are left alone to suffer puni-
-shments in the Earth.

Thus was it in the time of this Prophett Isaiah when
God had a controvercy with his people of Iraell. denou
-ncing & threatning his Judgements against them
by this, & others of his profetts. yet would they not
hear nor return.

Then did he move theme by his sweetest mercies,
those was in vaine. how long shall I call, & yea will
not answer. and all the day long. I have streatched
out my hand to a gainesaing people. these will not
move. And now, he sends his last warning Pieces
that they might take notice. he was bringing an
great Evils upon them, for the hardnesse of their
hearts, this was the Signe.

The Righteous perishith. yea they perish from of
this Earth. But what doe they lose, that loseth
a Righteous man. A holy man, from their place
whose, Souls, &, bodies, has bin kept from impietie
& polutions, of this world the flesh, & the deivill, which
are true Israelites indeed. Powring out daily
their pettions & prayers to God for the Kingdom
place, & Families. & with Moses stood before the People
to turn away his wrathfull displeasure against
them. with strong cries & tears to God to spare his
People from destruction.

Great are the benifitts which are enjoyed in the Life, &
Examples, Prayers, & supplications, Govrnment, &
instructions, of a holy, Righteous King. Father.
41
Master, or Ruler, over any Kingdom Place, or Family, &
then the loss is more eminent, and general to that societye,
The death of the least of Gods servants are heavy afflictions
But when the tall Ceadars falls. greater is the blow to
the shrubs, under whose branches, was their shelter.
The head being off, how can the other members subsist;
too frequently followes confusion.

yet the Prophet tells us from God, no man laies it to
heart, to consider, Why doth God this, nor are sensible
of this signe of wrath. that they may repent: of their
Sins, which has provaked his anger against them.
God saith more. the Merciful men are taken away
too. As if this gift of mercy were of more use to them,
as to there good, then any other virtue.

A great loss in deed & to be perticularly lamented
by us; when Mercy perisheith from of the Earth. (As
from God, to man,) those people are miserable.

Take away that Glorious Attribute of mercy from God.
(by which the world was made, preserved, & upholden, from
us.) there remaines Justice, & Severity. With an Almig-
ty power to fall upon us men, to the destruction of soul &
body, Who can endure the Justice of the Lord when his wrath
doth arrise yea, but a twinkling of an Eye. who is able to
stand before him. so when mercyfull men is taken from
amongst us. many times Tyrany. oppression & injustice
followes. yea when a father; the Glory of the wood is cut down
42
What remaines amongst men, when an unmercifull
man is ruler ouer them; but expectations to be devourd
, & torne assunder through Avarice. Pride. factions.
self intrest, & what not. even all confusion. in
such a Kingdom; place or family.

And with out an infinite mercy to prevent, will pro-
ceed to utter desstruction, yet, the fears of this will not
Rouse this secure People, out of the Lethergie of Sin.
When, these righteous perish. yet will they not con
-sider, when it is don to warne them, of their own ruin that
merciful men go. nor will awaken, to look about
& inquire, by the word of the cause of Gods dealing
to take them away. That it is from the evil to come
And so by that means, be converted, that he should
heal them.

As it was with the stuborne Jewes. so it is our own
case, God knowes, in these Kingdoms. our sins
were ripe for to be cut down by the sickle of Gods
Judgements by our Ennimies. & for them, to fall on this Kingdom.
Whose bloody desiress had so far besotted there hearts that
were upon a speedy excution of their designs.
All whose secret intentions God saw. (& that my
Fathers Soul was greived for the iniquities of the times)
delivired him from the following miseries. by a quiet
peaceable & sweet departure in the Lord.

According to his word, he was taken away: But from
what, or why, doth God cut short the life of his servant
.not in anger surely; against them. Athought tis said
in this text the Righteous perisheth.

no he perisheth from the pleasures of the world & the delights
there of for the present injoyments of this life, that he might
translate him to a better Place, & more durable Riches.
And not only so; but their departure was, to be freed
Even from the Evils to come.

Well might this be applied to our very case, in my
dear fathers deliverance. For his eyes did not see
those great & Tirrible Evils, which we did that sirvived him
, Even bitter ones, that fell upon the whole English, & Irish
Nations. Such as was never heard of the like. such horrid
Treasons, Tretcheries. Bloodsheds. burnings. fammins.
desolattions. & distructions.

Which fell so heavily upon our Holy good & Pious
King whom the world was not worthy of. And that Excellent
pure & Glorious Church then Established. for soundness
in faith & doctrine non could parrellel since the Apostles
time. And surely these things was foreseene
several years before, by him, he laid out his endevors
to prevent the falling of them upon us. by his frequent
admonishments, & reproofs for their vanities.
With his Zealous prayers & deep humiliation. of his person
And daily intercessions at the throne of Grace for these
three Kingdoms.

But our sins crieing so loud in General, for
vengeance that the Lord would not spare those which
Offended with so high a hand. against the sweet
mercies and forebearance of our gracious God.
Yet not withstanding, all those calamities & dis-
tractions of those times, I must ever acknowledge
& set forth, the loving kindenesse mercies & goodness
of the Lord of Hosts to us in our delivernces in all
these troubles. he making places of refuge for
my fathers wife & children.

So that not a haire of our heads perished in the
general destructions either by the Irish, or English
Rebellions. In Ireland were we miraculosly
Preserved in Dublin, for several weeks after the
Rebellion was broken out in the countrey.
And though in much frights by Alarums from
the Enemies, yet were we delivered from those
evils, till by a safe passage into England with
All my mothers Family & goods with her at
Dublin, we got quit of Ireland & got to the
Beere house at Nestton.

Thus was there a Sanctuary from those Perills
for this righteous mans family when 1000 was
swallowed up in the common calamities of that
Kingdom, by the Irish Papists. And so Alsoe,
45
Thus did the Lord deliver my dear father. in this
way. the best of all, most certainely it was, for
there the weary be at rest, & the wicked cease from trou
bling. He died, & was gathered to his Fathers in a
quiet & peaceable time. As he lived in Peace so
he departed in Peace, & to Peace, giveing him rest in his
Sleep, the sweet sleep of death to him, though sad,
to us, he left behind him.

It followes in the 2d v. He shall enter into peace:
they shall rest in their beds, each one walking in
his uprightnesse.

When the Righteous man leaves this turbulent
world, whither, shall he go, or what place, has
God prepaired for him. lo the Spirit of God tells
us, by his prophett, here the place. He shall enter
into peace. they shall rest in their beds.

And in this change, of my father was fullfilled
this prophecie; which had bin confirmed by our dear
Saviours, blessings to the Peacemakers; The poor in
Spirit: for theires is the kingdom of Heaven. to the
meeke: To the merciful. for they shall obtaine mercy
To the pure in heart: for they shall see God. the peace
makers: for they shall be called the children of
God.

Several of these graces; if not all of them
This dear servant of God was emminent for. in whose
blessings, I trust, he injoys his shaire. being called
by God to work in his vineyard. young, he fitted
him for his place here, that he might obteine
a crown in Heaven. hereafter.

Many received a blessing in his peaceable And
meeke. humble frame of heart. being a great meanes
& instrument of reconsiliation, in his time, to Publ
-icke, & private families, which were pertakers of the
beniffits received thereby.

Therefore I hope in that God of peace, whose servant
he was, that he now also rests, himself in his Death
He shall enter into peace: They shall rest in their
Beds. Their Grave shall be a bed of hon.or, to him
it is so. blessed with a good fame, & name, which is like
the Savour of sweet, & Precious Oyntment, as Solomon
the wise saith, he serving the Lord here a few days is
blessed with this preicious oder forever. the name of
the Just shall live forever.

Each one, walking in his uprightnesse. the merciful
the Just. the upright. the holy. the Righteous. man. All
have their abundante blessings Matt 5.

And these fell upon the head of this good Josiah
Whom the Lord had such care of to deliver him from
those Evils following his Death. In that his Eyes
did not behold the Evils, which he brought upon this Land
In all these things, we have cause to bllesse our
gracious, & heavenly father, in fulfilling his word
to him, that is in this Text.

Making him happy in his name, & memory, to Pos-
-terity, living happilie here, & dieing in the Peace
of God, & with all the world. Peace at home. & abroad.
in his own conscience, & Soul, abundance, of tranquility
having walked uprightly all his days. And now
this Diligent labourour. of God was at last called
by his Lord, & has received, of him his hire.

Even the wages of Eternal Glory. with his Lord & God to
behold that fair beauty, & see him face to face.
& live with him forever. Now Mortall. has put on
immortallity. to followe the Lambe where ever he goes
Receiving, that blessed doome of him in Matt. 25: 34
Come yee Blessed of my Fathers & thou hast bin faith
-full over a few things. Enter thou into the Joy of
thy Lord.

Thus have we seen that God is able, & frequently
doth make it apeare. that the Death of the Righteous
Servants of God are exceding great blessings & a
happiness to themselves. when he gathereth them
48
Sooner from the wicked. preserving them safe in
the Grave from all violencies & outrages, both of
sin, & sufferings. & giving into their bosomes
An 100 times more the reward of his grace,
with Glory Everlasting. Peradventure on the contrary
When, as their deaths may prove a currse to
the world, to be left of such Mosesses & Samuells
which pleaded to god for them & whose Deaths are
too oftten fore runners of fatall Judgements, to
all hard harted, & incorigable sinners.

The Lord God, of mercy. grant to us all of his
Family, that this grand blow in taking our
Head from us may be a warning, to fear & serve
this great God, of our fathers. returning from those
evil wayes, & sins, which has offended him least
we perish by iniquity. learne by our Fathers
example to imitate his virtues. being in peace
& unity amongst our selves. that so living in truth
& peace, we may at Last enjoy the God of Peace. Amen.

div.head: A Prayer upon my fathers Death.
div.p:
Oh thou most great & Dreadful Lord God. mighty
in Power, & wisdom. which seest & knowest all things
in heaven & Earth & canst look us into destruction
yet A most gracious & Tender loving father of
49
Mercies to them that loves thy Majesty through thy
dear Son Jesus Christ our Saviour. I thy poor servant
sinful dust & Ashes, doe beseech thee, to make me truly
& sincerely humbled, & repentant for those Sins
& frailties, disobedience, to thy Commandments &
holy Laws, & childish follies of what nature so ever
that has offended thy pure Eyes. & caused thy Majesty
to be displeased, & to take my dear father from my
head. In whose wellfaire & life, my good & happiness
in this life did consist. And very much conduced too
my Eternal consernes, & good of my poor ignorant
Soul. By whose Providence. care & wisdom I have
bin upheld, succoured & maintained under thee
ever since I was borne. Injoyeing many blessings
& opportunitis of learning, to know & serve thee,
being taught by him, & my dear Mother what
things are necessary for my Salvation. he being
a grand instrument of good to all us his children.
O Lord forgive all our follies & Sins against thy Self
& him. pardon all our iniquities for the Lord Jesus Christ his
sake. Sanctify our hearts. & amend our lives by thy
grace & Spirit. And sanctify this great loss &
Affliction to me, & us all. learning us by thy corrections
to know thy power & serve thee with fear & love.

That thou maist return with a blessing in the keeping safe
my dear mother. & that our Sins Might not provoke thee
50
To take her away from us also. And so make our
selves miserable. Let us reforme of our vanities
becomeing new Creatures Obeing thy righteous
Laws who art the God of our father. that we may
be in Covenant still with thee.

Thou maist be our Father. Captaine, defender &
guide. Support. direction & preservation to
my Mother & us. according to thy good promiss
A father to the fatherlesse & a Husband to the
Widdowes, we may rest safely under the shaddow
of thy wings, forever to be defended, & delivered
from Sin & dangers. both Spiritual & temporall
Give unto me thy hand-maide. thy holy Spirit
to dwell in my heart for ever. to Rule my passions
governe my affections. furnishing my ??? with all
graces. gifts. & virtues requissitt to this high
calling of a Christian. That I may immitate the
good example thou hast set before me of my
Father to walk before thee in Righteousness
and holiness all my days. that thou O Lord mi-
-ghtest have the Glory of all thy mercies & goodness
showed to us in this infinite blessing of my Father
Let us be converted from dead works. that the temptation
of the Deivill. the world & the flesh. may never prevail
over any of us. to sin against thee. & disobey
51
my mother, or be stuborne to the Laws of our Father
And although thou hast pleased to deprive us of
his Life the guide of our ways. & head of us all.

Yet, O Lord I pray thee leave us not to our selves. to
Swerve from thy precepts. & Righteous Laws thou
hast set before us, either in thy word; or the Councells
of our dear Parents.

And since it has pleased thee. to take my father
away. for reasons known to they own wisdom. Let
a double portion of thy Spirit. be shoured down up
-pon the Head of my dear. Mother. Lord give her health
of body & Soul. strengthen her faith, & patience.
Comfort her in all her sorrows & sufferings.

Preserve her from all Evils & dangers. be thou her
Husband & guide in all her ways. And she trusting
in thee with all her ??? may never beforsaken. but bless'd
with a general Suply of thy graces requisitt in all her
weighty consernes. & business of this world.

That she may be preserved from the malice & Power of all
known & secret Enemies. let neither she nor us O Lord
want any thing with out the which we cannot serve thee in which
conditions thou hast called us unto. for thou alone canst
bless a little, & cause the widowes oyle not to faile, & we
shall be blessed. giving us safe resting places, in the
distractions that is coming upon us in these lands. that we
may sing praises to thy holy name.

Fullfilling thy will here upon Earth, a few days
which thou hast appointed for us. to live. that at the last
wee may live with thee for ever.

And Lastly O Lord most holy & gracious I yeald
thee all humble & hearty thanks and praise.
for all those favours & mercies. graces & gifts. with
the Blessings of this Life. & those spiritual. together
with the happy opportunities thou gavest to my
dear father. to serve thee in his generations. by
A happy successe in all his weighty Callings

The good Providence. & prudence by which he added
more improvements to his Estate then his Progenators
for his Justice, uprightnesse. mercifullnesse, Charity
to his Relations & straingers. in general.

for the favour & good will thou gavest him in his
own & a strange countrey. And for all the good wher
ever thou inabled him to doe, either for our Souls
or Bodies. These blessings, I humbly acknowledge
did alone proceed from thy divine goodness from
whence comes every good & perfect guift.

Therefore O Lord I beseech accept my gratitude, & praise
for all. And as thy mercy has bin so plentifully
bestowed to this family. adde this one thing more to
us. That all thy dispensations may be sanctified to us
In giving us grace to live accordingly. & may be a
holy people. as the redeemed of the Lord.

Not being stuborne & rebellious. By dishonouring
thy Majesty. But as lights shining to a perverse
people amongst whom we live. even to the salvation
of our Precious Souls in the day of the Lord Jesus.

Lord I pray thee also, endue me, with Patience &
humility. to sustaine this thy hand of punishment
to me by the departure of my father, and like a Christian
learne, betimes to follow my Saviour, even when thou
shallt call for all those comforts. I have, if that shall
seeme good for me in thy Eyes. Season my youth with
true principalls of Piety. & holiness. That whether
Prosperitie, or adversity. Afflictions, or crosses.
Povertie, or a compotency, thou shalt please to give
me to enjoy in this life. I may so devote my self to thy
service. That I may learne to see thee in all things.
& enjoy all things in thee. not seeking my happiness
in this world. may take up my Cross daily to follow
my sweet Saviour. dedicating my youth. in all
obedience, & filliall duty to thy comands. And my
virtuous Mothers. Being a comfort. & stay in her
weakness. & At her dispose in the Lord in all things.

That thus spending my days, according to thy word,
when I come at my end, I may rejoice in thy salvation
And live eternally in thy Presence, & Glorifying
the Blessed & glorrious Trinity with delight, & joy for
ever. And these most humble Pettions I crave for the
Lord Jesus Christs sake my dear Saviour.
Amen. Amen.

div.head:
A Prayer to be said before wee Receive.
Made by my father. before he went into.
Ireland 1628.
div.p:
O Eternall. Omnipotent, & most Merciful Father
thou that openest, & no man shutteth, & shuttest
and no man openeth, let the Wordes of our mouthes
& the Meditations of our hearts. be acceptable in thy
sight this time and for ever more.

O Lord God, by whom wee were created at the
first, by whom wee now live move & have our
being, Look not upon us as wee were placed at the
first, by thy divine Power, in the State of Per-
-fection, adorned with those Heavenlie qualities
of knowledge & freedome of Will, whereby wee
had some remsemblance of thee our Great Creator.
Neither as wee lye in the loynes of our frist
Parents
who, by eating that sower grape hath set an Edge
upon our teeth. Much Lesse as wee are defiled with
our own Pollutions. & uncleannes. But behold us
we beseech thee, in that State which thy divine Pro-
-vidence, through the Redemption of thy Son & our
Savioure Christ Jesus hath prepared for our Resto-
-ration, unto that happiness from whence we are fallen
that so wee who were altogether dead of our selves
, may by him be recovered unto that Everlasting Re-
-surection, which thou (that wishest the Perfection & continu
ance of what thou hast made). hast prepared for us before
the begining of the world, If wee fear thee & keep.
55
Thy Commandements.) Now, seeing O Lord, such
miserie hath accrued unto us, by the Act of the first
Adam, Wee humbly desire that wee may take hould of
the Covenant of thy free grace, which the second. Adam hath
prepared for us; And that wee may evermore Magnify thy
great & unspeakable Mercies in sending thine only
Son to become Man for us, who being with out Sinne
suffered for sin, that wee who were nothing but Sinn
might be made Rich by the imputation of his all sufficient
Righteousnes. But dear Father, such are our infirmi-
-ties, that wee have bin so far from Acknowledging
thy infinitte goodness towards us in sending thy only
Son to redeeme us, when we were utterly lost, so farr
from being thankefull to him, for his unexpressable love
towards us. that was content to suffer death, (even the
scornefull death of the Cross for our Sakes;) so farr from the
Perticipation of his virtues, or the imitation of his holi-
-ness and Examples; That those laws, which either by the
instinct of nature (a guide even unto unreasonable
Creatures) or by divine precept thou hast charactered
in our hearts, wee have as much as lay in our power, raised
out, by adding actuall unto originall sins; so that those
Wounds of his which our tears should have clensed, our
Sins have inlarged; those stripes of his which our Penitency
should have healed, our iniquities have reiterated;
And those scoffings, railings & unjust calumniations
of his adversaries, have bin augmented, by our neglect
of those duties & offices of Piety, which wee by his example
& precept should have performed to others, in so much
that we have Crucified thee again our Heavenly Saviour
by our impenitent & unproffitable lives.

Wherefore, though at all times wee ought to ac-
knowledge our Sins before God, (thee), who being a
Righteous Lord, lovest righteousness, & whose coun-
tenance will behold the thing that is Just, yet at this
time wee desire thy Especiall assistance, in confessing
our selves before the Throne of thy Grace (& Justice)
uprightly & necessarilie, where by thy grace wee
desire to participate of the the Body & blood of our most
dear & Merciful Saviour, because other wise wee -
shall be guiltie of our own damnation.

Com.
1st
Wee doe therefore O Lord: confesse, the wee have con-
-verted that acknowledging thee for our true & onlie
God (as thou commandest by fearing thy Name, lov-ing
thee above all Creatures both in heaven & Earth.
humbling our selves before thee. being patient to
endure what thou sendest, & hopefull onlie in thee)
Into an ignorance of thy divine will, a carnall
securitie & contempt of thee, a halting & counter-
-fitt love of thee, as well as an inordiate love of our
selves & others, an hipocriticall trust in thee. an
outward & counterfitt humilitie; an impatiencey
& murmuring against thee, lastly into a finall
desperation or presumption.

Com.
2d
Neither O Lord have wee Attributed that hon.or and
Glory to thy divine Majesty which became us, but in-
stead of Images & Idolls which thou hast forbidden
wee have given that honor
& Preheheminency to our
Wills, lust, our own desires, our own imaginations,
which have made our Selves liable to thy reproch and
indignation. in so much that wee cannot expect but
that thy justice should be intended.
57
Against us and our generations after us for ever.

Com.
3
But so guilty have wee bin O Lord of taking thy holy
Name in our mouths in vaine. That wee have not onlie
neglected that Duty of Honouring
& reverenceing thy Glorious
Name, by invocation, prayer & thanksgiving, the acknow
-ledgment & publication of thy praises; the glorifieing
of thy holy Name upon all occassions. but by railings,
bannings, cursings blasphemies. malledictions and
imprecations wee have profaned thy Great Name, by
foreswearing, false sweareing, light & common swearing
foolish calling thee to witness, rash vowes, wiles, deceipt
, lies, & such like untruths, vainely dishonoured thy
great & glorious Name:

Com.
4 And whereas like a merciful father, thou hast provided
six days for our necessaries & reserved but one for thy
Sabboth, wherein thou hast injoyned us a frequent use
of thy worship. as well in public congregations, as by
our selves, an attentive hearing thy worde, & workes, &
meditating upon both, a frequent use of thy Saraments
A Charitable disposition, to thy poor members whom
thou hast left here amonge us. In visiting the Sick &
comforting the afflicted, & releiveing the poor; wee have
contrarilie absented our selves from thy sevice & worship
contemned thy ministrie & Sacraments. neglected the hearing
& reading of thy Scriptures, & instead of prayers. deeds of
Piety, mercy, & charitie, wee have intermedled with prophan
& ordenary affaires of those days.

Com.
5 But allas dear father of Mercies, wee are not onlie guilty
of offending thee our Heavenly father, but have broken
those bonds & obligations which common civilitie and
humanitie hath appointed betwixt us & our.
58
Neighbours: for wee be commanded to provide for
our inferiours by imbraceing them with a fatherlie
affection, by providing for their maintenance and
Education, by instructing them in the fear & nurture
of thee our heavenly father, by giving them all good
examples, in our religious & honnest carriage &
behaviour; by chastising them for their offences
And to hon.or our superiours in heart worde & deed
& gesture; to yeild all obedience unto them, to
imitate their virtues, to express our thankfulnes
to them in word & deede, & to winke at their
imperfections & infirmities: Contrairy to those
duties, we have wanted of that Naturall affection
where with wee ought to abound; wee have neglected
our duties by contempt our scorne, to much indulgence
and rigour, by lightnesse & immodestie, & too much
boasting. Neither can wee excuse our selves. O Lord
Com.
6th
from hatred, anger, evil will, desire of revenge, wai-
wardness, peevishnesse, inhumanity, wrathfull looks
and such like misbehaviours against our neighbours,
Whereas thou hast commanded us unfeined love,
one towards another, benevolence, compassion,
meekenesse, long suffering, affibilitie, & all kinde of
courteous behauiour.

Com.
7th
Wee cannot but likewise acknowledge our lustfull con
cupiscence, in heart, word & deed, in repeating love
-songs, filthy talking, all manner of uncleanness, as
well with our selves as others: Whereas on the other side
thou hast enjoyned us all chastiety, modestie in our
actions, wordes, gesture attyre. behaviour, and conver-
-sations; Moderation at all time, in meat, drinke,
59
Sleep, & all such like necessaries. And thou hast
Com.
8. forbidden us all inward grudgings & longing after
Wealth by avarice, or coveting other mens riches: all
fraud, deceipt, tricks. in bargaining & selling: All
usurie, idleness, niggardise & Profusion of thy good Creaturs
, yet have we incurred the breach of all theise thy Heavenly
directions, by not dealing uprightly with our neighbour in
buieing & selling, by not caring to save him from damage
by not doing the workes of our calling, by not useing liberality
of frugalitie in all our actions.

Com.
9, 10
And wee must Lastly confesse O Lord against our Selves
that thou haste enjoyned us all plaine meaning and
speaking, all taciturnitie, grave speech, a moderate use
of the tongue, the bearing of a good oppinnion of our Neigh-
-bours, & judging, all things done by him to the best:

But contrarilie wee have delighted our selves to much
in lyeing, false testimonie pratling, scurrilitie, defa-
-ming, & backbiting, sinister suspittion, and wrongfull
judging our Neighbours. And now O Lord, by this
looking glasse of thy divine Law, wee see our selves
so strangelly deformed, nay, so much defaced, with byles
& ulcers, & wounds, how can wee conteine our selves
from sorrowe & repentance, till wee have washed away
theise sins and obliquities of ours in the fountaine and
comfortable streame of his Blood that died for us,
wherein being once dipped, though wee were before as deep
as scarlet, wee shall become as white as snowe:

Butt alass, we are not able to cast our selves into this
poole. such is our lameness & Imbecilitie; Without the
help of thy Spirit to work in us such a sorrow and
contrition that may alter and change these flinty
60
Hearts of ours, and make them hearts of flesh, or
rather from flesh convert them into Spirit.

Wee therefore O Lord, confesse our sins, and are Sorrie
for theise our misdoings; nay wee are Sorie O Lord
that wee can be no more Sorrie. Accept wee desire
thee O Father, the will for the deede, & conforme
our wills unto the deeds: Furnish us O Lord with
the sorrowe of attrition & contrition, which may work
in us a repentance never to be repented of Namel
lie, (as St Paull teacheth us), a carefullnes, which may
work upon our understanding, upon our indigna-
-tion for our sins past, upon our fear, in regard
of sins to come, upon our desire to good things;
upon our emulation to good Persons to immitate
them, upon our revenge, & punishment of our selves
for our sins: for if wee would judge our selves, wee
should not be judged of thee O Lord.

O send us therefore strength wee humbly beseech thee
O lord to punish our Spiritual sins of Pride, contem
-pt of God, wrath, desire of revenge, lusting after
vanities, with a calling to remembrance (with sorrow &
bitternesse our lives past, with the thinkeing upon the
judgements of hell & death, by studieing to be pa-
-tient to put up wrongs; to be ready to forgive sins
by setting our desires on good & heavenly things.

And give us grace wee beseech thee O Father to pu-
-nish our carnall sins of uncleannesse, gluttony, ease
sleep & the like, with chastising our bodies with abstinesse
, fasting, watching, meditations. Prayer, & devotion.

Help us wee also humbly beseech thee dear feather, to
punish our worldlie sins, of covetousness, Ambition
Pride, thirsting after the outward comodities & advan-
-tages of this World, By making restitution of what
wee have got contrariely to thy lawe: by being
compassionate & bountifull to our fellow members;
Then, shall wee by thy goodness, not only be freed from
the imputation & present guilt where with, our fore
past lives have now defiled us, but bestow our
future course of lives, in walking the ways of Godlines
going from grace to grace, from good work to good
Work, till wee attaine to that measure of perfection, which
thou hast apointed to us, during the time of our
Earthly Pilgrimage here.

And lastly, Most gracious, & Merciful Father.
Wee are humble sutors unto thy heavenly Majesty: that
wee may be assisted, with thy divine & gratious Spirit.
in the dutifull ordering our selves, before during the
time. and after the receaving of this blessed Banquett;
That before, with all the forces & facculties of our fraile
Mindes, we may Extoll thy goodness & wisdom in
sending thy onlie Son to Redeeme us, that at that
time we may magnify his obedience to thee, & love to us
for shedding out his precious Blood for us that were thine
& his Enemies: And after being clensed with that
Blessed Lavacre, be cairefull to keep our selves unde-
-filed that so now wee may by his grace be clensed:
here after by his favour preserved, & at the last by his
love be presented spottlesse & unblamable, before thy
62
Throne of thy Justice, who hath dearly bought
& redeemed us, Even thy Son Christ Jesus the
Righteous. In whose name & words, wee present
these our humble requests unto thy divine Majesty
and whatsoever shall be now or here after
necessary for us in Souls or bodies Saying as he
hath taught us. Our Father &c.

div.head:
My Mothers Preservation from the Irish Rebellion
Octb. 23 1641. A Thanksgiving for
our great deliveration:
div.p:
Many, & great was the sorrows & sufferings of my
dear & hon.ord Mother, with her whole Family upon
the sad change, by the death of my Honred Father-
And she continued in her house in Dublin. Mainta
-ining the great household in the same condition as it
was. At her own charges, for the honor of the same, to
her own disadvantage many ways.

for she by that means tarried in Ireland, dischar
-ging those Servants & paieng many debts, which
should have bin don by the Executor longer then she
could well doe; in regard that her Jointure being in
England she wanted suplies.
thus she continued
till about the october after, when on the 23d day in the
year 1641 that horrid Rebellion & massacre of the
poor English Protestants began to breake out in the
countery. which was by the all seeing Providence of God
prevented in the Citie of Dublin where we were.
63
In the vacancy of a wise & prudent Governour. af
ter my Fathers death & my Lord of Straffords imprisonmt
by the Parliament in England. That nation was under
the authority of Justices. the Lord Parsons. & Lord Burlacey
These 2 old gentlemen havein lived in Ireland many
Peaceable years could not be made sencable that the Irish
had an ill designe against the English & therefore did
not take notice of their frequent numerous meeting
in a strange insulting manner. but when they were in
formed by some judicious men neglected the searching in
to that business. till through their remissenesse the
faction had got deep roote, & headed there designs
to a full maturity.

Which undoubtedly had overwhelmed the whole body of
the English there as well in Dublin. as the Countery. had
there not bin a most miraculous discovery of the Plot
made in Dublin, by which as the means our gracious God
appointed we were delivered from Perishing in those
flames intended for us.

The Lord Mackmaughhan & Mackguire, two of the Ring
Leaders of this wickedness. was desined to Sease upon
the Castle of Dublin, which at that time was Richly stored with
All Amunition, Arms, ordenances. & other Artillery
for the defence of the Castle & Kingdoms. by the Lord Lieueten
Strafford, well knowing that the Irish must be ride with a curb
But this place of the English strength; was then cairlessly
at that time deserted; none being set to gaurd the bridge &
& gates. but 4 weak old men that could make no resistance
That night being (satterday), before Mackguire should
have taken possession of the Castle. he being desined the governor
thereof, by the Rebbells. & should have seized on it on the
64
Sunday morning. Mackmaughan willing to save
a kinsman of his own name that lived then as a servant
with Sir John Clottworthy an English man, writt his
cosen a letter to Dublin to meete him in great haste
about a bussinese of great consernment.

his cosen imeadiately took horse & ride into the Country
but finding him gone to Dublin followed, & discovrd
where he and Magguire was set drinking in a blind
Alehouse, at which dore they had set men to guard it
Now this had bin converted a Protestant about a
year before & married to an English woman. but they
knew not that he was turnd. he observed along time
by there ways & impious expressions that they used to
wards the English. so much as he feared some bad
designe in hand & therefore was the more diligent
in following them, to discovery.

When they were mett they fell to drinke much, they
causing him take more that he might be drunke. but
he desired them to tell him what they sent to him
for. Mackmaughan clapt him on the back & told
him that there was the galantest designe which was Ploted
&, to take effect shortly, against the English Doggs,
that could be to cut there throats, & to morrow by 6
a clock in the morning said he my Lord Mackguire
will be master of Dublin Castle. & they would
Batter down the Town over the Heriticke Dogs
eares & not spare one of them.

After which speach his cosen the Protestant started,
& cried out, what shall I doe for my wife.

They said hang her. for she was but an Eglish
dogge.
he might get better of his own country. so he conside
-ring himself to be in their hand, who would murder
him, if he resisted, complied for the time, till he found an
opportunity to get away. which they began to suspect
& gave warning to the gaurd to kill him if he went out
so they dranke on, till the Protestant was forced to requir
leave to go into the next roome, for they durst not trust
him farther. And he withdrawing thither. broake down
the window, & leaped out of an upper roome. & over a
wall before he could make an Escape to acquaint the
Lord Justices. But this man had also the River to Swim
at that time of night which was 12 a clock before he came
to the first Justice which was Sir Will.m Persons.

Rising come to the Gate he was forced to threaten hard
before he was admitted. & then he told him. My Lord
I am sent to you by the Providence of God. to save your
Life & all the English. I am bound in conscience to deliver
my own soul in there preservation from the Irish who
intends to destroy them all, & told him all the foregoeing
sircumstances telling him with all that he must not look on
him as an idle drunken fellow. but as one which had all
-most lost his own life to preserve his. & that if he did
