not take care to prevent this mischeife all the innocent
blood of the English would be required at his hand.

With many such like expressions. after which there was search
made for the two Rebells. but non was found till the same man
which discovered the Plott found them himself, hid in the top of
that house with in a Trap dore. so they were taken & secured
& we all poor sheepe destinated to destruction was thus
wonderfully preserved & delivered in Dublin.

Whereas the Rebellion began that Sunday in the Country
with sword, fire, & murdering all before them, not
spairing infant of days nor old Age. all was made
havocke of & so continued till they had notice
that it was discovered in Dublin & were prevented by
our forces which defended the Cittie.

Yet cannot it be immagined. but we had our shair
in Dublin. when we were forced upon the Alarume to
leave our house. & fly into the Castle that night. with all
my mothers Family & what goods she could.
from thence we were forced into the Citie. continueing
for 14 days & nights in great fears, frights & hidi
ous distractions & disturbances from the Alarums &
out cries given in Dublin, each night by the Rebells.
and with these frights, fastings & pains about sacking
the goods, & wanting sleep, times of eating, or refresh
-ment, wrought so much upon my young body, that
I fell into a desperate flux. called the Irish disseas
being nigh unto death, while I stayed in Dublin, as
also in the ship coming for England.

But my dear mothers care was exceeding great
for my 2 brothers Christopher & John. with Tom Danby
& kitt my sisters two elldest sons. & my self.
In providing a Ship to transport us all together
with her good Plate, & houshold stuffe in Dublin. which
she affterwards delivered to my uncle will.m Wandesford
after she came to weschester. But it pleased God to
give us all a safe & quiett passage out of Ireland
67
In to England. landing at the Beerehouse neare
Neston. Where we ttarried several weeks by reason of
my distemper, brought out of Ireland, when we fled
from the Rebells.

This I say brought me exceeding weak, so that I had a
Doctor from Chester for my cure. After which with the great
care & love of my dear mother. God was pleased at
that time to restore my life, & strengthen my great
weakness, inabling me to go to Chester in a Coach.

Thus did the great God of heaven, & Earth preserve us
most miraculously in all our dangers & extreamities
bringing us safe, all to our own native Countrey.

Blessed be the most high God, Possessor of Heaven & Earth
which preserved our lives from all manner of destruction.

div.head:
A thanksgiving for preservation
from the Rebellion in Ireland Octb 23 1641.
div.p:
O Lord, great wonderful & holy. which sitteth in the
heavens, in the glory of thy majesty far above all things
in heaven & Earth; And that beholdest us the poor sonns
of men with the eyes of mercy & pity when wee are in distress
& calamities, delivering us from Ruin & murders.

What shall I say, or can I express how wee are bound unto
unto thy gracious Majesty for thy Providence that watches
over us for good, who saw & discovered these wicked
bloody practices of our implacable Enemies that secretly
laid traps to destroy our Souls. O how should our gratitud
exceed all others, who has bin delivred by a most strainge
providence & preserved safe sleeping & wakeing.

When as thousand souls, more innocent then our selves
perished. & was swallowed up sudainly in the pitt of
horrid murder & fury prepared also for us in Dublin
Oh my God what shall I say, which am astonished at
the miracle which none but thine Almighty all seeing
powes,
& hand, could have prevented. thou O Lord
hadst a care of me even from my birth, & youth up.
And hast preserved me from great &, infinite dangers
but this exceeds all other thy boundlesse goodness to
my self. My mother, & brothers with her two grand-
chilldren; from the utter destruction of all her Posterity.
O what shall I render to the Lord our God for this his great
deliverance of all our Souls. That did not give us up to
destruction amongst the many 1000ds that perished. to be
murdered, stript, slaine, burned, drowned, or into
any one of their damnable practtices against my
innocent Soul. O Lord what am I, or my fathers
family, that thou shouldest take care of us.

But even for thine own name sake, & tender mercy
who gave us our lives for a Prey, in a strainge Place
and delivered not up our lives to the sword, famine
Pestilence, & Rebellions. I will magnify the name of
the Lord most high; while I have my being will I praise
thy holynesse for ever. which saved me from perishing
in the sea. and gave us a speedy & safe passage out
of Ireland, free from stormes, & tempests. Raising
me up from death, that I was nigh unto, even of that flux
he it was that brought me helps, & blessed the means which
was given me to cure that infirmity.

Yea the Lord hath done great things for me already
whereof I do rejoice. & my Soul is filled with gladnesse,
O Lord I beseech thee, Give me grace to make a good use
of these deliverances, & mercies, afforded. to tie me fast
by the bands of faith, & obedience, to thy holy Laws. in
this my youth, that thou spairest. that so I may be a blessing
to my Mother & relations. And since thou hast freed
me from these bloody minded men. So o Lord deliver my
soul from my Spiritual Ennemies, from the violencys of
Satans temptations, & secret devices, deluding my soul
with snaires of Sin & evil, nor that I should be overcome
by any Sin or polution, of the world. to offend thy gracious
Majesty, which has don so much for my soul. but that I may
love thee with delight & joy. following the vertuous Exam-
ple & dictates of my dear father, & mother, praising
thee with all my might, & laing out my endeavours for
thee here, that at the last I may live with thee for ever in
heaven, to glorify the Lord to all eternity. And this
I humbly crave for Jesus Christs sake our only saviour
Amen. Amen.

div.head:
Upon my Mothers coming to Weschester from Ireland
& of my having the Small Pox. in Feb. 20th 1642.
div.p:
After our coming to Weschester from the Beerehouse neare
Neston, when wee fled out of the Irish Rebellion. It pleased
God to move the gentry of the Cittie to be exceeding courteous
& civill to my dear Mother & my self. assisting her with
what necessaries she wanted in a strange place, & such
pittie & favour we found. that she wanted nothing in that
Place which our Neighbours procured not for us. in which number
was Dr Manwaring & his wife. Sir Thomas Smith & his Lady
70
And Family. all being very dear friends to us.
My Lord Cholmely & his Lady, with many other persons
of qualitie. several of which would have furnished
her with monnyes. but she wass unwilling to trouble
any. still expecting returnes out of yorkeshire.

July
17th ---
1643
But the warres falling out hott at that time, being wee
were beleagured in Chester by Sir will.m Brewertons
forces for the Parliament & there happened a strainge
accident which raised that Seige July. 19th 1643
As I was informed; there was 3 granadoes shott in
to the town but through providence hurt noebodie.
The first, being shott into the Sconce of our Souldiers.
with in 2 men of the Captaine Manwaring. but having
an Oxes hide ready, clapt it there on. & it smot-
-hering away in shells did not spread. but went
out. The 2d light, short of the Cittie, in a ditch, with in
a Pasture amongst a company of women milking
but was quenched with out doing them harm at all.
Praised be the Lord our God. The Last fell amongst
their own horse, short of the town. slaing many
of them, & by that means the Seige was Raised.
thus was we freed from great evils to befall that
town, while wee staid there. that sucseeded after
we came into yorkeshire. which still the Lords hand was
Streached out for our Preservation in each place
we came to it was a sanctuary to us, blessed be the Lord
most hight for all his goodness towards us:

But I had in this time of the seige, a grand deliverance
standing in a Tirritt in my mothers house. having
71
bin at prayer in the first morning we were besett in the
town & not hearing of it before. As I looked out at
a window towards St Maries Church. A Cannon Bullett
flew so nigh the place where I stood that the window sudain
-ly shutt with such a force, the whole Tirritt shooke. And
it pleased God, I escaped, with out more harm, save that
the wafte
took my breath from me for the present. &
caused a great fear & trembling. not knowing from
whence It came. I bless, and praise the Lord our God for
this my particular preservation at that time.

Also my Brother John Wandesforde, was preserved
from death in the small Pox. he having taken them of one
of my cosen waill.m wandesfords sonns living then at
Chester. Great was my mothers fear for him, & care
& pains she took about him. and at last he through
mercy was recovered. Although he was very much dis-
figured having bin a very beautifull child. & of a
sweet complextion. In the time of his sickness I was
forbiden to come to him least I should get the small
Pox & indanger my own life. & so observed my mothers
command in that.

But my love for him could not containe it self, from
sending in letters to him, by a way found out of my
foolish invention, tieing them about a little dogs neck
which being taken into his bed, brought the infection of
that dissease upon my self, As also the sight of him
after his recovery. being strooke with fear, seeing him
so sadly used, & all over very read. I immediately
fell very ill, & from that time grew worse.

Till I grew so dangerously ill, & inwardly sick;
that I was in much perill of my life, by their not coming
well out. but kept at my heart. not withstanding
all the means of Phisicians, or others, that my dear Mother
cost & care she used for me. yet I was well nigh death.
But blessed be the most gracious God, & Lord of mercy
, which pleased to hear our pettions for my life, & to spair
me in much mercy. & caused them to come well forth
& so by degrees the malignity of that Dessase abated when there
was many in that place died of it.

There was in our house a little boy, that my father had taken
for charitie. This Frank Kelly falling sick on good
friday (& I on the next day) was most sadly used in great
extremity, of pain, & sickness, & miserabley sore.
& could now swalow. his sight was eaten out, &
his mouth very sore, notwithstanding all the great
care, & industrie of my dear mother 2 wattchers
& the same helpes of a Dr & meadicens we both had,

And great was my mothers love & charitie for him so that my
dear mother, she did sit up many nights with this
poor boy, & drest his sores, with all offices as diligently
as if he had bin her own child, notwithstanding
his loathsome dissease. All the time of this boys
sickness, he was so full of sweet expressions & Hea
venly minded, with much acts of Religion. that it was a
great comfort to my mother, & all about him. with a
bundance of patience, & gratitude to God, & my mother
for all they had don for him.

Every one being astonished, to hear his wonderful, hope
Repentance, for his Sins, against God, in the time of his igno-
-rance, before he was converted from Popery, & since, his
several confessions with sorow, & bitternesse of heart, for them
& praing, them to intreat God for him. Then would he
beyond expressions stedfastly declaire his faith, hope &
beleife in the mercies of God, through his redeemer Jesus Christ
alone, for salvation of him, & commending his soul to God
in much prayers & meditations, both aloud & often in his
slumbring to their great admiration: that the goodness of
God should condesend, to make himself known to a poor
child, in uttering forth infinittly more then almost any
could express.
And was an abundant satisfaction to my
dear mother, to see an improvement of grace, & religion,
in his heart, since he was brought into her house; it being
not two years, at which time he was a Papist after his own
poor Parentes religieon. but after he came into my father
house in Ireland, & brought into England, by my mother.
he was through all good instructions, & teatchings, as to
Read, & his cattechisme &c. it pleased God to open the eyes
of his Soul, & he became a true convert, & a patterne of
much goodness, & vertue, that I never saw the like in many
years, above his, being about 9 years old.
This poor boy
alalong his sickness, still praied for me when he heard
I was in danger of death desired with tears that God would be
pleased to spare my life & to bless me that I might live to
doe much good to others. as to him, & that he might rather
be taken away & I spared. & he lived till I was well
again. & would have gon to seen him. but he by no means
74
would suffer me, least his extremity should doe
me harm, but I standing where I could hear his vioc
& he mine. he blessed God heartily, & rejoyced to hear
I was delivered, & hoped God had heard his Prayer
& that you said he might live to the glory of God.

And it did please our gracious father to releive him
out of his missery by Death, about 14 days after
this good child whom he had fitted for himself died
uttering many gracious speeches, out of the scripture,
& abundance of patthaticall prayers, & Petitions to
God: for himself, my mother & us all, with hearty thanks
often to God, who had taken him out of that wicked way
as he calld it, wherein he undoubtedly had bin damnd
bring him to believe aright in God, for his salvation.
with many hopefull & religious expressions, more then
could be expected from such a Child. he freely & will-
-ingly gave up his soul into the hands of his Redeemer
with come Lord Jesus & receive my soul, & so died.

I had great reason to take especiall notice of the great
goodness of God to us, in giving us opportunity to
bring this poor Soul out of the darknesse & ignorance
of his sinful education in which he was. & it was the
good providence of God, so to order it, thus the accident
was.
As my father was upon the greene, one day bowling
seeing a poor naked boy in Rags, yet pritty & nimble
was very officious in gathering up his bowles. He took
notice of him with intentions of charity towards the boy.

Askeing him several questions. & hearing his witty
answers, seeing him an Irish orphan, had compassion on
him. and told him if he would be willing to forsake
all his old ways that he was bred up in his Papist friends.
he would bring him up in the true fear of God. And
he would take care of him & provide for him that he
should never want all his days.

At which the boy was very glad, & said he thanked his Lordship
& that he would be willing to learne what he should put
to him. & would pray for him all his days. so from that
he took him home, clothing & nourishing him till he died
& then my mother continued the same in her house where
he received such instruction & as that I hope the Lord had
glory thereby, & that poor soul now reapes the beneifitt of
of such charity.

div.head:
Receaving the
1 sacrament
A Thanksgiving after my recovery
from the small Pox in Weschester: 1642.
div.p:
Blessed be the great & gracious God, & father of mercies
the Lord most high, which had compassion upon me a poor
fraile wretch, & spared my life, from this destruction
in this sad sickness, or to have such a lamentable
disfiguration, & be loathsome to my self or others, as
this poor child was. thou o lord, full of compassion did
with hold thy heavy hand from falling upon me in such
a measure, though I was justly brought into great dan
-ger & much extremity, to let me see thy displeasure
for sin. & thy power to take off thine hand when thou
pleased. Lord thou hast spared me when there was no
hopes left, then didst thou turn again & restore my
Life.

And spared me as a man spared his only son.
O Lord let it be in mercy that thou hast preserved me in
these wonderful manners of all thy late & former de
-liverances. Make me I beseech thee a vessell fitted
for thy service here, that these signall deliverances
that thou hast showed to me in this Citty, & Ireland,
from thy Enemies, who would have devoured us up
soone & swallowed us quick. from those imminent
dangers in the time of the seige, making me escape from
that Cannon bullett. giving me a kind affection among
-st these strangers. & those dear expressions of love
of my dear Mother, in all my weakness, & sickness
with all the means was used for my preservation.

Thou O Lord hast don it, and to the glory of thy name
I return my humble thanks & praise, where as I,
& my brother escaped, when this little boy in our house
was taken, & 100ds in this town died thereof.

O dear God since I have daily my life given me, a
new make me joyfull in thy salvation, wherein thy
great mercies are made more manifest. then to many
in the world. O let my soul be precious in thy sight
who hast delivered me with great Miracles. Sanctify me
from my youth, & all to thy service. that I may be free
from the follies thereof, & dedicate all the facculties of
my soul to thy service. Thou which hast brought me from the
womb to live to see the 15th year of my life run.

Alsoe I praise thy name principaly for thy great favours
in thy beginnings, in making thy self known to me in
the Receaveing thy most holy, & blessed Sacrament which
78
Is the first time I had the happiness to doe, in this Cittie
O Lord I beseech thee forgive my Sins & unworthinesse, my
Childish-nesse, & ignorance, & unpreparednesse. being unfitt
to draw nere to so holy a great God as thou art. And with
all accept my true & faithful endevours to come to thy
holy Super, wherein thou offerest to be received by faith
& grace spiritually into my Soul. Grant that I may receive
& applie all thy mirritts to heal my wounded soul. and
pardon my Sins, as verily as I have bin made pertaker
of these outward ordinances. And I beseech thee bless
thy handmaid, & receive and accept this thanksgiving
& praise from my ??? as thou didst from thy servant David
which loved thee from his youth. as I have desired to set God
allwaies before me that I may not offend. Lord give me underst
tanding & I shall live before thee & praise the Lord for all his benifits
afforded to me for soul & body. all which I humbly beg in
the name & for the sake of my dearest saviour his sake, the
Lord Jesus Christ the Righteous. to whom with the holy spirit be
all glory & power, might dominion, thanksgiving &
praise for ever more Amen.

div.head:
A discourse of passages, & delivernces of my mother &
us 3 Children after her removall from Chester, to Snape
& till we came to Kirklington. 1643, 434
div.p:
Aug.
28
1643.
From Weschester my dear mother removed with her 3 yonger
Children. Alice. Christofer. & John wandesforde. (She having
sent her 2 grand sonns home from Chester before the seige)
with these, & several servants & tennants, though with much difficulty
by reason of the interchange of the Kings Armies, & the Parliament
she was brought into the Town of warrington, towards coming
in to Yorkeshire, she finding more favour by reason of the Captains
Civility. & by a pass from Collonel Shittleworth then usuall.

Seeing nothing but a weak company for her Person. &
having lost all in Ireland, only 2 Trunks of wearing
linning. they gave her leave to pass. & about 10 a clock
at night, we came weary into the town of warrington.
After a while, we were entertained, with (Alarums as was
pretended) from the Kings party in Chester. this was
but to awaken their diligency the more. but there was
no cause; for that poor Town had work enough to defend
it self from its Enemies.

From warrington, we went to Wiggen the next day,
being a Town Zealous for their King, & Church. wee
found it sorely demolished, & all the windowes broaken
many, sad complaints, of the poor inhabitants being
at our first coming was scarred least we should have
bin of the Parlament party. Their cries were the greater in
respect they were inforced, to see the burning of 500d
of their own Bibles. publickly at the Cross by the Soldiers
which they plundered, under pretence of being Popery,
in their Service books. and reviling them with the names
of Papists Dogs. But this Town had bin preserved
from such false doctrine, or herisie, & would have died
for the true Proffession of the Prottestant religion.

The memory of Dr Fleetewood was so famous at that
time with them, which was a most Pious Godlie Minister
living about 30 years since with them & by his life &
doctrine had set such good order amongst them that they
still retained the true Religion he taught. They heearing
that my mother was his neece, flocked abundantly to see her
80
usuing all the civilities, & kindnesses imaginable, to her
for his sake. & notwithstanding that their Bibles & books
were burnd. never neglected the prayers at 6 a clock in
the morning & 4 in the affternoone.

The next day, we passed from thence towards yorkeshire
with many prayers from this People. And when we came
to the borders of Lancashire, at a place called downham,
we were not permitted to pass. but with harsh language, &
Abuces by a Parliament Corporall, & his gang. they would
not believe our pass. but took us down, swearing &
threatning, we should be striped. so my dear mother
& all of us was forced to come into a pittifull house for
shelter, & lie there all night, with heavy hearts, least we
should have bin used barborously, as they continued in
threatning against my fathers, widow & children.

but lo our gracious Lord God, who sees all wrongs &
indignities offred, to his servants. in his due time rights
them, did bring us safe out of all our fears & dangers,
blessed be his holy name for ever. & turned shame upon
those cruell men that did abuse us. That night 2 of them-
selves with my mothers servant. went to Coll. Shittleworth
10 miles off. who upon the sight of his own pass. did de-
-claire his grand displeasure for their rudenesses to my
Mother, & Child: causing his nephew Captaine John Ash-
ton to punish those vilaines & convey her safe as far as
his quarters laid, wishing her a good jorney. Thus did
the Lord of hostes deliver us all & making our Enemies our
friends. O praised be the Lord God of our Salvation delivering
us from bonds, imprisonments & plundering. fears &
frights.
O that we might live to his praise & glory, of his name

Sept.ber
2d
1643
My mother was minded to go to Snape, where my
Sister DanlyDanby was. & being invited by her she went
Sirfett Lobster
at Richmond ----
Sept.
15th
----
1643
thither to live, till she could better dispose of her self,
& us in those troublesome times. For it being in the
heate of the warres she could not live at Hipswell her
Jointure, which was molested, some times with the Parliaments
& then the Kings forces amongst them. (to uncle Nortons)
So that for a whole year we lived, with great comfort and
safety with my sweete Sister Danby at Snape.
where she
to snape
from
Rich.
Octb.
11 43.
was delivered of a galant Son even in the midest of troub
-les. God gave her comfort. & my brother would have
him called Charles. because of his ingagement for the
Kings service.
Now while we lived at Snape my brot
Bro. Jack to
B. Sco
No. 16.
43.
-her Christopher W. was exceedingly tormented with the
fits of the spleene. having taken them upon the death of
my Father, with grief in the Church at his funeral.
seiseing them upon him they continued sore, notwith
standing all good means used, laboured & endevours of
my mother. & us all, with all means, meadicens & ad-
-vices of Phisicians for him. I am witness & many more
that not any thing was wanting. which might conduce to his
Nov.
22
to Scoole
23 43.
recovery. At the last she sending him to Dr Batthurst
at Yorke. where by Gods blessing he was perfectly cured
of this distempers. This was indeed a great deliverance of
him from this distemper wherein many that has seen him has
begged of the Lord to take him out of those torment. And at
length through great mercy he was delivered.

It was advised that my Mother should go from Snape & live at
yorke. for the better Education of my 2 brothers, Christopher
& John.
As for my Eldest brother George being then in
France, was happy under the Tuittion of one Mr George
Anderson, a scotch man. but a most sober, wise discreet
Person. A great scholer, & excellent qualified man, and
of grand abilities. A Zealous divine for the Church of
England. an indeed a most Excellent good Christian for
his life & conversation.

Under the conduct of this good man, was my deare brother
George, happiely placed for his Education, in all good, & commen
-dable qualities, in France, during the heate of the warre, in part,
Although he was compelled to return into England for lacke
of supplies when his Rents was seized on by the Parliament,
Through which he endured a great deal of hardship.
But to return
to my Mother who prepared for Yorke, with her Children
& goods intending to live there. But it pleased God we
was prevented from going further, then a place in the
half way. when we were mett with a friend. Mr Danby of
Cave, who gave express notice to my mother. that as she
loved her life. not to go to Yorke. For the Parliament forces
had mett with the Kings, & they were all betrayed. & so was
forced to retreat, & that town would be beseiged, and so
this counsel came seasonably, & happiely, to hinder our greater
troubles & sorowes upon that Townes surprisall. Praised be the
Lord our God which did prevent those evils, & preserved us in our
way. when we were nigh to danger, & knew it not.
for this
poor Gentleman Mr Danby was soone after, Killed on the
moore for the King, when the Kings forces was almost all de
-stroyed & cutt down by the Scotts & the Parliament Army.

After this my mother, & family returned, & came
to Kirklington, where she stayed at Mr Paggetts the
Minister, being most kindly entertained & received
till the hall was made fit to dwell in. in that time
after she came thither in the year 1643. was the battle
of Hessome & the taking of yorke. & she was much con-
-serned for my brother Christofer wandesforde being
then at Yorke for cure & at Scoole.

Butt it pleased God in providence so to order it un
-expectedly my brother George. was newly come over
out of france, being at My Uncle Osbornes at Keveton
& wanting suplies in the warres time, was forced to come
toward his Estate, about Richmond. at that time
when the Armies was in Battailie, & was surrunded
in his passage to Yorke. but when he perceived that the
day was lost from the King. he rid to fettch my brother
Kitt from thence. where as he happiely mett him riding
out of the town to see the fight. he took him up behind
him & brought him safe to Kirklington, that night butt
was pursued by a party of horse, of Scotts. & at a 11 or
12 a clock at night, we received both my brothers home
safely, out of those great dangers of being Murdered.
blessed be God our Saviour & high deffence, to the poor de-
-solate widow, & her Children, in these horrid distractions
& fears, of ours, & the Churches Enemies, thus did we receive
them home again, with great Joy. But my poore brother
George Wandesford durst not stay at Kirklington, the next day
by reason that a party of horse was dispatched to seise on
him, suposeing him a commander, in Arms for the King. But
84
he was forced to fly for his life. & secure himself where
he could, the Lord still preserving him from his unjust Enimis
being an innocent Person. & never ingaged in either party
& who was but newly returnd in to his country. & this was
his first salutattion & wellcome into it.

div.head:
A deliverance from a Surfett of Lobster.
at Richmond 1643.
div.p:
Affer this when the scotts had helped to overthrow the Kings
Army at Yorke, for which designe they were called in to England
&, to destroy the Regall Power, of his Majesty. waiting upon
the Parliaments Motions, to fullfill the intent of the Scottish
Covenant, in Rooting out the Prelaticall Party, & the Establish
-ment of their Scottish Presbittery in the Ruin of the King
& Epicopacy. these scottch Rebells quartered them selves
All over, the Countery, Especially, in and, about Richmond.
forcing all People to take the Covenant, how contrary soe-
-ver it was to their duty of Aleagence, or conscience.
& those who would not; were forced to flie, or was impri-
-soned, & Ruined, so that my poore brother George was upon
this account compelled to live obscured, from all People, in-
regard that he would not be compelled to this treason, nor was
willing to be imprisoned, by them.

Sept.
15.
About the year 1643. We went to see my Aunt Norton
at Richmond, & to live a while with her till Hipswell was
fitted, & there itt Pleased God to preserve me from death
which I was nigh, unto by Eating a little peice of Lobster that day
I had taken Phisick, for it turned on my first sleep
when I wakned, into an exceeding terrible vomitting
& purging. & so followed with such violence that they
could not make me any help, nor could I have so much
85
Respitt or ease till I could take any thing, & this
continued, all that night, & the next day, till night;
butt by the gracious blessing of God, upon some respitt &
things given by Mr Mahum. with my dear mothers cair
I escaped that desperate fit, & by degrees was cured,
only it brought me very weak & faint.

Praised be, the God of all mercies for this his merciful
providence, in delivering my Soul from the gates of
death even adding this favour to the number of the
rest & giving me great & fresh occassions to lift
up my voyce in gratitute to the Lord of our salvation
O give thanks unto the Lord most high which is great
wonderful, & holy, the Lord increase my faith in thy
name & thankefullnesse to thy goodness. for these daly
deliverances & new lives given to me. Bless the Lord O
my Soul. with all thy powers, of Soul & body, all that is
within thee, bless his holy Name, & magnify him for
ever, which has delivered alsoe me, & all my mothers
house out of the violency of our Enemies which hates us
with out a cause, Lord bless us & all thy servants that
professe the truth of thy Religion, & suffers for a good caus
that they may be delivered at the last. & thy church & King
may be preserved to praise, & addore thy name, & that I
may be bettered by all these trials & troubles that thou see
fit to chaistise me with all in my youth, to bring me near
to thy Majesty in faith, & godlinesse, all my days
for my Lord Jesus Christ. Amen.

In the year 1644 no.ber 29.
After I was recruited in strength my mother went to
Live at Hipswell her Joyntyre with my B. George my self & George Lightfoot & Dafeny Cassell. & my D. G. W. his man.
And there she was troubled
with the Scotts one while & the Parliament forces another while
86
Tormented, us gitting all our provissions of meate and drink
, let us want all nesscessaries, yet there dominiereing & in
sulting voluptuousnesse must be suplied, & my mother
was charged for 18 or 20 months together with 25l a month
in monnys to the Soldiers, besides the quarting of a troope
of Scotts on free quarter, which was trible the valeue of
her Estate. & at that time she borrowed monnyes to
maintaine all her 4 children my brot. Christo. & John were at Beedale scoole from nov. the 16, 1643. many years which she paid afterwards
Albeit we had a particular maintenance to have bin
paid out of Kirklington, & for the heires part out of Hud-
-swell. Yet even in these times most sad and lamentabl
did the Lord most high preserve us from ruin, utterly &
made us have a Place of safety under his wings of
Protection. all those Evil times of fears and distractions
Blessed & praised be the god of our Salvation. Amen.

div.head:
The death of my Sister Danby: September 30th 1645 Sept. 10th 1645
at her house at Thorpe.
div.p:
About this year my deare, & only Sister the Lady
Danby drew near her time for delivery of her 16th Child
Ten whereof had bin baptised. the other 6. were still
borne, when she was above half gon with them, she have
-ing miscarried of them, all upon frights by fire in her
Chamber, falls, & such like accidents happening. All her
Children were Sons. saveing my two neeces, Katherine &
Alice Danby, & most sweet, beautifull, & comely were they
all. The troubles, & distractions of those sad times
did much afflict & greive her, who was of a Tender &
sweet disposition, wanting the company of her husband
Sir Thomas to manage his Estate. & other consernes.

But he being ingaged in his Kings service was not
permitted to leave it, nor come to Thorpe, but seldome
till she fell sick. these things, added, to the horrid rudn
-esse of the soldiers, & scotts, quartered then amongst
them, which vexseing, & troubling her much with frights,
caused her to fall into Travail. sooner then she expected
nor could she get her old midwife. being then in Rich
-mond which was then shutt up, for the Plague was exceed-
ing great there. so that all the inhabitants that could get
out fled saveing, those had the sickness in their hou
-ses.

At this time did my dear Mother & whole family
receive grand preservation from the divine Providence
in delivering us from the Arrow that flieth by day, when
as 100ds died so near us, & thousands, fell at noone
day, nay all that town was almost depopulated. how
did our good & great Lord preserve all us at Hipswell
, so that no infection seized upon any one that belonged us.
although the malice of the beggers was great to have
don harm by raggs, notwithstanding all her Charitable
Relief daily, with much meate, & monny. Blessed by the
great & ever merciful father, who did not deliver
us up to this heavy judgment, of the Lord but did reb
-buke the destroying Angell. & at last stayed this Plague
in Richmond.

But to return to my poor sister whose extreamitie
called her friends to her assistance. she had bin very ill
long time before her delivery, & much altered in the heate
88
of her body, being feaverish. After exceeding sore
Travail she was delivered of a goodly son about Sept 3d by one dame
sworre. this boy was named francis. after another of that name
a sweet child, that died that sommer of the small Pox.

This child came double into the world, with such extremity
that she was exceedingly tormented with pains. so that she was
deprived of the benefitt of sleep for 14 days; except a few
frightfull slumbers, neither could she eate any thing
for her nourishment as usuall.

Yet still did she spend her time in discourse of goodness
Excelently Pious, godly & Religious. instructing her
Children, & servants. & prepairing her soul for her dear
Redeemer. as it was her saying, She should not be long from
him. That week when I was left with her after my Lady
Armitage, & my Aunt Norton was gon. though she could
not get rest. yet all her discourse was very good & profi--
table to the hearers, who might learne Piety, chastiety
holiness, patience, humilitie, & all, how to entertaine the
pleasure of God with contentednesse. making so excellent
a confession of faith & other Christian virtues, & graces
that Mr Siddall. exceedingly admired her Partes & Piety
giving her the as high a carracter as could be.

She did intreat Sir Thomas her husband, to send for Mr
Farrer, & to joyne with her in the receaving the holy Sacramentt
but he would not give leave. which was to my knowledge a
great grief & trouble to her thoughts. That night
she powred out her soul in Prayer with such comprehensive
& good expressions that could be. for her own soul, for pardon
& remission of her sins, for grace & sanctification from the
spirit. faith & assurance, &c. then for her husband Children
Mother and all her other relations. & my self.

For the Restoration of the King, the Church, & the Kingdoms
peace, with such patheticall, & Jelous Expressions that
all did glorify God, for things he had don for her.
After which she did in a manner Prophesie, that God would
humble the Kingdom by Afflictions for there sin &
security. but after that when we were humbled and
reformed, whosoever should live to see it (for she should
not) should enjoy, happy days for Church & state.
thus she continued, & with prayers for our Enemies &
for they stood in need of our praires, for the forgiveness
of all their Evils.

She called her children, exhorted them abundantly
to fear God, serve him, & love one another, be obedient
to their father. with admonishing them, & her family;
she was kinde, & dearely affectionate to her husband, to whom
under God she left the care of her 7 young children.

Some times, she did express abundant joy in God, &
would sweetely, with a melodious voice sing aloud his praise
& Glory, in Anthems, & Psallmes proper for her condi-
-tion, with many sweet verces praising him for all things
, Nor was she in the least concerned to part with her husband
or Children, nor any thing in this world, having her hope
& desires fixed upon God. Leaveing her Children freely
to the Providence of her God, who had releived her soul
out of all her distress. who had promised to be a father
to the fatherlesse. All her words weere full of sweetnesse
& Affection. giving me manny hearty thanks for all
my pains, & care I took with her. & watching a whole
week together. if she lived she would requite my love
90
with an abundant of affectionate expressions, to this pur-
pose. My grief & sorrow was so great for her that I had
brought my self into a very weak condition. in so much
as my mother came to Thorpe with Dafeny Lightfoote a
cairefull servant, to help with my Sister. And sent me
home who was almost spent in that time.

At which time, I took my last leave of my dearest & only
sister, never could get to see her for my own Illnesse
affterwards. But she waiting her Lords time to be
called, was fitting her soul, & ??? for him. As the dissease
increased of the fever notwithstanding what could be
don for her in that condition, it did to her, as many others
in such extremity, deprive (her for want of sleep &
food which she could not take by reason of a sore throat)
of part of the use of understanding for a little while, when
its fury lasted. But Dafeny was alwaies with her. who
she had a great love for, and as she grew weaker after
a months time of her delivery, holding her head on her
breast, said to her in a faint weak voyce. I am going
to God, my God now. Then said Dafeny nay Maddam
I hope God will please to spare your life, to live amonggst
your sweet Children, & bring them up. how can that be an-
-swred my sister, for I find my ??? & vittalls all decaid
& gon (no:) I desire to be desolved, & to be with Christ, which
is best of all. I have made my peace with God. And imme-
-adiately she said, with as strong a voyce as she could.
Lord Jesus receive my Spirit, then giving a little
breathing sigh deliverred up her soul in to the hands
of her Saviour. sweetely falling asleepe in the Lord.

And thus ended that sweet Saint her weary pilgrimage
having her life interwoven with many caires &.
91.
Afflictions, although she was married to a good
Estate, yet did she enjoy not much comfort, And I
know she received her change with much satisfaction
being she hoped to be freed as she said from a wicked
world, & all the Evils therein. Thus departed that good
soul, having bin young called to walk in the ways
of God, & had made his service her contineuall practise
The Lord sanctify this sad loss of this virtuous
Sister of ours to the whole Family. & that as she lived the
ways of Godlinesse from her youth so she may be
a godly Example to all her Children.

She was a most obedient Child to her Parents loving
& loiall, affectionate, & observant to her husband
a tender, & prudent Mother to her children bringing
them up in the severities of Christian duties yet enough
indulgent over them with a Christian moderation.
A wise, & discreet mistresse towards her servants
who loved, & hon.red her in their obedience.

truly affectionate to all her relations in general &
courteously affable to all Neighbours, & friends.
And indeed a great loss to all amongst whom she-
lived, doing much good, & imployeing her time in
helpeing the diseased, & doing many cures. following
the Example of my mother in all those things.

She lived, after the birth of this Child. about a month
dieing on the 30th of Sept. 1645 10th of Sept. 1645 . And was buried that
night at Sir Thomas Danbys own Town in Massam
Church in the night by reason of the Parliament. Soldiers & Scots
who would not let a Sermon be Preached. Butt there was
great lamentation made for her Death.

div.head: The death of my Cosen John Norton. 1646.
div.p:
My Cozen John Norton died of a consumption, long in
A languishing condition, but at length it pleased God
to take him to himself in the year 1646.
He was a sweet good natured youth, he died at St. Nicolas

div.head: The Death of Sir Edward Osborne. 1646.
div.p:
My uncle. Sir Edward Osborne who was my mothers
owne half brother; was a very good, wise & prudent, man
under whose tuition my father left the hope of his house
my brother George, as being joynt gardian with my Mother
he had so fraternall a love for & parentall care over my
Dear mother, & us all; that we were most happy in
him. & during his life, this our Family was kept in much
peace & tranquilitie, he seeing that each party had its
right & dues. with a care for the due observance of my
fathers will, of which he was an Executor

Butt after his death, we (that is to say) my Mother, & her
Children was much opprest, & injured, through the bad
Managerie of all that Estate, & that was all seized on by my
Uncle Wand. for the Debts, which he was much wronged of too,
by one he made a Leace of it for 7 years, taking many
100d pounds more then his due, & before he got it again
he put him to a suite. but in this time all the Children was
Maintained, by my dear Mother, from her Jointure.

My deare Uncle Osborne being at Keeveton with his ladie.
And desiring to eate some mellons at the time of year
sent for several from his gardens at Thorpe, & Keeveton
And finding some excellent good. did eate a little freely. but that
fruit was too cold for him & strooke him into a vomiting &
Purging so violently that it could not be stayed, till his
93
strength was past recovery. so that in a few days time
he was deprived of his life. to the great & exceeding loss
to All his own Family, & ours, as also of his Majesties
& countery. he being a most Excellent good Christian, true
& orthodox, to the Church of England a faithful Loyall
subject to the King. & of a sweet & affable disposition to
all: in whose death I suffered the loss of a Father, & my
Mother, a husband. but he was very happy in a holy
good life, an high Esteeme in his Countrey. & of a great
fame for vertue; & much lamented in his death.

Making a sweet & comfortable conclusion, of his life
with an abundance of Pieious & Religious Expressions.
He died about the month of July: in the year 1646.
at Keeveton in the farthest part of Yorkeshire.

My Cozen Edmund Norton, Eldest son to my Uncle Norton
was married to Mr Dudlys Daughter & heir of Chopwell
in the Bishoprick of Durham Mrs Jane Dudly an excellent fine
& good gentlewoman. Feb. 10th 1647. at Chopwell.

My Cosen Edmund Norton died of a Plurisie at Yorke
the 30th of November: 1648. A gentleman of a sweet good
disposittion to all, obedient & dutifull to his parents & true
friend in time of adversity. a religious young man,
A faithful subject to his Majesty, for whom he suffred
much. he lived an honnest good, sober life, doing good
to all, died Religiously, & is I hope now very happy in
peace & rest, loving a peaceable temper. & was beloved of
all that knew him & An unmeasurable loss to his Parents.

div.head:
Upon the beheading of King Charels the Martyr Jan 30th
1648
div.p:
Our blessed King Charles the first. whose memmory shall
live to Eternity was cruelly Murthered, by the hands of
Blasphemous Rebells, his own subjects, at White hall.
London the 30th of Janueary: 1648.

Let all true Christians mourne for the fall of this Stately
Ceadar, who, was the chief suportt of the Church of God.
A holy, Pious, Prince, who fought gods battailes a-
-gainst his Enimes. being a nursing father a good
Josiah to his 3 Kingdoms. who for the defence of the true
Catholique Religion. of Jesus Christ his Lord. And for
the defence of the Noble Laws of this Kingdome of England. the
Protestant faith & the Privileges of the Parlament &
Subject. Ruling them in peace & happiness many years.
he laid doune his life. beeing sacrificed by the iniquitties
of his subjects; Their sins pulled down his Ruin on
him & our selves. let his admirable book speak his
Eternal Glory & praise, the best of Kings (as meere man)
that ever this Earth had. never defiling him self with sin
or blood. of a tender compasionate sweet disposition.
Incomparabley Chaste; & free from the least tincture of vice
or Profainenesse. Oh how may we take up justly those
bitter lamentations of Jerimie. The Annoynted of the Lord
the Joy of our hearts, the light of our Eyes, is taken in their
pitts. the Crown is fallen from our Heads. No unto us that we
have sinned, let every soul gird it self with saccloth, &
lament the displeasure of God which has smitten our head &
wounded the defence of this our English Church our Solomon Hezekiah
in him our staffe & stay, is gon. o repent, & humble your selves
you Daughters of Jerusalem, for him that clothed you in Scarlett
95
Is taken from you. what will you doe in this your day
day of Calamitty. o that my head were waters & mine
Eyes a fountaine of tears, that I might weepe for the slaine
of the daughter of my People, nay that our Eyes might gush
out with tears for this holy saint, & martire, of the Lord.
O Lord God, most great, and Excellent, in thy being &
Atributes. what shall become of me a vilde unprofi
table creature when thy displeasure has thus risen again
st the Head of thy Church here. for my sake & treatcherys
against thy goodness & mercy, has thy hand bin strea-
ched out, to deliver thyne onoynted in to the hands of
cruell men. O Lord I am ashamed, & blush before thee
who have provoked thy wrath against us. but o dear
Lord lay not this sin of murdering to my Charge, or having a hand in
compliance, with such as rose up against him. for thou
knowest that I have abhorred all such practices against
thy divine majesty, or thy vice Girent, on Earth. but
O Lord deliver me from blood guiltinesse that it may never be
laid to my charge nor my posterity. nor what else thou
knowest me to have committed against thy holy laws
& precepts. for many are my frailties, ignorances, neglect
of my dutis, to God & man. which might thus have disple
-ased thy goodness. and give me a holy heart & repentant
with all the graces that thou didst indow our Sacred Majesty
with all, fit for me. And be pleased to pardon the whole King
-doms of this bloody Crime that we may not Perish in their
sins that are guilty of this innocent Blood. O Lord hear
O Lord spare, & doe for thy sonnes sake, & smite us not
96
in thy Anger as thou mightest doe in severitty, for
this horrible, great & unheard of wickednesse. but have
Pittie & compassion, for thy mercy sake & destroy not the
Innocent with the guilty. O hear, Our dear Kings petti-
ons, for our forgivenesse, that he made, for his Enemies, let
not their iniquities be theires & our Ruin.

Give them a most sad, & deep repentance, & humiliation.
for this bloody fact, all who has had their hand therein
either Explicittly, or implicittly. & after a sharpe and
salutary repentance, give them pardon, & remission of
this horrid sin. And further O Lord, our God. still preserve
thy Church in this our Israell. And bring to us in peace &
safety our Lord & soveraine King charles his son. to
Rule Peacably, & religeously over us. with the Establishment
of thy true Religion in this Land.

And to this end doe thou most wonderfully turn the
hearts of all People to doe the same, that we may be
in thy due time freed from all these most sad plagues,
& judgments, that are all ready on us &. what we may fear
further for our impenitency, & hardnesse of heart.

O Lord give us truth, & Peace, against that these herisies that
are now Established as it were by a law, may be extirpa-
-ted, the hon.or our of the Lord Jesus advansed, our King re-
stored, & all thy Servants enjoy there inheritances as
thou hast given. And with all give us humble & penitent
hearts for all the abominations of this Land. & for this
great wickednesse Let us lay our mouths in the dirt bewal-
-ing all the malicious designs, & treasons against our
Lawfull King. Learning thereby more humility. & to be
contented in the subjection thou requirest. Sanctify thy
Dealings to me thy servant & make us better for the Lord
Jesus Christs sake.

That thou maist receive the hon.or & Glory by our true
convertion, when we see the Evil of our doeings. may be
again Established by thy Powerfull mercies. That all
the world may see the Glory of the Lord & give thanks unto
thy holy name. o holy blessed & glorious Trinity to
whom be all thanks, Praise hon.or and dominion for
Ever & ever. Amen. Amen.

My Cosen Julian Horton died at Richmond greene
at her fathers the 9 of April. 1649.

div.head:
Upon the Death of my brother George Wandesforde.
March 31 1651 & of his Sequestration. &
other troubles, after his return into England.
div.p:
The fatall blow given to my Fathers Family, by the
death of our excellent brother, was very great, but the
effects thereof fell out most heavy upon my self, in
the sad loss of so dear & loving brother. nay I may
say a father to us all.

He was a Gentleman excedingly qualified, with suttable
indowments both naturall & acquired. giving him-
selfe over in the qualifications for the service of his God
his Church. his King & countery, and such as rendred
him much beloved. & lamented at home & abroad.
for the great loss & sad conclusion of so brave a Person
Yet enjoyed he in his time, after my fathers death not
much comfort, for since his reture
[word] SiC ??? although presumably means 'returne'. out of France, in the
Public calamities of Church & State. he was driven to
many straits & hardships.

Being sequesterd through a false oath of his adversarys
suggestion, & his Estate, with all the other apoynted for widow
Children & Creaditors, of my father seized on for the Parlia
-ment upon that account. This don under the pretence of
Godlinesse & Religion, because he did not joyne in such
Practices of Rebellion against The Church of God. &
our Lawfull King whom God had commanded to be obeid
nor could any adheare to Such designs, whose hearts
was sencable of those duties of faith & Alleigeance
with out the danger of Eternal damnation. and the curse
of God upon them who seperated from the known Laws &
commands of God Almighty, and the Laws of the Land wherein
were happiely placed. our peace & Safetie.

According to that of the wiseman. My son fear thou God &
the king & medle not with them that are given to change for
who knowes the ruin of them both. Yet not withstand
-ing this threatning; Evil was so Established by a law
That there was no man of Estate which did not lift up
his hand against the Lords Annoynted, that could be freed
Eitther from plundering, sequestration & imprisonment
Robed, or murdered, by secret, or open hostilitie.
if any gave information against them. As for my brothers
crime, it was for disposseing of the Parsonage of kirkling
ton in his own right as heir, & of my Mother as a Gaurd
-ian to him yet under Age being but 19 years old, unto
Mr Siddall, A very Pious godly Minister. but not of
the Priesbyterian faction. This living being of too good
a valew for a Royalast, was looked upon by one Mr
Nesbitt of the other oppinion, & so the more confiding Person.
which could not be invested in to it, tell my brother &c was
made a delinquent.

After which it was conceaved upon such a crime as
Loyallty, to his God & Prince; this Privilege of the dis
posing of (this) with the injoyment of his own Estate was
sufficiently forfited. upon the poynt thus much was
confesst by Mr Nessbitt to my uncle will.m wandesf
-ord after my brothers death, being the cause why
he was sequestired.

In this condition was my dear brother amongst many
others most faithful in this Realme. And therefore they
might soone make a fault where there was none & poor
Naboth must suffer that an occasion might be found to
take his possession. Albeit he saw too evidently that the Kings
forces & Power declined. yet could not his Loyall heart
be gained to joyne with the Actors in this Rellellion, allth-
-ough there wanted not solicitations. but his heart-
could not with out abhorrency look on such practicies
, more abominable then that of Ireland. because masked
with a fair show of true Religeon, & Piety, to fight aga-
-inst the most Christian King that ever this Nation had.
under whose government we might have still continued,
happy. if our own sins ripe for judgement, had not prev-
-ented Gods mercies. And stirried up the Philistines with the
discontented Scismatticks, instruments for our Punishment
in their Rebellion. It mut
[word] SiC ??? i.e., must. not be denied, that my dear
brothers affectionse & conscience, carried him in judgment
to serve his King, the Church & State, by way of Arms.
yet as things then fell out, such was his prudence. for the
presservation of his Family, according to his gracious.
100
Majesties command to his friends. That he saw all
was lost, & that they should sitt in quiett, & preserve them
selves for the good of himself; or son; affterwards. So that
he saw it was in vaine to strive against that impetuous streame
to involve himself in utter Ruin, willfully, when no good
could possibly be don by his service to the King, otherwaise
then by our Prayers & tears for him. this was the reason made
him decline the ingageing into that warre.

Butt his Enemies vigilancy of all opportunitys to gaine
his Estate, & this Living afforesaid, had spies upon his ac-
tions wherein they might take an advantage against him &
had there designs furthered upon this accident.

I formerly showed how my brother was disposed of, for tra-
-vill in to france, for his improvement in Education.
At his return in to England & in his passage betwixt
my Uncle Osbornes house Keeveton to his own Estate &
my mother to Kirklington. he being ignorant of the
Armies ingagment that day on Hessome Moore. was to pass
that way towards Yorke home. but most unhappiely it
fell out contrary to his expectation, & before he could
retreat anyway found a necessity to secure himself
from the stragling company & so by providence light into
the company of my cosen Edmund nortons Troope that day.
till he got towards Yorke for the securing my second brother
there at schoole. After which Escape he came to Kirklintn
But this was the opportunity his Enemies sought. & with out
any questioning in to the true state of this business, set seve
-rall as Mr Luke wastell by name, whose family had bin
raised by my father) to examine too poor men which had bin
101
upon the moors that day. who were carried to Yorke on
purpose to sweare they saw him fight. but the wittnesses
would not take oath they saw him fight being more
just not to perjure themselves; then their masters, they
would give in evidence, only, that they saw him on the
Moore. so when the Kittes could not prevail with them
for a more full oath to their purpose. they were dis-
-missed with out any reward save much anger & repr
-oaches for their charges in that Jorney.

This dealing much incensed the poor men, who said
affterwardes they were trapan'd into that business, &
would not for the world have gon up. if they could have
foreseene the deisgne to have prejudiced my brother.
Neverthellesse this formalitty of the projectors was suff-
-icient ground to proceed against him as a delinquent
against the Parliament (though according to their own
rules he was not liable being under Age) yet where such
self intrestts as by Nesbitts solicitation, it was legall
& all the right in the world that his good service should be
gratified; And thus it was performed; immediately
there was his Estate all seized upon. he proclamed a
Traitor to the Parlament, with my mother, my 2 younger
brothers my self, all of us 3 being young. for I was but
15 years old. & the Eldest of the them. this was don in the
Church of kirklington by Mr Nesbitt in a triumphing
manner, & there upon my brothers Person should have
bin seized upon. but he was secure through a disguis.

Mr Siddall also upon this account, was sequestred.
because he would not relinquish his title to Nessbitt.
he having enjoyed that Living from my Mother & brothers
donation since the death of Mr Daggett.

Such Practices cannot subsist with Primitive Piety, or
the Purity of our true Religion. what ever pretext is
with our new Reformadoes.

In this confusion & streights, wherein my Fathers Family
was fairely desgined for Ruin, through the desperate malice
of our unjust adversary, who did worry the Lion for his
Skin. There happened a propossittion of Marriage, made
betweene my uncle will.m wandesforde, who was then en-
-devouring to get of my brothers sequestration, with my Cosen
Richard Darley, for to be had betwixt A nephew of my
Cosens & my self. which motion of Mr Darleys was at that
time relished by my Uncle Will.m & thought to be the only
expedient to secure my Fathers Estate & accepted by
him through whose scolicitation at first, (though he de-
-serted it affterwards). that after some time, it came to
such a progresse. As upon that account My Cosen Rich. Darly
was instrumentall, in putting my brother George upon the
traversing his deliquency, & in the End cleared his Estate
from the Ruin of Sequestration.

As to my own particular being willing to be advisable
by my friends in the choyce of a husband, deeming their
judgments above my own. was persuaded that this proposall
might tend to the good of the whole Family & was inclined
upon these grand motives & inducements, to accept of this
Motion, for Mr Thornton.

Contrary to my own inclination to marriage, as
also to that Judgement which was oppositt to my own
in his Relations, which Probably might bring me to
several inconveniances: Neverthelesse, for so general
a beniffitt to my family. & hopes of finding a Sober
religious Person I waved all other opportunities
of greater advantages in Estate &c which was propou
-nded by several Persons of qualittie & of my own
persuasion with my self, And presently there was
a Treaty of marriage entred into by Mr Thornton &
my dear mother, which was depending till a good time
after my brothers death.

But it so pleased God, for our greater affliction, when
wee hoped to have enjoyed the benefit of the clearing his
Estate from that Tiranny of Sequestration that we received a very
grand blow, by the sad infortunate loss of my dearest
Brother. which was the preludium to our many afflictions
& troubles in that poor Family. when we lost such a head
& Piller, in whose life consisted much the continuance,
that noble extraction, & galantry, not leaveing in it his second
behind him.
The occasion of his death & our misery was
this. upon the dispatch of that business at London by
My Cosen Darley, of the discharge, of his Estate from Seq.
My brother George deemed it his part to return thanks
due for such a favour, non more gratfull for a kindness
don then himself, having laid at Mr Harry Darcys
104
That night, came to Hipswell. to consult my mothers
advice about writing to London to Mr Rich Darley
about that business. After his obeisance & craving her
blessing. told her he was now going to Richmond, to my
Uncle will.m where he would write to Mr Darley, desiring to
know what she pleased to command him further in it:

My Mother said that her service & thanks must be returned
him for all his kindness in that bussiness which she would have
don herselfe by writting. but that she was sudainly surprised
at that instant of his coming up to the Chamber, with much
fears for me, who was, so violently tormented with a
pain in the right side of my necke amongst the sinneus &
which caused me to cry out in extremity, nor could she
imagine what was the cause, only she still anoynted it with
oyle of Roses. My brother seeing me in such pain
Asked how it came. of which I could give no other account
having bin as well before as ever, till I was combeing my
head toward the right hand, & bending my necke as he came
up the staires, & ever since it had held me greiveously.
this was the sircumstances of the strainge pain, which held me
strongly till about half an hour. which was the very time
of his drowning.

but to proceed to the circumstances of himself. he pittied me
much & would have stayed with me, but that his uncle will.m
stayed for him at Richmond for letters that Post. And after his
walking, 3 or 4 turnes about the chamber in his studieng
of his business, still my thoughts I saw a great deal of
change, he looked so seariously & soberly. as if there was
some great change near. but what I knew not. only feared
the worst that we should be deprived of him whom I so dealy
[word] SiC ??? i.e., dearly. loved

He in a very reverent manner kneeled down and
asked blessing at his going out again not long before
which my mother took notice of, praieng God Almighty to bless
him & said sonn I gave you my blessing but even now, how
cometh it that you take so solomne a leave of me.

he answered. for sooth I cannot have your prayers & bles
-sing for me too often. and so with her prayers for him in his
preservation, & his most humble obeisance in a dutifull
manner he took his leave; biding me fairewell dear
sister. I hope to find you better at my return home.
I likewise praied him to have a care of him self. &
lookeing after him I thought he had the sweetest aspect
& countenance, as I ever saw in him, & my ??? was
even full of fears that we should loss him. there was so
great and intire an affection for him on whom we did all
much depend. & speaking of this to him, he said I was
allwaies full of fears for him but he did not deserve it
And this was the last parting we had in this world with a
bundance of dear love & affection betwixt us as we ever
had in our lives together.

Going after this downestaires he called for his horse. &
although he had 2 men my mother kept for him yet took
he neither with him but bid his foot man James brodricke
an (Irish man & an excellent runner) to meete him at
Richmond. at 11 a clock where he was to mette my uncle will
so my brother went towards the River; And as he rid by
our Chapell where there was a wedding that day. he asked the
People, whether the Swaile might be riden. they said that
there had bin a flood. but it was fallen for some had crost
the water that morning. so he biding the People joy in their
marriage, went very slowly towards the river.

And as we heard after wards by 2 men which saw him on the
106
Other side he went down as cairfully & slowly as foot
could fall. Nor was the second flood come so high till he
was in the midest of the River, but when it comes from the
Dales it falles with a mighty mountaineous force sudainly
As I can my seelfe testifie, who (through the mercies of God)
was very nigh perishing in that water, once or twice, but was
delivered.

for as I was coming betwixt St. Nickolas, & our house at
Hipswell, if I had bin but 2 yerds of the shore, I had bin lost.
by its force. but by providence, I was not above half the
horse length
on from
ground, and yet the horse was taken to the
midle girths. albeit, it had bin all the time, I passed through
before the flood came down. but a little above the fettlocke.
Thus wonderously was I preserved from drowning. The
Lords holy name, be praised even for ever for my eminent
deliverance from perishing in & by these floods of waters

But to return, to the sad relation of my brother, which we was
informed of, by 2 men which walked beyond the River.
they perceaving A gentleman going down to the water,
imagining it some from Hipswell, seeing afarre of that the
flood came sudainly, & mightely down. made haste to
the Swale; & see only his horse getting out of the River. where
he had bin tumbled in, all over head, & by swiming had
got out & shaked himself. They got hold of his bridle
but missed the Person that rid on him. perceived it to be his
horse made a great search for my brother. but could not find the
body. With great sorrow, & lamentation, they ran to Easby
& Richmond raising all the Townes, flocking in exceedingly with
lamentable Mornings &, out cries, for him whom they dowted
was lost in that unhappy River.

The most lamentable newes came to Hipswell. where our very
107
Hearts were almost broken, with this greevous dismall
heavy blow, & loss of our dearest brother; & for the harty
greifes, & sorrows, I sustained it well nigh had brought
me to have, died with him. And if God had seen it fit, that
my poor unworthy life might have gon. so he might
have lived, for the good of his Family.

And but that the hand of our gracious God was seen migh
-tily in my mothers preservation. we had bin deprived
of her life also. this great blow aded to her former
afflictions, & to have brought her with sorrow to her grave
being deprived in such a heavy manner, of the hope of
her house. A man of so great accomplishments, & great
-nesse that I have heard many lament, & say that few came
near to him. for excelents abillities, Temperament of
Body, & humours, faculties of mind, ingenious, & of great
ingenuity. A most obedient, & faithful Son to his
Parents. which increased there comfort in him.

A dear, & affectionate brother. A faithful friend.
A loving, Land Lord: To his very Enemies, ever courteous
& affable. not disobleiging any by his morrocity or
perversenesse. his very Enemies then could not but
lament his loss said, he was the greatest loss that Yorkshire
had for a brave gentleman. & if thus much came from
the mouths of adversarys, no incomium his frinds can
set upon him can speak his worth & mirritt at whose hands
he had deserved, so much. & I am sure the Country
generally had a great loss of one so Pious, under-
-standing, & Loyall to his King. so that if it might have
gained him the world he would not have taken a false
oath, or Covenant, to wrong the Church or his soveraine.
his death was upon Munday morning in Easter week.
108
March the 31, 1651. was his blacke munday. the strange
pain which seized on my necke portended this Sadd loss.
Great, & infinite, was the search by thousands, of People
from that time till wednesday following, his body not being found
till on that day, & about the time when he was lost.

And then one of those men which was a witness against
him, was the first, which discovered his body, it being fallen
into a poole near Cattericke Bridge, a bove a mile from
the place he was drowned. John Plummer the mans name.

After they had drawne him up, care was taken of his
body, which was as sweet & comely, in all parts, as in his life,
except one bruise on the nose which was thought to be don
when he fell, upon some great stone, there being abund-
ance in that wathplace:
Allbeit he was an Excellent swimer
yet was it not the Lords pleasure, that it did him any help to
be saved thereby. The Corps was laid at Thomsons
on Cattericke brigg, that night because it was deemed the
bringing him to Hipswell, would, too much have agravated
my mothers excessive sorrow, & indangered her life also.
He was carried by coach, to Kirklington in the company
of all the Gentry in that part of Yorkeshire. with a greater
Lamentation, & sorrow, then was for any, with in the memory
of man at his funeralls.

He was buried in Kirklington Church, near Sir Christoper
Wandesforde Tombe, my Great Grandfather, Mr Siddall
preaching his funeral sermon, as I take it, and with as much
solemnity, as those times & such a sudden accident could
admitt. And this is the true relation of his death, of the fall
of this stately Ceadar of our wood, our staffe to my dear fathers
Family, whose death, cannot be spoken of with out tears.
I have taken on me, to inlarge more fully. As to the sircumstances
of the latter part of his life; & death, as also of my honred.
109
Fathers, with the inlargment of several sircumstances,
& passages, belonging to both. because this age of the
world, & sad times, is so apt to raise & report false
things of Persons of quality, & worth. bespattering these
dead Ashes according to the malice of Satan. whom-
they durst not presume to touch when living.

And although I am not worthy to undertake this
taske according to each mirritts. I could not in my
conscience be satisfied with out the commemoration of
some of those resplendant virtues in them, which I was
a daly witness of. being obleiged in point of gratitude
according to my capacity, to relate the truth of these sad
afflictions wheerein I had a deep shaire, & to leave
them for the right information to my Posterity of their
finishing this life, according to my knowledge.
he was buried upon the first day of April 1651.

Sir Christofer Viwill who had a great love for my Dear
brother, made an Excellent paper of verses upon him in
bewaling his loss which I will insert here after.

div.head:
A Lamentation, & Prayer, upon the death of
my hon.red brother George Wandesford Esquire.
div.p:
Alas O Lord, most great, & mighty, wonderful in
thy Powerfull Attributes, & Judgements. what shall
I say or, doe unto thy glorious majesty. who hast
looked down upon us, with a mighty breach. adding
great sorrows to our Public calamitys. Thou hast a
controvercy with this whole nation, & also with this poor
Family, by taking away our brother by an unnatarall
death, when he was in hopes to have lived in peace and
quiet. yea then hast thou oh Lord deprived us of our head
& suffered men to breake in upon our Estate, & disturbe
our
110
quiett injoyment, of this good land thou gavest to us.
And now at last smitten, the chief branch of our Family.
Ah-las Lord, our God, we have bin rebellious before thee, &
adding sin to iniquities, by our disputes, & disturbances
& now we have lost, a maine Piller, which preservd the peace
& quiett of us all. yea in a suddaine, & sad manner.

Oh what have we don, in displeasing, this great & dread-
full God, walked unworthy, of the mercies of so gracious
A father; whose dealings towards us, has bin in much
mercy & clemency. having preserved him & us all from
the violencys of our Enemies, & the Churches, in many great &
eminent deliverances. Yet hast thou now taken him
away, (who was the Joy of our hearts) in these sad times, to
our great discomfort. But what are we, O Lord; sinful
dust, & Ashes, in disputing thy pleasure, thy will be
don in us, & by, us, & on us in all things.

O Lord, teach us humility, & patience. & grace, to repent
of our iniquities, whatever it be which is displeasing. or hath
provoaked thy anger, & displeasure, in his death. let us
bewaile it, all our days; being humbled for our miscarriadg
-es & nonproficiencys in thy schoole of Afflictions.
The murders, warres, blood shed. That especially of the
horrible Murder of our gracious King. that wicked doers was
let in upon him, & us for our Crieing sins.

O Lord pardon; O Lord forgive; & doe for thy mercy sake
make us not a by word, & scorne, to our Neighbours. in these
signall punishments. return to us again, & let not
sin prevail, to our destruction, not thy corrections to deso-
-lation; but correct us in thy judgment, not in thy anger, lest
we should be consumed, & brought to nothing. Put an end
I humbly beseech thee, o Father of Mercies; to our confutions
111
And distractions, Public, & private. Sancitifie
this heavy chastisement, in our loss. to me, which had
a great shaire, in what troubles that followed to us all; &
pity thy humble repenting, returning Servant, who
is smitten, with thy Rod, & desires to receive instructi
-on. Lord comfort my dear mother, in these her
sadnesses, & sorrows, by the loss of so dutifull a Son.
& make us that remaine, to be stayes to her, in her Age.
And my fathers friends, to be comforts, & succours in
this world. unite our divissions in this Family, that none
may wrong, thy widow, & her Children, depending on thy
Providence. let us all rest on thy merciful favour
for provision, with out invading each others righs
[word] Sic ??? i.e., rights. un
-justly. Let it suffice o Lord that this blow is given,
& stay thy sword of vengeance, against this nation
in general. let this thy punishments have this effect, to
drive out our corruptions, & purge away our Sins. and
then heal our souls, & receive us to thy favour:
Forgive all our malicious persecutors, & turn their
hearts, that is the cause of our destruction.

As this affliction came by thy holy pleasure, & perm
-ission, so teach me, and us, all patiently to submit to
thy dispensation. Blessing thy name, that he fell not by
the hands of the Philistines, whose cruelltys was great.
But before his change (though it was sudden), didst show
him thy mercies, in considering his wayes, & reconsiling him
-selfe to his God, & giving him the opportunity of thy ho.
holy Sacrament a pledge of our Salvation; with great desi
-res to serve thee faithfully, in his generation; with many
many other testimonies of thy love, as that of his Estate.
And great abilities & understanding in religion. several
good gifts & graces; fitting him to walk uprightly in thy
sight. And it may be this providence was better, for
112
him then. to live; to see, & pass through those Evils to
come, when there was no king in Israell, every one did what
was right in his own Eyes. but he was brought to his grave
in Peace; And now o Lord most high. & yet most merci-
-full Father. Let me not Sin against thee by adding reping
murmuring thoughts. for it is the Lord, let him doe what
seemeth him best. I lay my mouth in the dust & say. I am
not worthy to speak unto thee, nor have my own life given
unto me; in abundance of health & strength; therefore doe
yeald thy majesty, most humble thanks & praise. that I
am still preserved, in all these times of Ruin. & from peri-
-shing in the very same River, at two several times. And
for my mothers deliverances; & all of us from the hand of
our Enemies, & the Churches. O Make not a full end with us
which hath bin ingratefull, for these mercies; nor be not angery
with us forever. but Bless my fathers family, & give him
a light in this Israell, to praise thy name in his Posterity
in the ways of Righteous & hollinesse for ever. And make
our souls to be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus.

I beseech thee, O Lord, humble, us for this affliction. & break
-ing the head of our number. that the rest may lay it to heart. &
became wiser thereby. Give us not over to fall into the hands
of unmercifull & cruell men; that fights against thy Church &
Annointed. but deliver us, & thy whole Church, in this King
dome from the Rapin, of sacrilegious Persons; as would destroy
the Seamless cote of Christ. tearing it in Peices by factions
Devissions, & heritticall oppinnions. from proud, & covetous
prettenders, to reformesmation; laid in the foundation of blood
& Murder. Let not their prosperity Allure: their oppression
inforce, or draw any of us to joyne in their designs. no
not so much, as by consent, or compliance, in their wickednes.

Least wee eate of such things as please them; And
sin against so great, & Glorious a God, in Robing him
of that hon.or ; his only due (& to non other creatures) of those
services, ordenances, Sacraments, tithes & offrings all
thy own peculier right. or detaining our Kings, due
obedience, to his Power derived from thee; and thy
Church, which thou has graciously Established here by
all which we Rob thee of thy Praises & Glory thou should
have asscribed, for thy goodness in these things, by
us, & may thereby heape to our selves swift destruction
by invading thy right. the Kings, & Churches.

But on the contrary as we have hitherto, bin preserved
from such iniquities, by thy mercy. so through thy
continued Grace, we may be delivered from either doing
such; & if it be thy will from suffering by & from such practi
-cies, as much as thou shalt see fit in thy gracious prov
-idences. That so we may still, live in this good Land,
injoying once again thy peace, in the Restoration
of our Right Lawfull Soveraine. with the restoration of thy
Church, & holy good Bishops to feed & governe, & direct
this flocke, aright in the ways of thy truth; & salvation
of our Souls. That Errours, Schismes, & Rebellion, may be
extingushed, & exterp-ated. thy good Laws Divine
& humaine, Reestablished. And we of these Kingdoms
Fixed upon those Axes again, of truth, & Peace.
Righteous nesse & obedience. That we serving thee in these
Nations, in true filliall fear. may again enjoy thy
Presence with us. being a People saved by the Lords mira-
-culous favour & mercy. Giving thee the honor
& praise
of all thy dealings with us.

Make us all
a reformed Nation, from all their Evil ways
putting away far from us
the Evil of their doeings. that
we might not be abhorred of thee. but to be a Righteous
People, Zealous of Good workes. That thy name may be
Glorified in our Conversion, the hon.or of the Lord, Jesus Christ.
Advanced, & we saved from destruction; & many nations
come in to thy faith, when they Behold, what the goodness of
God is, to us most vilde People. and give thanks with us
to thy Majesty, forever. And now O Lord, most just. there
is no reason, that thou shouldest hear the prayers of sinners;
but in his name, only, I most humbly on the bended knees
of my soul, beg these humble requests. & put up petition
for his sake that suffred for sin, & sinned not. O Lord hear
& doe, for thy mercy sake, for we are in deep distress. our
souls drawe nigh to the Grave. & if thou doest marke
what is amisse, who can stand in thy presence. but with
thee there is mercy, for all the ends of the Earth, & thou hast
commanded us to call upon thee in the time of trouble,

And further, O Lord, my God, leave me not, to my self.
but comfort thy servant. blessing, directing, & guiding
me, in all my life. in all my ways. I trust in thee. And be
a Tower of defence to my dear Mother, & her Children
Defending us in this troubleous times from all evils &
Dangers for the Lords sake. All these requests. & whatever
ellse thou shallt see fit for us, or my self (with pardon for
the Errours of these imperfect prayers, & acceptance of the
same, & pardon for all my sins & provocations). I beg Even for the
Righteous Jesus our Lord and Saviours Sake in whose name we
have admittance, to the throne of thy grace; he ever making
intercession. for us & therefore I have presumed to powr out this
Sad complaint before thy dreadful majesty. who sees all
115
Our wants & infirmities therefore in his name & word
I humbly conclude these prayers as he has taught me
in his holy Gospel to call upon thee Saying:

Our father which art in Heaven.
Amen. So be it:

div.head:
An Eligie upon George Wandesford Esquire
on his unfortunate Death. by the Hon.ble Sir Christopher Wyvill Barronett.

On the deplorable loss of our hon.red friend &
Neighbour George Wandesford Esquire March 31 51.
div.l: Ere-since the Bishops, Parliament, and King,
(A blest Conspiracie) agreed to bring.
The faith of Christians, & Baptismall Seal.
Free-Denisons into this Common-Weal.
To the late, famous, Streame of Swale adhers,
Through the long Current of a Thousand Years.
A Sacred-Reputation; there, Whole-Bands
Of forward-Converts, by the Reverend-hands
Of Old-Paulinnus did at once Begin
To shake-hands with there God, & of their Sin:
Those Waves did, then, a font, the Banks afford.
An acceptable-Temple to the Lord:
Oh What meant the Rash flood by one act, to Throw
A Ruin on its own fame, and us too,
So brave a vessell, & so Richly fraught.
That guilltty Channell has to Ship wrack Brought
As bank rupts all our Contrie; Noe-Man here,
So unconserned but must let fall a Tear;
Whilst the sadd-murmur of those Waters Call:
On every-Passinger to mourn his fall:
His family; no greifes can tell its fatall Loss;
Dum, in admiration, at this dreadful Cross.
