contingency; nor did I intend to Alter the same with out
great cause. which I hoped in God would not be; because there
was so great a somme left for his debts, & was made be-
lieve it could not be cutt of the Intaile with out my consent
but it proved affterward the contrary, to my great grief
& almost my utter Ruin; & my Children's.

There was left only Newton which was my Jointure settled
so on my heir. that it could not be cut off with out my consent
in passing a fine: nor was the Rents ever more clear then
seaven score paid a year. of it.

And now I hartely thanke my gracious God who gave me
opportunity to get this don; for the satisfaction of my
conscience & the relief of my Children; blessed be his name
that did not take me out of this Life before: least by some
means they might have bin disapointed. and I leave
both my husband & Children, all in the wise & gracious
disposittion of the Great God, humbly craveing his blessing
upon them all for Christs sake Amen.

div.head:
Upon my deliverance, of my son Robert Thornton
my 7th Child: borne at Easte Newton: the first child
that was borne in the new house: Sept. 19th 1662
div.p:
Almighty God; The wise disposer of all good things
both in Heaven & Earth. Who seest what & how much
of the comforts of this mortall Life is conveniently fit for
us to enjoy in this Earth; hath at length had pittie
on my afflictions & gave me such a mercy & dear
in-
joyment to my self & husband; after all his & mine
several troubles & losses of Sonnes: As I could not hope
for or Expect:

Making me a Joyfull Mother of a sweet Son. borne at
full time; after 5 great trials, & hazards of miscarige
-s when I was with him; the one of sickness;
a 2d through grief
at a strange accident that hapned me of a fright: which caused
a marke of blood upon his heart. of most pure couler: &
several shapes. contineuing till he was about a year
old: And seen by many persons at several times;

The 3d the Trouble of Nettletons Balifs: & the fourth that
before the Settlement was made of his Estate, on my Children
The fifth was a great danger I escaped of him; by a fall, I
got down the staires to preserve Celia Danby from hurt
when she Tumbled down the whole staires before me:
The least of which mercies & deliverances were subject of a
hearty praise & thanksgiving to the Lord of Lords.

But it still pleased the most high God to adde this blessing
when I was delivered: after a great danger. & Pirill of my
life in travail of my Son Robert Thornton; upon Friday
the 19th of september 1662 he was borne at Easte Newton: betwixt
the houres of 8 & 9. a clock at night having bin since the
night before in strong labour of him till that time:

But as though this grand mercy should not pass alone.
with out its severer Monitor; to my unbridled Passion of Joy
And that I might be causioned not to set my affection too much
on things below; be they never so necessary, or desirable,
It pleased the great God, to lay on me his weak handmaid
an exceeding great weakness. beginning a little after my
Child was borne. by a most violent; & tirrible flux of
Blood.

With such excessive Floods all that night; that it was Tirible
To behold to those about me. bringing me into a most desperat
condition; with out hopes of life. Spirits, Soul & strength
seemed all gon from me:

My dear husband & Children & friends had taken their last
faire-well: In this deplorable Condition layd I in for several
hours together; not being able to utter one word. all the means
could be was don in that fright, but did not prevail. After 5 hours
It pleased my gracious Lord to have compassion on his langu- Torment
-ishing creature. & brought to my remembrance a pouder which
I used formerly to others, & with his blessing had good successe in the
like kinde. and hardly could I get the name of it to my Lady
yorke for my feblenesse: but after she had given me some of it

Through the mercy of my Saviour. Who healeth. & helped all that
came unto him. by it helped me. so that the flux stayed by degres
Till Dr wittie was come. when after the use of other means I
was delivered, & spared at that time. from that Death so nigh:
but brought so exceeding weak. that the Effects lasted till Candlemas
upon my body by fits; yet did I recover my milk again

But oh, O Lord, most high & loving father, wherefore are
thy Miraculous favours & mercies extended thus, to such a vild
worme as my self, who am not able to recount the unmesurable
goodness not tell what thou didst for my soul. Doubtlesse
to set forth thine almighty Power, Glory. & Infinite Perfection
That canst raise from death, & bring to the grave in a moment.

div.head: A Thanksgiving after my deliverance of my son Robert
div.p:
Oh Just, great & Almighty Lord God. I humbly prostrat
my Soul & body. lie trembling at the remembrance of my sins
& unworthynesse, which hath caused thee to afflict me so
sorely in thy anger: beggeing pardon for all mine offences
& grace to live to thy glory: I also fall low at the footstoole
of thy grace & mercy, giving thy divine majesty All
Possible thanks. Dominion. Glory. Power & praise. & what
ever can be asscribed by the Tongue & ??? of men & Angels, or
given to thy most Glorious goodness: thou King of Kings
& Lord of Lords. The only giver, & preserver of my.
206
Soul & Body. who hast preserved. the one from all
Spiritual. the other, from temporal & Eternal Death.
Let not Glorious Trinity, this death, joyned with the others
I have lately beine preserved from be forgotten. But sealed
on my ??? with Indeluable
[word] I.e., indelible. Carracters on my Soul & Spirit.
How can I suficiently set forth thy noble Praise. which
cannot express the mercies, nor goodness I have Received.
O Lord let thy Holy Spirit inspire my heart, & inliven
my dull Soul to utter forth thy Hon.or our holiness, goodnes
loving kindness of the Lord to me his poor unworthy ser
-vant & to the Sons of men. and that forever.

Doe not forget O my Sad Soul what the Lord hath don for
thee times with out number. Delivering me at my first con-
ception, both from the Lions, & graves mouth, when the Pitt
was open for me, ready to swallow me up
when Satan missed his purpose, then was I again Prese
-ved from, another of his stratagemes, to have devoured
me & my Infant: from unjust Anger that was stirred up
against us, which he intended for our destruction.
Then from our unjust adversaries to destroy our Estates
And now in giving my self & Infant preservation
from this temporal deaths in my wonderful deliverance
of Child birth: And Lastly this dreadful flux & in-
firmity. whereof very few doth escape with there Lives
O Lord I beseech thee except of my hearty Pourings out
in Prayer & praise. & let me live to magnify thy Name
for all these transsendant mercies, day & night. & Let
this be arguments of thy love & favour to me & my dear
Son whom thou hast given me, for Jesus Christ, the righteous
his sake; For the Lord God had great Pittie upon my distress
& gave me after this a compotency of health & strength
to be able to give my Child Sucke. which by his blessing
I did till Robin was above 2 years old he contineuing very
healthfull & strong: So that my Sorrows much abated.

Thus may I sing a new song unto the Lord. a song of thank
sgiveing & praises to God on high. with hanna in 1 Sam. 3
207
Who had Compassion upon the vildest of his Creatures. yet
hath he heard my sorrows & granted my requests. which I
made before him; with my mouth will I ever set forth his
Maraculous Praise; & tell of his marvelous greatnesse.
from day to day; for who can doe as thou doest; there is
No God in Heaven & Earth but thee alone Most great &
holy. Let this stand as a Piller of Gratitude, which I errect
for all the deliverances & mercies. I & my Children have had
both in Soul & body. The Living shall praise thee in Heaven
& Earth for ever: Amen.

My Son Robert was baptized on Satterday the 20th of
September: 1662 by Mr Luckock at our House in Easte
Newton in my own Chamber, where the Lord gave me opportunity
to see his admittance into the Church Millittan. by holy Sacrament
of Baptisme; when I hope the Lord did enter into Covenant
with him to be his God: & he to be his faithful servant to his
lives end: The Lord give him also the Grace of this means
as well as the means by which he gives his Grace unto us. Amen
his Godfathers & Godmothers were Mr Thornton; for my
my nephew Best. Dr wittie. My Lady Cholmely.

The God of all consolations & Comfort. Preserve his Life &
health: with happy opportunities of Religeous & holy. Educa-
tion. that he may be an instrument of great Glory to God,
Comfort to his Parents & relations. And for the building up in
Righteousness & hollinesse. his Fathers Family to Posterity
for many generations. And at the end of his life, he may
receive the comfort of a sanctified Old Age. with a Crown of
Glory to praise his Reddemer & mine for ever for our beings;
Finding what the goodness of God had beine to me in giving me
the requests of my heart; & being these mercies received by
& from a gracious father. who hath at length bestowed on
me his servant this hopes of contineuing our memories. by a
sweet son of my vowes. being obteined from God as Samuell
was by the fervent prayers & tears of a poor wreatched mothr

To thee o Lord I humbly dedicate my son of my womb.
O Let him be Established before thee for ever in thine everlasting
Covenant: Amen. look meditations on 1. Sam. 1t 10, 11, 12 13v.
in my book on Purpose. made on that occasion.

div.head: Mr Thorntons Preservation from drowning: Oct. 1664
div.p:
After Robin was 2 years old. Mr Thornton went to
London about wittness for Sir Christopher wandesfords
suite with Mr Robinson concerning the bounders. in this
jorney when he was returning home he escaped drow
ning at the waters near newarke. when the floods was
so high that they had nigh have carried him down with
the streame. but the Lord was pleased to deliver him from
that death. his holy name be glorified & praised for
ever. who brought us safely to meete again with Joy
to enjoy each other still in peace & temporal comforts
joyned with spiritual mercies. Oh that we might make
a right use of these temporalls. that we finally lose not the
hopes of Eternal mercies. through Jesus Christ our Lord
Amen.

div.head:
Upon the birth of my 8th Child Joyce Thornton Sept.
23rd 1665 at Newton:
div.p:
It pleased God to give me a new hopes of Comfort.
of beareing Mr Thornton another child. Although
these are accompanied with thorny Caires & troubles: &
more to me then others (but yet I was continued in
much health & strength after I had given suck to Robin)
allalong, Tille I was with child, & till about a fortnight
before my delivery. when my Travell began upon me
And then the Panges of Child beareing, often remembring
me of that sad Estate I was to pass. & dangerous Pirills my
Soul was to find even by the gates of Death; So that I being
terrified with my last extremity could have little hopes
to be preserved; in this, as to my own strength; if my
strength were not in the Almighty.

However I tribled my diligence & care in preparation
having with comfort reciaved the blessed Sacrament as
a pledge of my Redemption; which we had the opportunity
of doing in our family, with Mr Thornton & his servants
Receaving it from Mr Comber: Minister of the Parish at
Stongrave.

After this great mercy; in the reneuing of our vowes &
Covenants with God: I was fully satisfied in that condition
whether for Life; or Death: having committed my Soul in
keepeing to a faithful meadiator: & Redeemer: hopeing
for me to live, is Christ. & to die was gaine: when I should
exchange, sorrow, for Joy: & death for Life. & immortallity
I was the most concerned for my poor Children. who might
peradventure want some helpes from their weak mother
& having no Relation; or friend of my own; that might take
care of them if their father should see cause to marry a-
gaine, according as I had bin told: that it would be Nesseary
for him for his health: I was indeed the more scolicitous for
my 3 young Chidren; casting in my mind what friend of
my own to desire to in trust with their Education if he did so
For my Son: The hope of my house: I humbly committed him
into the Propection of Almighty God. as also his two sisters
And for his Education, into the care of my dear & honred Uncle
My Lord frechvile: my Daughter Alice to: my dear Aunt
Norton: and my Daughter Katherine: to my deare neece
Best: with strict charge to bring them up in the nurture & fear
of the Lord: & the true Proffession of the Prottestant Religion:
as it was my faithful endevours so to doe while I was with
them: That I might give a good account of their souls unto
my Saviour: They had also a very good beginning of know-
ledge through the due examination: & catechising of Mr
comber, each Sabbath day: as well in the Church, as at home.

Next in order was It my duty to take care for the right
Settlement: & devission of the goods & Personall Estate of my
Dear Mother according to her will & Testament which she left
me power to doe by Deed amongst my Children.

Having left their Maintenance & Portions settled as by the
Deede made formerly. in as good a condition as could be for
the many incumbrances & Debts upon Mr Thorntons Estate
So that it only remained for me to depositt the safe custody of
All the Deeds: Intails: & writings About our whole Estate
for our Children into a Safe hand: which in case of my Mortality
should be delivered to my Lord frechvile after my death.

This was seriously considered. & agrreed upon by and
with the approbation, & command of my dear husband
That they should be delivered in keeping to Mr Comber
who, as a friend to all, should preserve them: & give them
to my Lord frechville.

Haueing Intrusted all the Chief Consernes & Evidences
for my dear Children with in a little Red Lether Truncke
Locked. I delivered the same to him according to our agrement
Laing a great charge & injunction: with my earnest desire
that he would keep that Truncke safe. and if it pleased
God to take me; then to deliver the same with his own hand
to my Lord: as I had charged the same to George Light
foote & his wife Dafeny with it: in my sickness of my son
I bore at St Nickolas; after my mothers death:
for in it was contained all Children's Provision & sub-
sistance: & if any thing should happen to that Trunke they
might be Ruined:

It pleased my gracious Lord God to give me space: & time
to doe all these things as well as I could; after which I fell
into travell being one day & night in Travail. of
My Eight Child, & then it pleased the Lord to make me
happy in a goodly strong Child a daughter after an
exceeding sharpe & perillous time. being in the same con-
dittion of weakness after I came into bed & of my son
Robert, which I escaped very narrowly the blow of Death

But by the providence of God I was prepared with a remidy
which prevented the extremity, & with in 14 days I began
to be in a hopefull condition of recovery. Blessed be the
great & gracious Father of mercies. he also giving me
strength & the blessing of the breasts to give sucke, with much
comfort in my Infant, with my dear husband & Children
who then had increased my number to 4 sweet Children
O Lord I beseech thee accept the humble addresses of my
Soul, body & spirit. for these infinite mercies. give me a
thankful ??? to rejoice in thy Salvation. & in that thou
211
Alone didst raise me up from this death. & my dear
Child. not suffering our sins to prevail; but had pity on
thy servant my husband & my self giving us this add-
-ition to our number. on Earth: The Lord make her to be a
vessell of Glory to all Eternity. And I humbly addore thy
thy gracious Clemency & mercy. magnify thy name Amen

Joyce Thornton my 8th Child, was borne at Newton.
upon Satterday about 4 a clock in the after noone. on
the 23rd of September: 1665 Baptized on the 28th day at
Newton. I having the satisfaction of seeing her entred in
to the Role of Christians. & a member of the Millitant Church
of Christ.

Her Godfathers. my Lord Frechvile by Proxie. my Cosen
Legard. Maddam Grahme. & my Cozen Cholmley.
It pleased the Almighty in much mercy, to give me great
comfort in the nursing of this sweet Child. inabling me with
pretty strength to go through this duty. therefore doe I
praise the god of Heaven for ever. who had preserved my
Life. and given me this great temporal blessing. For all good
comes from him alone. Lord sanctify this mercy to us all.

div.head:
A Relation of Mr Thorntons dangerous fit of the Palsie
at Steersby no. 16th 1665.
div.p:
But peradventure I might be too much lifted up by this
mercy. & therefore it seemed good to the divine providence to lay
a very sad affliction upon Mr Thornton & my self. in a most
dangerous sickness seized upon him, as he was returning
from Yorke, in his way home. commeing so near as the moore
nigh steeresby: No. 16th 1665.

At which time he through could & the distemper of the Palsie, was
violently prevaileing more upon him in his Jorney as he rid
so that he scarse could be got to My Sister Cholmeleys house.
for 3 days that greivous distemper of the Palsey. Convoltions
& feavour was so high upon him. that not withstanding all
Possibles remidies could be used by Dr wittie, he was not able
to assist himself, nor capable to receive others help at some
times. & showed to all his friends there present that he was more
like to die. then hopes of recovery.

Which sudden & most dismall newes of My dear husbands.
212
Lamentable condition. being made known to me when
I expected him each hour to have received him home with
health & comfort. Did so surprize my spirits. that I was
brought into a violent passion of grief & sorrow: with fits
of sounding,
which I never knew before.

And prevailed so exceedingly, that I immediately went sick
to Bed. being so weak. upon that occasion. that all gave me for
dead. so that it was an impossibility to carry me alive to
see my dear husband. although I could not be pacified
with out it. till, I fell so weak my self I could not speak

Thus was I deprived of seeing, or doing, my faithful duty
to my beloved husband. through the Lords hand upon my
self in such extremity. nor had they hopes of the spai-
ring either of our Lives in all appearance. Only our hopes
was in the miraculous fountaine, of inexhaustable mercies
of the Almighty Lord God. who turneth man to distruc-
tion, & saith turn again from the Grave yee Children of
Men. Nor had I any comfort, or friend. that could
assist me in my Sorrows at that time, nor who to leave my
fower young Children too: in that excigent of both our
sad calamities. but only to the gracious father of Mercies
And beggeing my husbands Relations to have pittie on
my dear Children; then like to be left young Orphans
to the world of troubles.

yet blessed be the Lord who did not give us over to Death
but when we were nigh it behold the goodness of God, was
intreated for us to restore both our lives. And let me ever
return him the Glory of his power, & mercy in the return of
our Prayers. be asscribed to his Majesty. who immediatly
gave us hopes of Recovery. upon calling upon his name.
For that very night about that hour, when we were at prair
for him, my dear husband. wakened as out of sleep
when Dr expected his departure. And at 3 a clock at N.
called for a toste & butter. not having eaten ought of 4
days: & changed so fast in a way of recovery. that it was
admirable to all.

div.head: A Prayer after Mr Thorntons Recovery: No. 28th 1665.
div.p:
O what shall I say, or doe to set forth the infinite mercies
& transcendant loving kindness of the Lord our God, who
still in the midest of Judgement remembers mercies, & shewes
his compassion upon us poor Creatures. O Lord God. thou
King of Glory & Power. just are thy corrections & Judge-
ments, whether Spirittuall or Temporal. Thou hast chasti
-ised us very sore. & all thy stormes are gon over our heads
but surely we have offended & don amisse; either in negli-
-gence or remissenesse, or forgettfullnesse of our duties, to thee
or our nighbour. forgetting our deliverances & mercies bestowed
or to give thee the hon.or of all thy workes & goodness to us
ever since we have bin in the married Estate. I beseech thee
hear my cries & accept my groanes & Tears. Pardon our
sins & accept us to mercy & favour again. That we may
Joyntly & severaly serve thee unfeinedly. Sanctify I besech
thy majesty this most sad afflictions upon us both. & give
us grace that to make a good use of this thy hand of sickness
that it may be for our good, & profitt of our souls. that we may
say it is good for us, that we have bin afflicted. grant that we
may receive instruction. & thy loving corrections may
make us humble & thankefull. And here from the bottome
of my unfained heart, I lift up my voyce to addore, praise
& Magnify, thy great & Glorious name. Thou O Lord art holy
Just, wise, omnipotent. Almighty. and Infinitly full of
Compassions towards us thy fraile Servants. we sin. & thou
chastiseth us into obedience, if thy mercy will not move.
thy Rod must correct. O Let us not Lose the benefit of this
corection. but doe us the best good, of through reformation. &
let us not forget, or slight these grand deliverances of my
husband & my self. and as thou hast given us new lives.
give us also new ???s to serve thee. O Lord accept this sacrifice
of Praise & thanks even to thee o holy Trinity be all Posible
Glory. & hon.or Power & might asscribed for our preservations
for ever & for ever. Amen. Amen.

div.head: Upon my dear Joyce her death Jan. 27 1665.
div.p:
It was the pleasure of our God to vissitt my dear Child
Joyce Thornton with a great sickness falling exceding ill on
sunday the 20th of Jan. 1665 beginning as we thought with a
Cold which strucke in many Red spotts all over her body & face
after which she mourned
& cried exceedingly being tormented
with her sickness, we used all means that could be don to so
young a child by the advice of Dr wittie. yet no thing did
prevail it being the pleasure of God to take her out of this
miserable world.

She continued with some intermittions of slumbers, & in
much strength did resist the sickness. till the thursday af
ter. when it was past hopes of recovery. and about one
& 2 a clock in the affternoone on Friday the 27th Jan. 65.
The Lord was pleased to free her from all pains, by taking
her to his mercy. when she sweetely fell a sleep, with out
any pain or extremity to the Appearance of all.

She was buried at Stonegrave by Mr Comber the next day
who preached a funeral sermon.

I dare not, I will not repine at this chastisment of the Lord
though it may seeme never so troublesome to part with my
suckeing child of my womb. but say good is the will of the
Lord in as much as he hath spared my dear husbands life
which I so earnestly begged of him. spairing my own, also
who is the vildest of his Creatures. & has given me still the
lives of my husband & my 3 Children, for which I will praise
the Lord our God & beg of him patience to sustaine the loss
of my sweet Infant.

And instead thereof hath showred down upon me infinit
measurs of sprittuall mercies & incomes of his grace so many
that my ??? & tongue cannot express them with out that which I had
bin miserable. therefore to the glory of his Name I ascribe the
hon.rod of my Creation out of nothing, making me Capable of
salvation beyond the Essence of Angels. those glorious spirits
The inestimable mercy of giving Redemption to the world.
215
by thy Blessed son. my Saviour. And thou O holy Spirit
the God of all consolations, & comforts against the firey
Darts of satan the grand Enimy of Man. Great Lord as thou
hast taught me by afflictions not to set my affections on
things below, so much me so wise to seeke a habitation in
Heaven & not of this Earth or any thing in it. Oh give me
so sanctified an use of this affliction that I may spend non
of the small inch of time unprofitably which thou givest me
in this miserable Life, wherein I take no free delight & Joy.
but by all means make it my business to glorify thy name
& the gaining thy favour. with faith to believe in thy mercies
And that thou hast a love for my soul, even in these sad dispen-
-sations. And thou Lord the life of my life, prepare me for
this change & dissolution, that I may receive the Kingdom of
Heaven as a little Child. of thy alone miritts & free grace.
That then I may see that God face to face, which I doe now believe
& put my trust & confidence in being for ever freed from the
fears of sin & sorrow. And this for his sake that suffered for sin
& sinned not the holy one of God. O let me not in the intrime
be unmindfull of his hand by these corrections. but we may
be delivered from the Jawes of Eternal death. Amen.

div.head: Upon my Daughter Alice preservation in a sirfitt June 13 1665.
div.p:
It pleased God to deliver my Daughter Alice from a sirfitt
which brought her into a violent & dangerous illnesse, which came
upon her in her sleep as she laid in bed with me, when I wakend
sudainly in a fright with the noyse she made being almost
choaked, & her breath stopt with undigested Turbutt eaten
the night before, but with the help I made her, & taking several
cordialls. she vomitted what did offend her stomack.

Blessed be the most gracious God of mercies for ever, that raised
this child of mine up from death very often even from a
yong infant. therefore I humbly dedicate her to the Lord to walk
before him in Righteousness for ever. In her sound. she after
ward told me she was even over Joyed & ravished with the
glorious sights she then saw, as if heaven opened to receive her
& she was angery to be disturbed from that hapinesse.

div.head: Of my dangerous sickness: August 8 16th 1666.
div.p:
After the drinking of Scarbrough waters, Mr Thornton
sent for me to Yorke about business with my Lord Frechvile
in which jorney I thought I received some harm being lately
conceived before as Dr wittie apprehended. so this, together
with a grief that befell me at my return home, about a Settle
ment last made by Colvill for my Children's maintenance
& Portions; which had bin undon with out my consent
& knowledge when Mr Thornton was sick at Steersby,
for the Chargeing of Mr Raines & Mr Portington Debt of
1400l by mortgage upon Laistrop. in so doing there was
not one penny could be secured for my two Poor Daughters
either maintenance or Portion, till after the payment of
that Debt. & there was but 100l per annum for all: And also
that my brother Christopher Rent Charge out of Ireland was secu-
-red to them also: for 7 years 200l a year.

which condition I could not, but lament; nor had I got a sight
of this new disposittion of that Estate. which I doe believe Mr
Thornton was partly necessitated to doe, in regard, that they
would not be satisfied with the security alone out of Ireland

After this hapened. I fell into a very sad & desperate con
dittion upon satterday the 16th of August: 1666 being then
about 8 weeks gon. the violency thereof continued a long
time after Dr wittie was with me. And for 3 days he did not
expect my life. so that he was compelled to use all his Art for
my preservation. But it pleased God upon the use of his
meadicens, that extremity a little abated, he leaveing me
in a hopefull way of Recovery, only said I must not
expect to be restored till about the latter end of octber

All which time I was in continuall faintings upon the reneuall
of that extremity. So that my loss of Spirits & strength &c
was so great that it was expected I should have fallen
into a deep consumption. And I continued exceeding
feeble & weak till the Candlemas following The chief remidie
which I found for restoreing strength. was a meadicine made
of Muskedine, which I was directed to by my noble &.
217
Worthy friend madam Grahme, upon which I grew to gather
strength by degrees, to pass through that tirrible vissitation
& languishing condition all that winter.

I humbly Acknowledge my boundant duty & gratitude
for deliverance, & preservation from this death also; to
the Almighty Power & infinite mercy of the Lord my God
who looked upon the disstresse of his weak handmaid. &
brought me through the Jawes of death. Adoreing & mag
-niefieing his dreadful majesty; who did not cast away
my sorrowfull soul in its callamitys. whereof I have tasted
a large shaire of in this life, I besech thy goodness to make
known thy self to me in these great & heavy afflictions
that so my ??? being fixed upon thy divine beautys. I may
not desire any thing in this life, comparitively to the Love of
my dear Saviour. who hadst pittie on me when the helpes
of this world did faile: then thou o Lord didst putt thy
words into my ??? & directed me, that I should come unto
thee by faith as the woman in the Gospel did whom thou curd
Matt. 9: 21 v. Accordingly I came unto thy throne of Grace
desireing to lay hold on thee by faith, who in thy Providenc
caused that Scripture to be read that day in my eares, as a part
of that dais Lessons; when I was in my greatest distress in a
bed of weakness: At that time was thy holy word like oyle
in my bones to cure my infirmitie: And gave me hope to
believe that thy compassion is towards the Children of men to
pull them out of the Jawes of Satan & death: Lord thou did
see me in my sorrows, & spake comfortably to my soul. v. 22
Daughter be of good Cheare; thy faith hath made thee whole

And from that very day I did recover: O Lord my gGod. how
can I sufficiently set forth the glory of thy name & praise
who hast compassion upon my condition, & gavest me this
spiritual balsome to heal my soul & body. besides thee
there is none ellse that can doe as thou dost; I beseech thee give
me a thankefull & holy ??? to entertaine thee & all thy dispen
-sations towards me. & that this miracoulous mercy with all I have
received from thy goodness may tie & unite my soul fast
to thee, that neither Life nor Death. sicknese nor adversity.
218
can be able to disunite me from the love of thee o my dear
Redeemer who hast don such great things for my Soul
let me live the Life of faith a few days here that I may magn
ifie thy name for ever. O holy bellesed
[word] Sic. & Glorious Trinity
To whom all Power might, majesty, thanksgiving &
praise be offred by all creatures in Heaven & Earth.
Amen. Amen:

In my book of medittations, there is a discourse upon this deliverance
upon those words in St Matt. 9: v. 21, 22. Luke. the 17: v. 15. 16.

After these weaknesses seized so extreamly upon my Person
with such violency & danger to my life, I could not be insensable
of my daily decay & dieing condition: which these frequent
incussions of my health might too sudainely bring to it's
period. Death in it self being desirable to those whose affec
-tions had cause to be weaned from the comforts & vanities
of this Life. wishing to be freed from this worlds troubles. &
to be received into the Arms of Everlasting rest.

yet as a Christian wife, & Mother, was there a duty incu-
-mbent upon me to discharge; with faithfullnesse & Godlines
towards. my dear husband & Children; according to each Capacity
so that I was obleiged to be a comfort to the one. & a support
to the other while I was continued in this world.

Which duties, I made it my studie to observe, & though I
could not be in such a state of perfection; doing all I was
commanded from God. yet through his mercy strengthening
me. I may affirme that I made it my endeavour to performe
to my uttmost capacity with a good conscience towards all.

And for as much, as the future wellbeing of my Children did
then represent it self to my thoughts; & it had pleased God
in mercy to spare me till that time. living to see my self
blessed with 3 hopefull Children. For whose souls I was the most
concerned in thire Education in the true faith of Jesus Christ.

I was the more induced upon this account to accept of a
proposittion formerly made; & begun in the year 1665. By
Mr Comber to my dear husband. that he would except of
him self for my daughter Alice Thornton in marriage.
219
Who though her years were but young being 14th then
yet such was his great affection towards her; that he was
desirous to attend for her 7 years. if he might by his leave
obteine her at last: having, discerted all other opportunitys
for her sake & the favours he had from him. And also that what
ever her fortune was. It should be wholey for her to use & hers.
with all he did not dispaire, but that God who had Preservd
him, hitherto would provide a hansome compotency; & to mak
a better provision for My daughter. by adding to her own.
This propossittion was answered by a fair respect of Mr Th.
side & he was incouraged to proseed.

Nor could I be satisfied in a business of this nature. on which
might depend the wellbeeing of our Family. with out A serious &
deep consideration of all our Affairs, & the condition that our Estate
was in; which being well known to my Good Brother denton,
more then to any in the world. I consulted, and advised, with
him allalang in this transaction.

Whose prudence & discression, was a great support to Mr Th.
& my self in all our business & Actions. he also having had
knowledge & acquaintance of this Gentleman for several yers
might the better judge of his life & conversation, together with his
qualifications for the great & high calling of the Ministery.

Which in it self considered carries allong with it. the most noble
Title that man is capable of in this world, & wherein the highest,
Acts of Piety & Religion is vested. being hon.ord by God
himself in the old & new Testament. Above all other Dignitys
& having the greatest opportunity of drawing near to the Throne
of Grace from whence proseeds every good & perfect gift.
shewing to us mortals the way to Everlasting Life.

After the consideration of all these motives as Principally to be
regarded. I was in the next place; confirmed in our resolves to
proceed in this buisnesse for my Daughter whom I hoped to
be placed near us & her friends at stongrave being our own
Church; where I might have better advantage for my sonne
Robert & his sisters instruction.

Also I perceived by this last unsettling of that Estate from
my Daughters & yonger Children. they were brought into an
Incertainty for there Provision. which might fall too heavily
out for them. & be the worse for them after my Deceace.

So that upon consideration of the whole business; I have
mentioned. It was conseaved, convenient to entertaine
this motion & to close with such a happy oppertunity which
by the Providence of God was directed. And by reason of
her youth we resolved to keep it secret till a fitter time
when this intended business should be consumated.
There being still an affectionate corrospondancy of these
Persons by Chaste & religious conversations in our Family.
Neither was I out of hopes that Sir Christopher Wandesforde
might duely pay his 2000l out of Ireland which was to
redeeme that Estate & pay Mr Thorntons Ingagments.

But in the meane time. I might more probably die in some
of these sicknesses & my dear husband. who was often fall
ing into his Pallsie. when after our decease my Children
would be left in an uncertaine condition for Assistance

Behold the goodness of God which taketh care for mine, even
out of strangers. making me see his mercy in his Provi
-dences many fold to me & mine. Praise the Lord o my Soul
and forget not all his benifitts. Amen.

About the 2d of September: 1666 began the great fire
in London, which in 4 days time consumed 13200 houses
89 Churches. &: with out the miraculous Providence
of God it had devoured that whole Citty.

div.head:
My daughter Katherine Thorntons preservation in
the small Pox. the 29th of sept. 1666.
div.p:
Upon the 29th of sept. when I was yet very weak: be-
-gan my daughter Katte, with a violent & extreame pain
in the back & head; with such scrikes & torments that shee
was deprived of Reason. wanting sleep. nor could she
eate any thing for 3 days. she continued, to my great afflic
-tion not knoweing what this distemper would be.

At last the Small Pox appeared. breaking out abundantly
all over. but in her unguidablenesse stroke in again
so that my Brother Portington, used many Cordialls to save
221
her life. after which they appeared & then we had more
hopes. but was in great danger of losseing her sight.

She was all over her face in one Scurfe they running into
each other. But lo by the goodness of God, for which I
humbly bless & praise his holy name she passed the dan
-ger of Death beginning to heal. her extremity being
so great crieing night & day that I was forced to be re-
-moved though very weak as before into the Scarlett Chamber
for want of rest. Blessed be our gracious God through
his infinite mercy directing to good helpes & prospering the
means she was Preserved & healed again. Hanna
Ableson & Mary Cotes was her keepers. About november
she went abroad in the house. only losst by this sickness her
fair haire on her head & that beautifull complection God
had given. The Lord suply her Soul with the comelinesse of
his grace & spirit in her ??? Making her lovely in his
sight. And Praised be the Lord my God which was intreated
for my childes life. The Lord give me a thankful ??? &
that she may live to his Glory for Christs sake, Amen.

div.head: The death of my Brother John Wandesford: De. 2d 1666.
div.p:
It pleased God to vissitt my deare Brother John Wand.
At London. with his last sickness, being an Ague: joined
with violent fits of the stone. having had several of them
the last half year; his sickness continued so strongly
that he was very weak in body. though I bless God perfect
in mind & spirit. I am the better able to show the same from
the relation of his own servant, & the People where he lived
Testifieing this truth to Mr Comber. who was then at London
& intreated by me to vissitt my dear brother in his affliction
at the newes of hearing of me he did much rejoice & faine
would have seen his dear & beloved sister. but when he
understood I was in Yorkeshire. he praied them to remember
his dear love to me. & thanke me for sending to see him.
with abundance of Testimonys of his affection & love to me &
mine praing for us. then did he more Zealously prepaire for
his change & departure out of this miserable world. God have
-ing givn him a taste of heaven & happiness.
222
having bin long since weary of it, & banished from
the comforts of its injoyments. For several years since
my brother Georges Death he had laid under the most
sad & afflicting hand of God by reason of the want of the
use of his understanding which came to him by a deep
Malancolie seising upon his spirit Partly for the loss of
of my said Brother. & the grief he took upon ill usage
in the detaining of his Annuity. he being of a sweet
noble nature, it wrought the more to his Prejudice.

But I doe believe that what things of this nature, to any
of the Prejudice, of our family, did not proceed from the
Heires own inclination. being naturally of a good
& sweet dispossittion, but from the Counsel of such by
whom he had bin acted since his Marriage. who had
advised my bro. George to destroy the Intailes & Settlments
of his father by which he might be free to settle his Estate
wholely upon his Daughter to the Ruin of all his Family
but my bro. G. W. abhorred such treachery, nor ever
harkned to such designs. nor could my bro. Christ. und
-erstand the depth of such insinuations. not being experi
enced in the transactions of business, of this nature.

(However it was.) this poor Brother was the greatest suff-
-erer. both in body, & mind, having bin often recruited
& fully restored, was again brought down, through troubles
And want, he sustained. nor was it in my power to help
or releive him otherwise then by my Prayers & Tears for him.
our own sufferings being so great.

Yet did the God of mercies give him many intervalls in which
times he was religeously disposed. & constant in duties. with
a conscience to spend his days holely & uprightly; & in great
penitance for any thing that might offend his God.

About half a year before his death he was more strict in
his severe dutys of Piety, saying that he should not live long
so that he prepared for his desolation each daie.

The morning before he departed. (though he was very weak in
body). he would kneele in bed. & most devoutly, & seriously
223
Praied to his God & heartily recomended his Soul to
his Creator. and so laied him self quietly down: he
drew his breath shorter each minuitt & at last sweetely fell a
sleep in the Lord. thus was the conclusion of that dear, &
sweet brother. so much afflicted & under so long a
weakness. his condition was much to be lamented. & it
was indeed a contineuall grief, & daily corrosive to my
self, whose nearenesse in affection & consanguinity had
a sufficient simpathy in his sufferings.

He was a very great loss to our Family, by his trouble
& visittation; whose parts. Piety, Learning. & quick witt
was not infeariour to any that was remaining of it. being
of a most sweet, affable, & injenious nature. nimble &
ready in his acqute answers in disputes. as well at
Skoole as Cambridge. At both places he carried him self
so obleigingly that all Persons of his acquaintance loved & admired in his sigaci
tie coming nearest to his bro. George & for witt & Parts.
my dear mother had given him the best education she could
sending him to Cambrige about 15 years old: under the
Tuittion of Dr widdrington where he made great im-
provement of his time in the sciences, & learning. & was
so Studious. even at nights. & when his hours should have
bin for recreation: that his Tutor was forced to forbid that sever-
rity; his Sabaths were spent allwais (as much as he could)
very strict, in acts of Religion & Piety, Truly from his
childhoode & youth studing to serve & fear God.
In fine he was so hopefully good & pregnant, that my mot.
had much comfort & all his relations joy in him. being
full of expectations that this early plant might flourish to
the hon.or & happiness of the whole family. But it so hapned.
to our great grief; that this malancoly seising on him first at
Cambrige in a great sickness. then he was by an infinite
care & cost of my mother, he was perfectly well again. but
upon the former accidents mentioned, he fell very ill.
& yet all her care was contineud over him even at London
where he had bin inticed to go from her contrary to her mind
224
And suffered great hardships and injuries for the want
of somes care over him. & negligence to performe that
duty. till my dear mother committed him under the
Tuittion of Dr Batthurst. which he did faithfully perfo
rme all his life towards him. when he wanted nothing
for his comfort & help that either he could or my mot.
could doe for him. She every year giving that Dr a
gratituity of 10l for his pains & care over my brother
so long as the Dr lived. Although even then he wan
ted to discharge the mans house where he laid. out of
his own dues & Annuity. but I am sorrey there was
cause to speak thus much on this subject shall there
fore return to speak of concerning his Buriall.

He departed this life upon the second day of December:
1666 and buried in the Parish Church of Hodgeden. with
as hansome a solemnity as could be in that time. Mr Comber
preached a Funeral Sermon. Text. Eclle.
there being abundance of People on that occasion he
was buried the 3d December Mr Tirrill & his wife & servant
all expressing very great sorrow & lamentation for him
who had lived so innocently; & carried him self
so hansomely & well that had gained there affections &
pity towards his Person very much in that Place.
God making him to finde favour in his distress a
mongst straingers. And now the Lord God of Mercies
has I hope freed him from all misery. want, & oppression.
his most sad afflictions for several years had
prepared his soul for his Saviour. who had kept him
in all his health & sickness from any grosse sins, nor
was he inclined thereto in the least. but given him self to
God in his youth & childhood; (he was never heard to sweare
an oath;) before he went to Cambridge, I heard him make
the most fine exposittion extempory upon those words of
Davids advice to Solomon. And thou Solomon my son know
thou the God of thy father: &c the other 3 verces. that I never
heard the like from so young a Person. laying down our duty
to God. & service of him.

I hope he now injoys those hapinesse this world is not capab
of. who set himself to seeke God so early & so with an up
right ??? & however that the greatest of Temporal afflictins
[word] SiC ??? i.e., afflictions.
lay heavy on him. yet God sanctified all to him. & gave
him his Perfect use of his reason & understand that half
year before wherein he so excersized himself as was a
great comfort to his friends & relations. & testified that he
gave a return to some of our faithful, prayers for him.

Therefore in all things it now remaines, that I most hartily
return my humble & faithful thanks. Glory & Praise
that heard the groanes of his banished, delivering him by a
quiet & sweet sleep of death from all calamitys of this
wicked world & presed him for him self, who wanted those
mercies which 1000l doeth enjoy. And the Lords name be blessed for
ever that preserved his Precious Soul to his Kingdom through
Jesus Christ. I besech him sanctify this thy hand upon my
brother to me that thereby. I may be drawen nearer to thy
Majesty in love & gratitude. who hast not given me over
in to the will or Power of spirittuall Enemies. or suffered me
to lie in this condition wherein he was vissitted. Lord make
me to admire thy goodness & clemency towards me thy
poor handmaid who had deserved thy heavy hand. but thou
are pleased with testimonys of favour when thy mercy is
provoked that we may further glorify thy name & set forth
thy honnour
even to all generations.

Make me O Lord: to esteeme it thy free act of Grace to me
that I have never bin visited in the least with this kind of affliction
for thou alone has preserved me there from. which might have
befalen me as to many of thy dear servants in this world
by there other troubles of this life. O Lord except my humble
thankefull heart & I beseech thee if it be thy will, for
Christs sake never suffer me to fall into this most sad Estate
whereby I may be deprived of the opportunitys of doing thee
service or good to my soul. but give me still the perfect use of
Reason & understanding that I may live all my days to the glory
of thy majesty & the proffitt of my brethren. & the Eternal
good of my own soul for the Lords sake Amen.

About this Christmas 1666 my Cozen william Norton
was inhumainly murdered at London neare Grays Inn.

div.head:
My Son Roberts having the small Pox. Jan. 5 1667
and of his recovery perfectly again.
div.p:
The 5th of Jan. my deare Robin Thorntons began his sicknes
of the small Pox being very ill & weak for 2 days. the
7, 8, 9th he was in great danger of death. they not come
-ing well out till the 10th on which day he lost his sight by
them being very great ones & full.

About the 14th his feavor & dissease was at hight. & on the
15th he altered for the better. so that a change was discerned
the 17th he began to see again. the 18 had his sight clearly
recovered. after which he recovered very fast. for which I
most humbly bless God. with all my soul. & magnify
his mercies to me in the deliverance of this my dear & sweet
Child, in not quenching our cole in this Family. O Praise
the Lord o my soul & forget not all his benifitts. this his
favour to thee for ever. Amen. The 24th Robin first
got up. & was perfectly well. groweing strong & was not
so much disfigured As his sister Kate. But he never
recovered his sweet beautifull favour & pure couler in
his cheeks. but his face grew longish. his haire did not fall
of. he wanted 9 months of being 5 years old & some dais
Hanna Ableson & margery millbanke kept him in his
sickness.

It Pleased God, after my sonne Robert was well. to
vissitt my daughter Alice Thornton. which began in her
sleepe with another dangerous fit in her sleep. which much
awakned frighted me. she being almost choaked by the
Phlegme. making her exceding sick. before she vomitt
up some ill digested meate & with extremity she was
blacke in her face. but by the mercies of our Gracious God
after she vomitted. she did recover. though it kept her
weak. I will praise the Lord our God of our salvation for this
great deliverance of my Child. Amen.

div.head: My daughter Alice Thornton her Small Pox Jan.25 67.
div.p:
About the 25th of January Naly took Phisicke to prevent the
Small Pox. when she fell to be very ill pained in her head
& back on the 26th she being very ill & sick in an Aguish
temper the 27 & 28th till the small Pox appeared. being for
2 days in a cold sweate with out heate & in very great da-
-nger of Death. the 29 she was in great hazard yet lay
very patiently & did not talke Idle as usuall in such dis
eases. though there was little hopes of her recovery. They being
stroke in through her could sweats; yet was all remidies
used to her for warmth by Hanna. & c. & Cordialls by brother
Portington. But on the 29 it pleased the great & gracious
God, he did begin to give us better hopes. the small Pox then
coming out & apeare. she was in a warmer temper. not
so sick as formerly. & we by the mercies of God hoped for
a recovery: At the 31 day she fell blind intermitting till
the 5th of february being exceedingly choaked in her throat. &
could not swallow, almost any thing with out a Pipe for the
small Pox & streit throat. nor did she get any sleep
till the 3d february After which she got a little & the 4th her Eyes began
to unclose. the 5th saw perfectly. & they blackned. & her
throat mended. & the fever abated: the 8th day of feb she
began to be pretty well. though extreamely full & sore. About
the 18th Naly rose out of bed & recruited in strength by degrees
The haire came of & that favour cleane taken from her.

But oh that our hearts were inlarged in thankfullnesse
to the great Lord our God for the preservation of this my
Eldest Child whose speciall deliverance must not be for-
-gotten to give glory to the great God of Israell which had pity
upon my self, husband. & 3 Children. by restoring their
lives when they were all so night many deaths. O Lord
accept I beseech my gratefull & humble ??? which had com-
passion upon thy Servants & our Child. Let us all live to
be instruments to thy Glory & hon.orour here & here after: Amen.

My brother Dentons Son John fell into great extreamity
upon the taking of Phisicke on the 25th of Jan. which did not
work kindly. & so continued 3 days deprived of sleep
or foode. falling into a fever. with violent pain. all which
deprived him of his understanding being in a dangerous
condition. but it pleased God at last getting some sleep
about 4 a clock in the morning he knew every one when
the Pox apeared the fever abated & he recovered very
fast having but a few. blessed be God for his deliverance.

The 8th of April: 1667 Nally had a Pearle on her Eye
after the small Pox. which indangered the loss of her Sight
But by waters. & a meadicien to the wrests of her Arms
which sweet Mrs Bucke did advise she recovered that danger
being well again about the 30 April. 1667. I humbly
bless the Lord for the least, & greatest testimonys of his daily
favours to me & mine. O that these might set forth his
praises for ever more Amen.

In the year 1659 when I was at St Nickolas. after the
death of my dear mother Kate Thornton was preserved
from choakeing with a pin which got cross her throat. which by
the blessing of God I got out by my finger; when she was
nigh death: as also through his Providence. I preserved
her maid Anne Robinson from the like death by a peice
of a goose wing pinnion which was cross so long: that her
breath was stopt. & almost dead. at Oswoldkirke. 1661.

About the year when Kate was 10 years old plaing with
her cosens in Newton Barne & swing cross by a Rope she
got so high a fall by his swinging her from him. (J. D) that
she was taken up dead. being blacke & with out breath for
a long time at which sudden blow I was much afrighted for
my Child, rubing & useuing all means for her recovery,
and it was half an hour before any signes of Life apeared
But it pleased God in mercy. at last she did breath:
229
Again & by degrees came to her self at an hours space
after warming &c in bed but knew nothing of the fall a
long time. it had don her much harm in her head with
great pains: But I most humbly praise & addore the
Name of God most high. which graciously remembred mercy
in the midst of Judgement: nor didst thou cutt of my Child
life sudainly in her folly & childishnesse. but recovered her
again by mercy. O let this her Life be given her for good. &
that she may be Pardoned. & made an instrument of thy
Glory. & praise to magnify thee for thy spaireing her life
& understanding. give her & us all grace never to for
get these wonderful mercies to our souls & bodies. Amen:

It was the permition of God, for the affliction of us all, in
the loss of so brave a Gentleman. to let a dismall stroake
fall heavy upon the Person of my Nephew Thomas Danby.
being the hope of his Family. & just at that time when he had
ingaged to clear of all Debts Portions &c in the due performance
of his Fathers will. when all things would have bin don
to all Persons sattisfactions. But Allasse this poor Gentlemean
was sudainely surprised, & murdered. with out any pro-
vocation or malice begun on his side. comitted with the most
Barbarous sircumstances imaginable; by one Beridge a
stranger to him. but a Camrade to Ogle & Jenny
which was
then with Tom. Danby: but did not assist. The pretence was
about Ogles sword that Tom had redeemd from Pawne & unluc-
-kily had on that day. which Berridge upbraiding him, for picked
a quarrell. but, it is too probable that they had a spleene again
[word] I.e., again[st]?
his life because non assisted. but wittnesses of this bloody
Tragedie. The murderer fled. they were catchd. but by the too
remisenesse of the Jury Escaped punishment notwithstanding
the displeasure of the Judge. but Jenny that summer went home
& was convicted in Conscience never apeared after. but died
very penitent. he died in London neare Grayse Inne August
the first; in the year 1667.

div.head:
The birth of my Sonne Christopher, my 9th Child
no. 11 1667 & of his Death. Dec. 1st 1667.
div.p:
Of my 9th Child; it was the pleasure of God to give
me a weak & sickely time in breeding from the February
till the 10th of may following. I not having fully recruited
my last Sept. weakness; & if it had bin good in the Eyes
of my God. I should much rather (because of that) not to
have bin in this condition: but it is not a Christians
part. to chuse any thing of this nature. but what shall be the
will of our heavenly father, be it never so contrary
to our own desires. Therefore did I desire to submit
in this dispensation. & depend upon his providence
for the preservation of my Life, who had delivered me
in all my extreamities. & Afflictions.

I had not my health, till about the 10th of May. when I
perceived my self withquick Child. affterwards during
the time of being with Child. till within a month of my de
-livery very well as of any other. walkeing a mile
to the Church each Sabath day. I humbly bless the God
of my Life & strength. that restored so much health &
strength again to his handmaid. Giving me great
comfort in my dear & beloved husband. who all this
summer & spring was so well & strong as he never had
bin since his first ill fit at Steersby. The Lord giving
a blessing to those means appointed by Dr wittie for his
preservation. which order we observed; till towards Sept.
following. But when I grew so bigge & ill near my
delivery about Micklemas he intermitted those rules of di-
rections wanting my assistance about his Person to
in my Illnes. he relapsed several times. And had the Dr
sent for to him very often. by which helpes through Gods
Blessing was restored to me again. Praised be our good.
& gracious Lord God for Ever. Amen.

The birth of my 9 child was very Perillous to me, & I
hardly escaped with my life. falling into pangs of Labour
about the 4th of no. being ill. contineuing that week. And on
Munday the 11 of November 1667. I fell in travell, being
delivered betwixt the hours of 10 & 11 a clock at night
I was to my own apprehension & others, never nearer
Death. by the midwives inforcement of the Child so violently
which caused a grand dislocation of the back & reines by the
inexpressable torments I endured: But in the midest of
my distresses & anguish of Soul & boyie,
[word] I.e. bodie. The great and
Powerfull Lord God pittied my soul & had compassion on
me at that time, most Miraculously & wonderfully preser
-ving me from death when I was stept into the grave
even these 10 times, nay million of times may I give
give thanks. unto the Lord. who turned my sorrows into
Joy. that no death has had the upper hand of me still.

O my soul love thou the Lord & Praise him & magnify
him for ever. delight in him all thy life. he is thy Joy
thy Life. salvation & refuge. I called unto him in my
distress & he heard & delivered me out of the Pitt of
destruction & death. preserving me from fears & torments
Thou art O Lord the guide of my youth. the succorrour in my
sorrows. thou caires for me, because thy mercy is in-
finitt & uncearchable. & I have depended on thee ever
since I was borne. and put my trust in thee alone. O
Most hight. let me still have thee for my God in the ^ sweet
influences of thy Power & mercy by which the sonnes of men
are upheld & delivered. that we might magnify thy
glory & praise for ever. Thou hast given me a goodly
strong & sweet son, to mittigate those sorrows. &
addeing the blessings of the breasts, to that of the womb. O
Praise the Lord with me for ever. Amen.

It pleased the Lord to give another mercy that night
for my daughter Alice with fear & grief for me fell so
sick in my Labour that she was in much danger of death
but blessed be the Lord which preserved her then & recovered
her from that illnesse. the next day. no. 12, 67

Christopher Thornton my 9th Child was borne at newton
on munday the 11 no. 67 Baptized the 12th at newton.
232
His God fathers & God mother were my Bro Denton
my brother Portington. & Mrs Anne Danby.

After this comfort of my Child I recovered something
of my weakeness, better: recovering my breasts &
milk. & giving sucke, when he thrived very well
& grew strong. being a lovely babe.

But least I should too much set my heart in the
satisfaction of any blessing under heaven. it seemed
good to the most infinite wise God, to take him from me
giving me some apprehensions there of before any did
see it as a change in him. And therefore with a full re-
signation to his providence I endeavoured to submit
patiently & willingly to part with my sweet Child to
our dear & loving Father. who ses what was better
for me then I could. begging that his will might be
mine either in life or death. when he was about
14 days old my pretty babe broake into red spots.
like the small Pox. And through Cold gotten by thin-
-ner clothing then either my own experience or Practice
did accustome to all my Children. they following the
precept of M. D. (it presently) though then unknown
to me; upon this accident. with the extreame cold wether
fell into great loosenesse. & notwithstanding all the
means I could use. it continued 4 days. have-
ing endured it patiently. then fell into some little
strugling. and at length it pleased his Saviour & mine
after the 5th sick night & day to deliver him out of
this miserable world. he sweetely fell asleepe on sunday
at night. being then the 1st of December 1667 who was at
that time 3 weeks old, on the next day the 2d when he was
Buried at Stongrave by Mr Comber, who preached a
funeral sermon. Dec. 2d 1667.

After my dear Childes death. I fell into a great &
long continued weakness, by the swelleing of my
milk. he having sucket last (in his pain) of the left
breast had hurt the niple, causeing it to gangareene. &
233
Extreame pained with torment of it, made me fall into
a feavour. which together with excessive pains in my head
& Teeth upon much grief from the unhansome. Proud
carriage of those I took to be a comfort in my distress
proved the greatest corisive in my sick & weak con-
dittion. I being then the lesse able to support my spirits
under such afflictions. so that such strainge uncharit
able dealing kept me from gathering strength. I not
being able to stand nor go. for 4 months: till feb following
wittnessed by those servants that attended me then. &
was compelled to be carried to, & from my bed in a Chair

Even at that time did those which had a secret hatred
against me (though I neither knew it, nor its cause then
for I never in my whole life by word or act had the least pre-
-judice or don her any injury, to make it: as I must
apeale to the Lord for truth:) yet then she undermined my
peace & quiet, & scornfully presenting my reall weak
nesse & sad condition, to some in secret saying that I ailed
nothing, & I was as well as she. & made my self a
talke to my neighbours). All which she carried with much
subtilty for the dishonour of my poor despised Person
sufficiently afflicted with out this addittion. yet were
these but the beginning of sorrows to me upon that account; endeavouring
to bare all with abundance of Patience. which my God did
please to give me: in part hopeing with all that when I mett with
Tom. Danbys wife. I should prevail for her restoration
to her children; which she did object daily to me that she
had bin kept from, because her sister was angery she
came, as before, to be with me, while I layd lame. But
I still told her if I had suspected her sisters displea-
sure for that, I would never have, putt that to hazard for the
world. nor did she in the least give me notice thereof.
but my nephewe Kitts wife did make this an objection. & I beelive
owed me no good will for it. though she reserved more
for an after game (secret) to my Ruin.

Butt thou o Lord seest & knoweth my integretty for
this womans good. & the love I bore her ever since I knew
234
her. & therefore I desire this to pardon what occa
sion of evil has befallen me. from her & receive my humble
& faithful thanks for thy inexpressable mercy &
goodness to me thy poor Creature, All glory be given
to thy name, & for ever magnified be the Lord most high
which bringeth me down to the gates of death. & has raised
me beyond all hope or expectation. times with out number
even now; O Lord hast thou had pittie on my soul and
let me out live 6 of my Children. but graciously taken
them from this sinful life. Lord blese to thy poor handmaid
all these heavy afflictions. that are incident to this weary
Pilgrimage. & let me not depend on dust & Ashes for
comfort or satisfaction. be thou my friend & guide
my staffe & stay. still to support my own & husband
& Children's souls. let me prepaire daily & long for
those lasting Joys that never shall have End. which thou in
thy good time will please for Christ his sake to bring me
to: that I may sing for ever the song of thy redeemed
Glory be to God on high. Peace & good will towards us men.
I will magnify thee o blessed Trinity fore ever.
Amen. Amen.

After the recovery of my health & strength again
I had returned an other affliction; which was not at that
time so heavy when I was sick my self, I bless God
but like 2 bukettes in a well it pleased God to deal with
us. when the one was down the other was up. so I being
recruited had my work in the assistance of my dear Hus
band. whose often & frequent relapses in to his Pallsie
fell on him to my abundant grief. so that from no. 67
till August 68 Dr wittie was almost each month
fetched to him. when he relapsed. or the degrees beginning on
him. which most sad condition made me never inoyed my
self. with fears of losseing him my cheifest Comfort &
support. & for his Sufferings. although the Lord did please
to give him intermitions. & also. we could not perceave that
he was in any extremity. but slumbring all the time of
his illnesse, till after glisters he was brought
235
to himself again they being the speediest reamidie at
present. then affterward all other reamidies was applied by Dr nilly
direction. And he was well again. even to Peoples
admiration; which was so ill of a sudden & better again.
& according to the earlinesse of beginning with reamidies
They wrought. & the fits longer or shorter in continuance
So that we saw too aparantly that my dear husbands dis-
-temper might be a means to shorten his days at last. And
we were much concerned to get all the settlements
don & perfected. least we should be deprived of him

And to that end my Brother Denton with Mr Comber
& my self was exceedingly imployed at all times
almost when he was in a condition for business.
Hastening the Draughts of writtings, & settlements, with
Counsel how to give all Persons satisfaction in there
Just Debts. And not till the 28th day of may: 1668
was our settlement Perfected from the time of my Co.
Covills being destroyed. for either Portions or mainte
nance. which went most sadly with me. but now by the great
Pains & industery of my Brother Denton. & Mr Comber
who we did for my Children's good imploy , as a
friend to them in General, as well as in his Particular
respest
[word] SiC ??? i.e., respect. for my Daughter Alice. had much care
for them also. It was most true that I lived remote from my
own Relations: That day wherein my dear husband
signed His Deed for my Children's Provision out of
of Laistrop he did signe my bro. Dentons 3 Rent Charge
for his part of Portion by my sister of 250l out of the
other part of Laistrop. which ought in conscience to be payd.
I humbly bless our gracious Father which gave me leave
to git this don for provision of my yonger Children,
& that the Estate was in a better frame then it had bin of
late, by the payment of 1000l in Debts of his Rent Charg
of Mr sayer. which he had but newly sould & payd of with it
this year many great ingadgements secured out of the
land at Laistrop. by which it was made clearer.

A bout the 20th day of may: on that night, my dear hus
-band had a dreame which he told to my Brother Denton
Mr Comber & my self, in the morning. severally. which
did very much trouble me to hear. That he should
live but 47 days longer: Nor was he ever apt to
take notice of such things, but rather condemne me
for relating several ominus dreames that I had before
the Death of my Father, my Uncle, Osborne, my Sister
Danby, my brother George, before whose death half a
year I dreamt so fully concerning it, the manner & all
sircumstances about it. that he refrained that River after
I told him my dreame. till that time which was the last &
being compell by his business to doe itt.

Also before my mothers death, & several of my Ch-
-ildrens: So that now he himself was more apt to
make use of this as a warning to him. being often
heard to say he should not live very long. & with much
diligence endeavred to prepare his soul for God.
In which time I who had my comforts so intirely bou
nd up in him could not with patience almost to think
of this change. If possibly it might be the good pleasur
of the Lord to spare him to us.

we repaired (upon the next illnesse) to Dr wittie he not
being willing for any others advice. to confided what
course could be taken for his preservation. so that upon
a serious consideration of his distemper, then inclining
to malancolicke, he aduised him for the Spaw, where he
had bin other years with good successe. Upon which Mr Thornton
was very desirous to go, beleiveing it would help him
And The Dr firmly ingaged to be as cairfull of him
as his own Life. so upon the 5th of June: 1667 we
set forward in a Coach with him to Malton. with my 3
Children I thinkeing to have gon to scarbrough with him
but it so pleased God that I fell exceeding ill that I could
not go. but was forced to return home to newton: &
left him under the care of my Brother Portington & sister
237
And in the company of Dr wittie. the 8th of June following he went
by a hired coach to scarbrough. And about a month after
he returned home on horse back. it being his own desire:

All which time we had a dear & comfortable corrospondancy
betweene us, by our mutuall And frequent letters. I heareing
of him, or from him 3 times in a week & ofter
[word] I.e., oftener? each one bring
-ing me the good newes of his having cast off his malancoly
It cannot be immagined, what my Joy was in his return
to finde him so prettily recruited by a chearefull temper
of spirit. but I quickly saw: that his weakness had left
much dreggs of his distemper. yet had I great cause
of thankefullnesse to the Lord which gave me hopes of him.
& that if he could have bin prevented of cold he would remaine
well.

div.head: |On Mrs Anne Danbys going to Hooly. Ap. 20 67.
div.p:
Upon the complaint of Mrs Danby to Mrs Batte, (then a
Servant to the young Countesse of sussex; and accounts
by her to be the dearest friend she had in the world) of her
hard usuage by Madam Danby; & several discontents
framed by her servant in my house, adding to her for-
-mer disgust towards me in her being cast out as she
said for my sake. these, with other secret unjust reasons
of her own. bey these 2 persons was a mutuall compliance
in there designs & Mrs Danbys underming me in secret
brought Mrs Batte late at night to my house at newton
under pretence of providing butter for Mrs Danby at the
service at hooly to waite on that mad Countesse of Sussex
Mrs Batt told me. she came to fech her cosen danby a
away. & that she would have her from me. I upon this first
salutation being surpreised with her discourse as well as her
sudden vissitt. (which yet Mrs Danby knew of.) told her
again that I had bin desirous to see her & of her acquaintance
upon my neece her account. but that she should now come
to fettch her from me, whose wellfaire I much wished. &
loved her company, with out giving me any notice. I could
not tell what to say of it. & that what my poor house could
afford towards my neeces her content, & what I could doe
238
For her should not be a wanting. no more then what
I had formerly don to my weak capacity. And I could
not willingly part with her. hopeing that her sister upon
my soliciting would settle her again.

my discourse more to this Purpose. but the other said she
would have her away from me. Then I returned that I
would leave it to my neece her self to dettermine, as she
pleased. Upon the sunday morning. they having lien
together that night. & prepaired for a march to Hooly; But
they were prevailed to stay that day, being every way
unfitt to breake the sabbath. upon so slight an occasion

Upon discourse with Mrs Batte she said that she admired
why all Mrs Danbys friends, that non of them could in dure
her of her husbands side, but I that looket at her or shewd any
respect. I said that I could not so well know the reason
save that she brought no fortune & was a charge to that family
as I had heard them say, & that Sir Tho. Danby could not be
reconsiled because of kitts marriage to her against his
knowledge or consent. Then Mrs Batte said it was true
that she had seen a letter in Virginia that came to Mrs Danby
from Sir Tho. out of England, in answer to one from Mrs D.
to him. that was extreamly sharpe. where he told her that
she had inveagled his son to marry her with out his consent
& their marriage was not Lawfull. And for her that had not
a groate
[word] SiC, although presumably means great. Portion after such an act: to be so Proud & high
as to require him to furnish her with silke stockings. sattin
& cloth a silver mantles & other things answerable to that
State. was more presumption then any could imagine.
his son being a yonger brother & so had nothing but from
his goodness. Sir Tho. D. expressing much more to her in
that letter to this purpose. & was so incensed that he would
never seldom
see her in all his Life but shunned her at all times
sending for his son into England with out her; I said I had
not heard of such letters. but that Sir Tho. was much displeasd
at me & my mother for speaking for her to him & said that
we knew her not so well as he did. & that they might curs
239
time of her entrance into his Family, for the mischeife she
had wrought in it: & that match could not prosper which was
begun in such an unlawfull manner. it had bin the grand
discontent of his life. & more to the like purpose several
times so my mother, nor my self after many endeavors
could never prevale for her. yet did I allwaies commise
-rate her condition, whose Person was so qualified &
seemed to be religious. & carried so fair in her demener
having abundance of charity for her condition. having
helped her with advice & assistance in all things to my
poure,
[word] I.e., power. beleiving that she had bin wronged. according to her
own complaint. When our discource was ended. they
came from Church, & went to dinner. After it was consulted
on & thought fit to send to Mr farrer at Malton for his
advice whether Mrs Danby might go to Hooly as a vissitt
who returnd by word, that he conseavd she might go
and thither
although he knew that place was in opposition to Madam Danby
& would displease her if she staid any time. but for a while
she might go as he thought with out prejudice. this she
conseavd was allowance. but he spoke very prudently
to both partys. .Then Mrs Danby was pleased as it were
to consult as she said at least in pretence with me of her
going thither. which I could not tell how to dettermine becaus
at that time her sister Danby was coming into the Country &
I was to use my indeavours for her having then very
good hopes. as also so had Mr Farrer who said he did
believe he could prevail for 60l a year if she would except
it. And with all I did not know what to advice which might
sattisfie her. but left it to her how to dispose herselfe. for
I told her that as well as I could entertaine her in my house
she should want for nothing. I would use my uttmost with
her sister to give a sufficient Provision for her & her Children
But doubted that her Jorney to Houly might doe harm.
but because I could not doe her what good I would being so
low in our Estate, I could not hinder from her better ad
vantage. She said indeed it was much below her to go to
service (as Mrs Batt did counsell her) & she thankt God.

If she would take that course of life, she could doe better
for her self, but she would go over to see the place becaus
it was out of mattie Batts love extoling her frindship
to the skies & much undervaleuing all my endevours &
faithfullnesse, yet did she expect this as a reserve if
she liked not Hooly. The next morning prepared with great
Joy to go. & when she was at breakfast exprest much
indignation, that she was turnd out as she termd it for my
sake from Beedall. I could answer no otherwise then to
show my sorrow for it. & that if she had informd me of that
before that her sister was angery she should not have comd

At her going that morning she was highly displeased as
(I was informed) that she spoke it to. That Mr Comber, or my
brother Denton, who she had much deluded with fair show
did not waite upon her to Hooly. And was only conduc-
-ted by my chief servant. & 3 of the Earles men, with Mrs
Batt & her maid.

This was only a pretence, though Pride enough: for when
I sent men & horrses, to bringe her home above 60 miles
hence on purpose. she was not pleased. because Mr Combber
came not. but sent them back empty save with a Letter to
my brother Denton to invite him under pretence) but rea
ly the others who she then prosecuted with eager designe
for to drawe him in for a husband for Mrs Batte and in
whose incomium she had spent so much time & pains
to represent him with the best of Retorick to her; which at the
first view was sufficiently forward to show her good op-
pinion of that man. Mr Thornton was highly displeased
that she had bin so incivill to return his servant Empty &
that also he was made so wellcome there, that he diffred not from
a beast in his drunkenesse at that house. so that he would not
let me send no more for her.

In this time. I was so far from giving her any abuse
or remembring these injures. that Madam Danby coming to see
me on may: day: I so much soclicited for her that she did
faithfully ingage to me that for my sake, & not her own, which
had personally disobleigd her at Beedall.
241
before she came to Newton. yet she would doe what she
could, & that she would give her 60l per Annum. & giue her 10l
or 5l when she came to see her at a time & give her all her goods again
& if she could doe more, she would as she was able &c.
and did Protest & vowe that she did not take it ill that
her Sister came to me but wished her to come. And that it was
but her Plott to object that to me, to insinuate with me, & to
Make me keep her. for she knew not that she was with me when
she dischargd her house. but that her own unsufferable prid
which would never be humbled, & her Railing blacke mouthed
wench that came to farnly and abused her there, these all
did cause her to cast her out. and much to this purpose.

And that she was going to look into her Estate being the first
time after her husbands death. & as she found she could doe for
her she would though she did it out of her own Estate. for
my cause to bring them together. although they wanted for
nothing now. Upon these tearmes passed Madam Danby & my
self, concluding that I was to waite on her at Mallton at her
return when she would sattisfie me better & doe for her.

Having received this hansome and free account from Madam
Danby I diffirred not to give ketts wife the relation of it
by letter to Hooly purposly sending one before our last men
went for her. And her return for this kindenesse I have
related.

But after wards my brother Denton going to see his friends
near Leeds, brought her back again to Newton. where I did
receive her with Joy as was my custome out of my unfeined
love to her person. Nor could I be perswaded of her unworthy
-nesse to meshe so finely acting her part & so secrettly. only I
observed abundance of hight, & majesty in her deportment
with a kinde of scorne, at her return, rather more then usuall
towards me. & did see that then I was made use of as upon
necessity, not affection, as was formerly much pretended.

My endeavours was much slighted & daintily overseene.
& she highly insenced that she had not bin waited upon by
Mr Comber, which she looked upon it, as if he slighted her
favour & rejected her friend. by not accepting that motion.

Which unpardonable offence could not be passed with out
great indignation. yet so secret & subtile was this acted
, that it could not be diserned till after the malice broke out
publickely against me & my Childe. Alice Thornton.

Let this practice of hers be examined whether she carried
her self to me, either as a Christian; a friend; or a well wishe
who bublickly made me believe, nay recommended this
match to me as in her own Judgment & choyse we woulde
be exceeding happy in it for she did find Mr Comber to be a
man of as great Piety & Parts, incomparable. as she never
knew in all her life, & that she had solicited for him. advising
both parties. that is to say Mr Comber & my Daughter to this
buiseniess, above 3 years agone. she knew also their affec-
tions. & the Progresse of all that concern. & with a full gaile of
consent she went along with it as well with my brother Denton
as our selves. All;
Which proves it an undoubted act of displeasure conseaved
against me, and an act of revenge, thus seeking to withdraw
this mans intentions from the long intended match & that realy
she had excellent good oppinions of this gentleman to draw
him to her bosome friend. whom she so loved, & would preffer
And I know not how it can be distinguished from a treatch
