erous and unworthy part in a friend. thus to deal with me
after so long & serious debate of his intended marriage
with my daughter, with her own counsell, advice & aprobation
And so fallsely to undermine the same for her own partiall
& secret designs: first to have offred her self to bring a
match about with mrs Katherine Farrer, which she told him
would be of great advantage to him, & then when that failed
& he would not close with her against his full intentions
& our Resolutions already long since agreed upon.

But this did not sattisfie her, till she had made a new triall
& assault upon his loialty, by the last expedittion.
243
Related of Mrs Batt. in all which time since her last coming to
Newton ever endeavouring to with draw by insinuations &
exclent plausability Mr Combers affections from my daughter
after her evil designs was hatched against us at Newton
Thiese are full proofe of her great admiration of this man
with 100 more triks: Telling him that she had so great an
honour for him. that he deservd a better fortune & wife then
she was. for there was like to be nothing worthy of his
Parts & deservings. & that he would be undon, & never live
comfortable life, & she wished him so well that she could
desire him the best wife in the world. ever admiring his perfections
& insinuated so much, that she got his sermon notes or heads
& then write them over & calld them her own. so did she with
him about his Coates of Heraldrie of the Nobilittie of England.

Ever seeking opportunities when to use Artifices to her own
purpose of insinuation; which can be testified for truth. to
ingraciate into his affection non indevouring to admire
his person, & all expressions imaginable. then her self.

At the same time, though at secret opportunitis. she would
come to my daughter Alice. telling her that she wished her
so well and loved her for her good nature & vertue that she
would have her marry the best husband in the world & that she
deservd it; & that if those things were true that Mr Comber was
Charged with he was not worthy to live, & God forbid she shoud
have him. with abundance of such insinuations to this purpos
Naly told her she thanked her for her love, but she was
boud not to believe evil of any. unlesse she should see it
&. that she had never known any unhansomenesse from him
in all her life, it was true she had an affection for him for
she see no other cause. for she had received much good
from him for her soul. & she would have don well to have
showed her dislike before. & to that purpose. thanking her for
propounding one of her own relations to her. for she was
not worthy of such a person of hon.or. And that she hoped to God
244
he would direct her in her choyce when she did mary
that she might lead a comfortable life in the fear of God
though not so high in the world &c. And she could
never believe any such ill of Mr Comber as those said
which told her for she knew his conversation to the contrary

Upon which discourse. Mrs Danby did no more insist upon
any more to her. but grew to hate her more. notwith-
standing all my daughters observance, & attendance
on her. Ater
[word] I.e., after her return from hoouly; & Madam Danbys
to Malton. I endeavoured with Mr Th. to get her comp-
any thither. that I might have reconsiled her & her sister.
but she could not be prevailed with upon no tearmes, nor
so much as to write to her in a civill way. But said
several times she had as leve see the Deivill as her.

So that I went only with my brother Denton. thither and
had amost teadious & ill jorney being soe sick as well
when I came there, as back again. as I had like to have
died. Upon my adresse to Madam Danby I found her very
Civill to me but so highly insenced against Kitts wife as
I did admire. And at first would not scarse hear me
speak for her at all: saying that since she saw me last
she had bin informd of her Perfidious Railing & dishonour
in all things making her guilty as much as her lieing
toung & godly Railing could doe, of the horiblest sins of the
world. & she would doe nothing because of her wicked malis

And that for all what I did for her she was unworthy of it
because she had Railed on me too. for a requitall.
But I said I could not believe any such thing of her who
had so much religion. &c. And I thought her wronged.
Begging that she would not believe any thing against her
from Evil instruments that sowed discord betwixt them.
And at the last with much adoe endevrd to
prevaild that she would for my
sake give them a sufficient provision. & settle 80l per Annum
on her & her Children she said that if she would except
60l a year. which was all that she could doe. they should
245
have it don, & that she would get Kit a place in a troope
& give them their furniture & fit him with accoutrements
of all things for it. And if she see them endeavour to live
she would give her 10l or 5l at a time for incouragment
when she came to see her. but I having no committion
to accept of 60l per Annum. from my neece Danby but a charge
to the Contrary could not promise for her. only presed for
80l leaveing her to consider of it because 60l would not
pay their debts. And I would acquaint Mrs Danby with
her proposalls. and would give her an account. To that end
I did at my return to Newton give her as favourable an
account of my embassie as I could. consealing
all speeches which should give her the least cause of trouble

But Mrs Danby was not inclinable to accept of her sisters
offers. but stood upon her high horse. She would either
have 80l a year settled upon her and her Debts promised
to be paid, or she would never inslave her self again to live
as she had don with her Children. she could tell how to live
otherwise if she might not live hansomly with them.

After a days time or two. It was thought fit I should
write to Madam Danby again to second my solicitation for
her: And a letter was contrived by consent. wherein I writ
with as much humble submission as a Pettioner for another
could dicttate; only some clauses was put in from Mrs
Danbys own mouth, wherein she said she could not subsist
under 80l a year; & if it were till 7 years. & there debts
paid. Madam Danby returnd me a most sharpe & bitter
Answer: that since I was so positive for kitts wife, & that she
would not except of her free offers by me. which she was not
obleiged to otherwise then by her good will. she would never
give her any thing at all. & that she had made her brags
she had better friends then her husbands. & could provide
for her self she might. & that she would take care of her hus-
band & the Children she had to bring them up. & provide
246
For them; and him. but would never have any thing to
doe for her. with several such like expressions. so much
was she disobleiged for her high demands. And upon this
account did she cast her off. nor would have nothing
to doe with her further. And was so much displeased at
me that I then quite lost her favour. Neither could I see
any requittall in the other; but a slighting for my faith
fullnesse & goodwill. Yet still I shall not faile of my
duty of Charity to pray for those in necessity. & forgive
nesse that hates me with out a cause.

div.head:
Upon my Sad condition, & Sickness that beffell me by
the Slanders Raised against me: July 20th 1668.
div.p:
Notwithstanding all my true & earnest endevours
to show my great comiseration, & Charity, affection &
love I had towards this Gentlewoman. which not only was
showed to her as my bosome friend. in whose freindship
I rejoyced & thought my self happy in being instrum-
entall to doe any thing servisable to her in faithfullnesse &
affection. as well in testimonys of gratitude for what
kindenese I reciaved in my former sicknesses, & 2 Child.
; as also of her low Estate; being comd into my Sisters family
There was nothing awanting in my family, or my self
which she might not freely command. wittnesed by all People
that knew my actions & would speake nothing but truth.
nor any thing displeased her. but I took it don to my self
yet had I never till now; cause to bewaile my sad fortune
in her disaffection, nor felt the sad consequents of the falling
of from that League of amity & freindship which was of a long
time even after 6 years acquaintance, contracted with her
I may now see my folly. when tis too late, to bewaile my
Misery; not to foresee That, Possibly, to be true; which I could
not believe. Those which serves there friends for their Private
Ends, may have them turn.
247
to be their bitterest adversaries; And repine at there
happienesse, when themselves are miserable, or infortunate.
Some of this Gentle. w.
sinester indeavours has bin declard
by me, with there profe being very evident. Endeavring to have
gotten subsistance more to her satisfaction under their
Roofes when she should have brought that match to perfection.
being that which was conjectured, her eager designs.
having wholey cast of those former freindships, which she
pretended for me. I need not examine the injustice, or wrong
don in this action. but should have waived any thing, as
I did of this nature. had it rested there; & not proseeded to
such high indignities against my person, & the Family
from whence I desended. Persons of hon.or vertue & worth
whose Ashes long since was Buried in the unspotted bed of
hon.or And therefore could be nothing else but of the old
Serpents production to defile the bodies when dead) of those
he had no part in, when living. That through the scandalls
of their sides to forge speares to pearce there living
Posterity; & not of that Spirit which commands; Thou shalt
not Raise a false report. nor speak Evil of no man,
much less to joyne with the wicked & scorners against
there own knowledge, & experience, of them that fears
God, least they bring on them selves that punishment spoke
of in Psallme the 1st v. the 4th, 5, 6 Pro. 24: 8th He that deviseth
to doe Evil, shall be called a mischievous person: 28 v.
Be not a witness against thy neighbour with out cause:
& deceive not with thy lips. Too sadly have I experienced
this Pro. 25: 18, 19. Confidence in an unfaithfull man in
time of trouble, is like a broken tooth & a Sd foot out
of joynt. A man that beareth false witness against his
Neighbour, is a maule, & a sword, & a sharpe Arrow.

Yet such has bin my hard, miserable fortune to meete with all
in this time of my life, when the other heavy afflications & trials
from God lay upon my self, dear husband & Children.
I must taste of this bitter Pill too as one ingreadient of the
Mixture of my Saviours cup. which I will endeavour to.
248
Entertaine with humility & Patience that I may put on
the Lord Jesus Christ & him Crucified. And I know that tribu-
-lation worketh faith, & faith patience &c. Although I
am a shairer with Job. yet will I not part with my inte-
-grity while I die. Indeed I hope by these afflictions
to be the more benifitted, in the true excersises of those
Graces he bestowed in mercy, & by the falshoods &
cruelty of men be the stronger fixed upon God alone.
learning the Counsel of the wise man in Ecllet. 27th v. 1, 2d, 3
where he describes the propertie of a false friend. saying
Every friend saith, I am his friend also: but there is a
friend only in name. 2 v. Is it not a grief unto death
when a companion & friend is turned an Enimie. v 3.
O wicked imagination, whence camest thou in to cover the
Earth with deceipt:

4 There is a companion; which rejoyceth in the prosperity of a
friend: but in the time of trouble will be against him.
Beware of a counseller, & know before what he needeth.
for he will counsell for himself. lest he cast lot against thee
And say unto thee, thy way is good: & afterwards he
stand on the other side, to see what will befall thee.
Had the profession of Religion in these Parties, bin reall
they could not have dealt thus treatcherously, both as to
the heareing. & consealing my wrongs, (in her own bosom)
, & not only so, but made it her business of examina
tion amongst the servants of the house, how to scrue out
any sircumstanciall passages, were they never so
harmlesse & innocent in themselves that the instruments of the Devill wicked
-ly perverted not to their own advantage. & corupt hearts
charged with mallice & hipocrisie; who being Evil
themselves; & reproved by me for their imodest cari-
age; had set their inventions on work, how to abuse
my innocency in others oppinions, when their own con-
siences Could not but bear wittnese against themselves
of my chaste & virtuous behavour in my life & conversation
249
amongst them. Nor can it be imaginable; that one whose
heart God had framed so tender, even as I may say
& I hope with out boasting (like Josiahs); sanctified from
his youth accustomed with the fear of the Lord; & trained
up in the Schoole of a Crucified saviour; with abundance
of Afflictions & trials. being fearefull of the least sin
either in, Children, or servants, or indeed any that might
indanger the soul of all People under my Care or
Roofe. That I say, such a heart should be abandoned by
God, or prone of it self to doe any thing unseemly the
Laws of Morallitie or divinitie is very strange Nay I must with all hu-
militie accknowledge the Gift & Grace from God. and with
an unfeined gratitude to his majesty; who hath made
me even from my Youth to abhorre; not only the acts of
these natures. but all inclinations: tendances, or Complian
ces; which might defile the body; or Polute that Precious Soul
Reedemed at so dear a Rate, as by the blood of the Eternal
Son of God. who hath commanded us. be yea holy as I am
Holy: Possessing our vessells in holiness & Righteousness
for ever. And must declare that it has bin my dailie studie
& indeavours to aime at that perfection which is commanded
us. be yea perfect as my heavenly Father is perfect: not
that I dare to imagine tis possible to attaine that full perfecti
on in this life so weak & fraile; yet I follow after, if that
I may possiblie obteine that for which I am aprehended of Christ
Jesus: All though. I daily cast my self down at the foote
stoole (in the true sence of my own unworthinesse;) of Christ
Jesus acknowledging with St Paull though I know nothing by
my self yet am I not thereby Justified. And when I have
don all I can: I am but an unprofittable servant.

Neither would I have presumed to have spoke so much up
pon this subject were I not compelled to set forth Gods Glory
in my preservation & innocency: in the vindication of my
Life from all malicious imputations cast upon me. And
I know that St Paull; when he was dispised spoke more of himself
then otherwise he would have don; And I hope to leave these
lines as a justification of my innocency & integrety:
250
For the instruction of my dear Children; For whose saks
I may say these sufferings has in part befallen me.
By my great care & sedulity: how to Establish for their
future subsistance. Education, in the true faith: & Preser-
-vation from Ruin: which fears too much lead me to dout
since all our Estate was settled for Debts &c.

Nor was Mrs Danby ignorant of the causes of all my sorr-
owes. I having imparted to her the knowledge of our Conserns
Had her Charity bin as much towards the Preservation of
my hon.or untucht in it's Roote & branches, as mine was
to Releive her self under my Roofe by all imaginable
kindnessees & respects: And to have declared what she
had heard, to my self whose Eares was ever ready to hear
her discourse) instead of telling her stories, (or Rather)
forgeries of her Maid & others to my brother Denton.
I had not bin so irreparably abused: but have found
out a way to have righted my self long before I came to
the knowledge of being wronged.

But yet even this particular passage of revealing those
lies to my Brother. wee had too much cause to thinke them to have bin don
out of Polocie against me; & insinuation to him. It did by
the mercy of God prove a greater Argument, of my wrong
and abuses; to him who had bin a dailie wittnese of my
carriage for many years together. & thos many things which
I was charged with (as crimes) he himself had bin made known
to, in every respect; & justified such actions against
my accusers: he being extreamly greived for my suffer
ings. & a faithful friend in my adversittie.

Having bin privie to all transactions of our private con-
-serns & writings; which was not fit to publish to strangers
or servants: & yet the nature of envy is such to make
that evil which they cannot understand. And surely these
People envied me either a being in this world: or the grace
of God in my actions; who maliciously invented Prod-
igeous lies. & fomented them under the pretext of an
hon.orfor my person;

Neither could I be informed of such slanders against
me till by Mrs Danbys maides taking an occasion to fall
out with me about the dressing the Chamber when it was very
foule: she being in that womans place which they pretended
had first raised those lies; And desiring to have bin in my
own maides place; sought an occasion to undermine her
of that place; or else to give me warning to provide for one
in hers: having a desire to be at liberty; which I was not un
willing to in regard of my self: but because I kept her with
me till my Nece Danby was resettled in her own house, &
then she was to go with her. & to have don Mrs Danby a
kindness in it: But on the contrary; it proved an infortu
-nate act. by reason of their disgusts both of the mistresse &
servant against my self & family. yet it was the occa-
-sion that brought these misteries of forgeries to my knowledge
The maid telling me that she could tell me who had abused
& wronged me in my Family; but not unlesse she went a-
way for making a mischeife as she called it.

Upon which words I told her; that I should have bin beholden to
her if she knew I was wronged, & to let me know by whom
but she said, no not unlesse she went a way. I said it was
very hard if I could not be informed of the injury was don with out
she went away: & I would be determined by her mistresse.
So finding her mistresse in the same humour having agreed to
gether that I should not be righted by them unlesse she went a
way. it troubled me much to see such dealing. as also that I
was abused, as was pretended by others; when as she which
was my friend should had; consealed the matter, to make her
own advantage against me. Nor should I have bin told
any thing to have righted my self at all. if her maids
quaraling unjustly had not produced this effect.

What was the cause of these proseedings. God knowes for I
had not given either of them just occasion whom I had treated
like sisters in my house, but it was disernable. that some
sinister end was at the botome & not out of Love to the truth
or me that things was thus ordered.

When I perceavd my self thus usued: rather then I
could indure to lie under wrongs, and of what nature I
knew not; nor how to come to understand them I told them
that Barbara might doe as she pleased. if she did not like
my service she was free to please her self. though I could
bin glad she would stay while her mistris stayed. Upon this
she was resolved to go away. but I earnestly desired
her mistres would give her leave to tell me. how I was ab
used & by whom. that I might not still continue so. & I
should have bin obleiged to her if she would have told me
of it her self upon the account of freindship.

But Mrs Danby carried so infinitly high & strangly
because her maid was to go from her that I got nothing
but scornes upon my intreaties, which much amazed me:
Although she gave me possitive warning to provide telling
me she would not stay any longer. To what hight then was
these persons comed: who did not sticke to affirme I turnd
her off. & not she me. which I have witness of. but to lay it on me
Munday the 20th of July was the day apointed upon my
intreaty to be informed by them of my wrongs: which indeed
had near, have bin my last in this life falling out of
my perfect health, into a very dangerous sickness, on
the occasion of sudden & violent grief & terror, which
I was seized upon, in Mrs Danbys Chamber at Newton
being most straingly surprised at Barbaras accusation
before my face of my servant Hanna Ableson for telling
her several stories from another servant, very great
lies & fallshoods against my self. of such a nature as
I did abhorre & much unbecoming any to hear & not to
haue acquainted me with at first that I might have brought
that person to condigne punisment as Mr Thornton would
have don, if it had bin from her it was laid on: but it
was doubted to be of new invention to have outed this
maid of my favour: who when she heard those horrid
things. did utterly deny them all & cleared her self on
oath; that she never knew nor heard any thing from me
253
in all her life; but what was good, chaste & vertuous. &
that she might as well take away her life by false witness
as wrong both me & her; but Barbara carried her spleene
on so unhansomly with such loud clamors against me &
her unchristianly agravating, accusing. & laughing in
scorne against my Person, & the Hon.or of my Family.

Namly in these words like the (old accuser of the breathren)
that I was naught, my mother, my sister, & all I came on,
& this so imprudently before her mistresse. That I busst
out into an excessive lamentable sorrow. & weeping, with
such exceeding violence. not being able to containe, nor
answer, much saveing that I could rather 1000 times have
lost my life then to be robed of those inestimable Jewells
as the hon.or of my dear & blesed Parents, & friends: And
that I hoped God would judge my cause & theres. against all
these slanders of the Deivills inventions. & it like to have
cost my Life then: had I not had comfort in God, and the testimony
of my own Conscience to bear me witness, of mine &
their innocencys: And I was so highly concerned to hear
those holy persons graves defiled by unjust calumnies which
had they bin nipt in the bud there might have bin redemptn
but from the first raisers, but now they had don me the most
highest act of malice to conseale thes lies which they laid
upon one Mary Breaks, which was gon to Richmond: & they
requited me thus by there abominable abusing my Charity
in releiveing her under my Roofe. Making themselves
instruments in my persecution under pretence of the accu-
sing my maid Hanna. which yet was indeavred to be drawen
into the plotts against me. But these hiest agravations of
miseries don by my own bosome friend, is more treacherous
& ingratefull then I can express. & had almost broke
my heart to be thus dealt with by her that knew my Inocency
which shewes she had a mind to revenge some Peake against
us to hear her husbands family thus abused & satt as
a Judge to condemne but not rightly to determine.

The noyse of this womans Railing against me, my Daughter
Alice & maid. did cause my dear husband come to
254
her dore; & would have broke it open. & have kiked
them both down which had so basely injured and
abused my self & family. but I begged & intreated
him that he would not doe it for my nece had no place
of being: but he was resolved to have her out that had
carried so ingratfully towards me. which had bin a mother
to her at all times; Nay she carried so highly base. that
after I was come out of her Chamber, almost half dead
with sorrow at those lies & the impudence of her slander
ous woman who was set upon my self, my daughter
& maid that she would not bear wittnese as false as
others against me: That they both laughed & Jered
[word] I.e., 'jeered'.
& rejoyced together that they had revenged themselves on
me, & when Naly told Barbara it was not a businesse
to laugh at; basely said again. what caired she it
deserved nought but laughing at: with other oprobrious
Skoffing languages; which caused abundance of grief in
my poor innocent Child; who was persecuted by these
People as well as the Mother.

And all this was don because they failed of there unjust
designs; that nought else would sattisfie but a revenge
that might remaine to all Posteritie to blaspheame the honour
& good fame of those, which they both did avouch even in
their madnesse, they could not charge us with any thing
Upon my charging of Mrs Danby at that time & her maid
to show what she had seen or known of me of that nature
they solomnly cleared us them selves never to have seen
or heard any thing them selves: but laid those lies on
others: It was then more sin & shame for them to wrong
me in that & either to believe, or keep it in their breasts;
contrary to their own knowledge: & now to be excecu
-tioners after 7 or 8 months consealment, of others deaths.

And under (a pretence (which was hardly gained tto) instead
of healing those wounds of others; they rejoyced to have
such a poisoned Arrow to wound my afflicted despised
Soul with, which Mrs Danby knew so innocent & tender in that
(it was worse then death): And then to rejoice at my deplor-able
255
Condition. which I was brought into thereby, in there abominable
behaviour against me; which yet deservd the curtosie of a christia
nay of poor Prisoner; not to be accused; condemned, & ex-
cecuted before a just & legall hearing. And that by such who
could not Charge me with the guilt of such accusations.
If Heaven dealt no better with the most righteoust upon the
Earth; there would be non saved at that great day: but
we know that Judge determines just Judgement. with out
Partialitie with out hipocricie; envy, or malice. all which are
the Badges of the father of lies, (Who) if we heire set our
selves to fight under Christs banner, bidding him defiance
not be subject to his temptations & wickednesse. will surly
Raise a mist, to interrut
[word] SiC ??? i.e., interrupt. our Peace; & hinder our Progresse
to heaven. which if he prevail in he has don his work &
we are ruined: but if the old serpent cannot prevail. yet
there shall not be lefft one stone unturnd to make us mise
rable. Neverthelesse, though my Enemies desires, was,
& their secretts intents might endeavour to that End:

yet he that is the Keeper of Israell, & neither slumbers, nor
sleepes. which saw the inward motions & thoughts of my
heart knew my life free from, & innocent of any such
evils; but on the contrary what sorrows of ??? I sustaind
many wayes for the good & relief of my husband & Children

The establishment of his word & gospel; with other honnest
vertuous & laudable deisgnes begged of him to be full-
filled in his due time. that I might end my bones in peace
having taken care for those I ought in duty; He did I
say please to let me find favour in my dear husbands
sight who knew my designs. & all other Good Peoples.
so that I hope God will preserve his servants from that sin of
false accusing, judgeing, or beleiving any of these things
against me. But I was wonderfully Cleared from all such
wrongs by all my servants in my family.

For it was my desire that my brother Denton would. call
them before him; examining each of them perticulerly, what
they could say of my actions at any time. charging them
to speak the truth; Upon which action; they did every one
of them declaire upon their oaths that they never
256
In all there lives saw, nor heard any thing from me
but what tended to the good of there souls: & that if they
should say any bad of me; they should dishonour God
& wrong me And pull a currse on themselves knowing
nothing of me but Civill & honest: & that they were not
worthy to live that spoke otherwise of me. saying more to this
purpose: And they were all greived to see me in that
lamentable condition for those lies against me; And did
desire that I would not believe any ill of them for they
had never said such things; nor ever would while they lived
nor had they ever seen any uncivill action or word from
Mr Comber in there lives. but blessed God for his ministry.
After which examination, it was observd that Mrs Danbys
intentions was not to have my innocency cleared soe-
much as to have her Maides words justified In her accu-
sation. but my gracious God dealt more mercifully with me
in proveing me of all the servants; which dusrt
[word] Sic ??? i.e., durst. not avouch
so abominable falshoods:

But let all be rightly determined : whether it was not
of pure revenge after the march to Hooly, & her lossing
her expectations of this man: That should harbour so
damnable a Plott against our innocent lives in this way.
to be even with him & me: whom because he could not be
with drawen from my daughter in marriage. & which she knew
was then in agitation as well as my brother Denton: Thus to
requite us both. & with one sling to kill two birds
By that to make the world be-leive what a bad Person I was
to marry my Child to such an one if it had bin true.
And yet surely for all her side blowes in the fomenting of
those lies purposly to mischeive me: yet she confest she
had heard them long before she went to Hooly. Then could
she not possibly believe them: because she had such strong
indeavours to haue this Gentleman married to her sheife
[word] I.e., chief.
& Excellent friends: whom she strongly wooed him for.
which was an undeniable argument that both our injurys
& wrongs were grounded upon some other grounds then
truth. And will I hope at last produce a better effect
257
in her even of repentance, for all my grand indignitys
don against me upon all accounts. All though that can be
little satisfaction as to the reparation of my honor & good
Name thus injuriously blasted by her & other instruments
As also the dishonour don to God, in the abusing his of his minister
Whose Person she has so justified & admired; ever s
since she knew him: And recomended him but lately before
for her Cosen as a most vertuous Person.

And full well she knew my care for the disposall of my Child
to such when I did often tell her that I would marrie my
Children to their graves before I would doe it to any man & was given to vicious humors. & chose this man in confidence of being free from such
And now I am to take notice of the grand mercies of my
God that would not let me perish through the evil imagination
of those that rose up against me, but after an unmeasurable
Portion of sorow & grief having kept my bed 14 days, weak
& feeble through the exceeding pains of the mother & spleene
& other sicknesses thereon: yet at length he raised me
up again, giving me a great Comfort in my dear Aunt
Nortons company. who hearing of my sad misfortune &
weakness came to put a stop to my troubles. The Lord God
seeing my intentions Cordially good: would not suffer me
to fall. but gave me relief in his providence: & by the satt-
isfaction received in my good friends had an opportunity
to give a full account of my innocency yet they did
not question. nor believe any of those slanders. but when
they perceived how I had bin used, was very much troubled
for my sufferings indevouring to comfort my spirit so
disconsolate. I will therefore humbly acknowledge the
goodness & assistance of God in my suports, of my good
friends; when I was. in deep distress. through the mischevi-
esness of a false Tounge; many innocent has lost their lives
& I am sure this had well night taken myne. taken with all
its sircumstances. lieing under the scourge of secret malice
with out the least provokation or desert: then to have my
friend to turn an unjust enimiey: through whose
treacherous compliance I was the deeplier wounded. when
She knew all my Life; & that my endeovrs
[word] SiC ??? i.e., endeavours. was for the
258
Establishment of this poor family in truth & holiness
& that even then; when all was hatched against me. with what
sorrow & affliction I lived in upon the greifes for my dere
husbands weakness. & the troubles of his Estate. God knows
but I leave her to the just, Judge & comitt my cause to
his holy determination before whose Tribunall we must
all apeare. And whose dread I set before my Eyes from
my youth: & whose mercy has never left me, never since
I was borne, but he has kept me from the strivings of the
ungodlie: I may say as hana did, Talke no more so ex
ceeding proudly, let not Arrogancy proceed out of your
mouth. for the Lord is a God of knowledge; and by him
actions are weighed.

Well might this good woman say so; which was wronged
in the opinion of Eli and accused to be drunke. but she
said no my Lord. thinke not thy servant a daugher of
beliall: I am a woman of sorrowfull spirit.

And even thus was I, a poor helplesse creature. having
great burdens & temporal afflictions on me wrongfully abused
for the discharge of my duty, as a faithful wife; a m'ther
& mistresse in my house; as this hanna which praie'd for a
Son. And as the Lord did free this woman from the suspition
of that sin: so I hope he will doe for me. which has never don
no more either possitively, or intentionally, to deserve these
slanders. my soul being imployed & desires more for the
things of another life then this. & how to meete my dearest
Saviour with a pure & holy heart;

Such was my dear Aunts care & charitable affection towards
me. seeing me in such a deplorable a condition of weakness
& grief for these infinit wrongs & slanders; that she see
I did not take any comfort in my life. & that I could not
sleep but still the frights & terrour seized upon me, as if
those 2 persons which so abused me were standing ready to teare
my Eyes & as I fancied in my dreams would have killd me;
so grand an apprehension, I had of those words & actions I
have related: That my dear husband & my Aunt thought
there was almost no way left Left to take.
259
how to preserve my life; which was brought into a second hazard
by Mrs Danbys Repettions of her Maids slanders to my Aunt
Norton: indevouring by that to clear her own unworthinesse to
-wards me & base abuess of Mr Comber. causing my maide hana
to be arrained before my Aunt & herselfe to avouch the old lies
& new ones freshly invented: But hana was still so farr
from acknowledging them. That she did attest the falshood of
them all with great ingidnity
[word] Sic ??? i.e., indignity. & told her she did endevour
to make her guilty of those lies & abominable slanders that
she vowed before the Lord she was innocent of. That she might
make her guilty of her mistresses murder & damne her own
soul. & that she would vindicate me to her death, being the best
& chastestest woman in the world: & could not prevail with all
her threats against her. When my Aunt perceived her malice
she told her that she did not deserve what I had don for her in
all things which she had heard from her self: And although she her
self did witness me to be wronged. it was a signe she would
faine have some occasion against me were it never so unjust

And after wards: upon her telling her that my husband desired
she should prepaire her self to go from hence. & that I would
procure her a coach if she pleasd to go any whither amongst
her friends: Upon which she said I promised to keep. her & she
would not go out of this house. But my Aunt told her if
I did so. the more unworthy wretch was she that had so abused
me, & to this purpose (the innocentest & faithful friend she had.)
At length my good Aunt so ordered the business that she named
a day for her going; & there was a coach procured from Madam
Grahme: my noble friend; which carried her to Yorke with 2
servants to waite on her. being on friday the 11th of sept. 68.

At her departure I gave her to suplie her necessities 3l more
to the former 5l sent to her: she having had out of my Purse
the year about 20l in all with charges about her Jorneys, &
all suplies of Linnin & other necessarys.

I was exceding weak in bed when she went. nor did I hope to
recover either health or strength again had it not bin out of the
infinite Riches & goodness of my gracious God; which wrought
miracles on me his faithful innocent handmaid.
260
In giving me the praises & tears, comforts & assistances of
my dear husband & Aunt, with my good brother Denton & all
other of my faithful friends. who could not be but convincd
of those horible wickednesse in these passages related. &
all endevoured my restoration again: that my Life might
be spared to give Glory to the God of my salvation.

One passage more must not be forgotten which my brother Dent
And Aunt was witness of that Mrs Danby beleiving as she
said me, & Mr Comber to be wronged: did solmnely sweare
to them that she would never open her mouth against us
of any thing while she breathed: & since she went away
has endevoured to be reconsiled to me again that she might
enjoy the same privileges as before.

But surely neither Gods Law, nor mans. can obleige me
to entertaine those parties; which has so highly sinned a-
gainst both. for those wounds are incurable which she gave
& will not leave me to my Grave. Let no good Christian
taxe my Charity. the Sins were of such a nature against my
hon.or & Families; that it would confirme those lies which has bin
Against me. And a great dishonour of God & christian Relig
-ion: & therefore not of that private concern, with in the verge of
my private Charity. as of a petty particular injury.

Nor would I for the world, Patronise any thing of this nature
who has so clear a conscience towards God & man.
nor open the mouths of the wicked justly; against the Person of
those of whom I know no evil.

In this I will not faile that my Prayers may be heard for her
true & unfeigned Repentance: that God may pardon those
great & high indignities against, him self, the truth & us
together with all others contributaries, in this Tragiedie
Least they perish in there iniquities.

div.head:
P
Upon my lamentable abuses of false slanders raised
against me. July 20th 1668.
div.p:
O: Lord God, who hearest the Prayers of them that call upon thee
in their calamities and distresses, have mercy upon me
thy weak & afflicted hanmaid & servant.
261
overwhelmed with the stormes of ungodly & wicked doers
whose tongues are like rasiers; sharpe as a two edged sword
Deliver my Soul, O Lord, from lying lips: and from deceit
full tongues which have not God all ways before their Eyes
Lo O Lord they have laine in waite for my Soul. so mall-
iciously were they set against me. And false witness did
rise up: they laid to my charge things that I knew not.

With the flatterers were bussie mockers: which gnashed upon me with
there teeth. They gaped on me with there mouths: & scorne
was in there hearts. Lord how long wilt thou look upon this
O deliver my Soul from the Calamities which they bring on me:
& my darling from the instruments of the Lion and Dragon
Awake & stand up to judge my cause & stand on my side
which am opressed for thy sake. avenge thou my Cause, my
God & my Lord. Make them be asshamed for all those injuri
-ous practices & false accusations against thy innocent
servant: that the Proud doe me no wrong. Judge me, O Lord my
God according to thy mercy & Righteousness. & according to
the cleannesse of my heart in thy eyesight. O let not there
mischeivous imaginations prosper against me least they be
to proud. let them not triumph against my soul. for thou only
searchest & triest the thoughts. neither let them triumph over
me for I am thy servant & humble creature redeemed by thy
Precious blood. I beeseech thee O Lord let not their lieing
slanders prevaille to make me miserable, either to blemish
my Person family or Posterity. For thou knowest that against
these People have I don no wrong, that is risen up against me
but allwaies ready to releive there necessitys & wants. And lo
now they take my contrary part. let not there imaginations
prosper because I put my trust in thee. Plead thou my cause
O Lord with them that strive with me: & fight thou against them
that fight against me & persecute me: say unto my soul
I am thy salvation, Yea O Lord our God, who art the sheild of
the oppressed & wronged. the buckler of all that trust in thee. de
liver us from all the assaults & intendments of our secret malicius
Enimes against us, who with out cause make pitts for our souls
let the Angell of the Lord scatter all mischeivous immaginations
least they triumph over us & say, we have devoured them.

Strive thou with them that strive with us, and fight against
them that fight against us. Preserve us still our inno-
cency that we sin not against thee, nor doe injustice to
them, & restore me to thy peace again. which these People
has seeked to disturbe even the preservation of that mercy
which thou didst give me, that fame of precious oyntment
before thee, all my days, if it be thy blessed pleasure too
give me that comfort. but if otherwise it seeme good to thy
wisdom. yet let me still remaine thine in all afflictions &
trials retaining a pure mined in an Chaste body that I may
tread the steps of my dearest saviour. & daily take up his
Cross & follow him. Thou hast never failed me o my God
even when I was in deep distress & anguish of soul & Spirit

All which I take as grand suports of my heart & incoura-
gments to serve the Lord with all my ??? who hath never failed
nor forsaken his weak handmaid destitute & despised.
I know O Lord thou both canst, & dost me good by this heavy
& sad affliction, as well as by the rest of thy chastisments
Teach me O Lord heereby not to rest upon the Arme of flesh
& pardon my too much relieing upon this worldly freindship
when I should have had thee my only counseller.

Let me be the better by thy Rod, in the scourge of wicked Toungs
who although they may seeke occasion to slay me & Roote
out the remembrance of me from the Earth. yet let them not
prevaille. for though they currse yet bless thou. & behold
the anguish of my soul: for out of the deepes have I called
Lord save me I perish if thou hearest not.
But still will I hold me fast by God my saviour for my
guide & direction support & deliverance. puting my trust
in thee O Lord, my strength. O stablish & settle my ??? in
thy faith, fear & love, that neither life nor death may
seperate me from the Love of God.

And blessed be thy holy name that hast still preserved my
dear husbands love & affection intire to me all my life.
And I desire humbly to acknowledge thy infinit goodness
to me that did so. for it was not in the power of these wicked
(Toungs though indevoured to doe it) to shake or remove those
Christian, faithful, & conjugall bonds of intire and.
263
dearest affections betwixt us. Thou O Lord having given
us thy grace uniting our ???s in that holy band of marriage
wherein we lived. both of us hateing the very mention off all
such vilde abominations as this world was too full of
but blessed be thy mercy & grace of our good God whom we
serve day & night for making us live in this holy band of
above this 16 years. having this to comfort of our ???s that
we are his undefiled servants, faithful to each other. desiring
to follow Christ in the Regeneration. & receive the Crown of a
sanctified wedlocke with him in Glory

Lord bless my dear husband, who thou hast given me. with
a long & comfortable life. with the hapie opportunity of his
Children's religious Education. & if it be thy pleasure to see
there disposall in marriage to the intrest of true Religion.
That they may be thine in life and death. And now behold I have
taken upon me to speak unto the dreadful God of heavn & Earth
Lord make my soul for ever thankful to the most high God
which hath had regard to his poor weak, humble servant.
what am I that thou should have given me such testimonys
of thy favour to support my soul in all calaminities & that
thou hast given me part of the bitter cupe of my saviour
to drinke. Lord uphold me in it: let it not crush me to destruction
but to mendment of any iregularitys of my fraile life.

And I will give thee the Glory of thy works of mercies & favours
for ever. I most humbly beg on the account of my Christs
Intercession that I may have the grace of perserverence, & truly
thankful ??? to walk worthy of these inestimable mercies
& glorify thee in the midest of all my trials & sufferings.
making a way for me to Escape. I will magnify thee Lord
most high & Praise his holy name. besech thee that I may at
last be delivered from the scourge of evil Toungs. & that by a
holy & Pieious life I may show my gratidute to thy majesty
& ever rejoice in thy salvation. And I beseech thee so to order
to the circumstances & opportunitys of my life. that I may
live in the society of holy People. quiet & Peacable. in righteousnes
& truth for Jesus Christs his sake. to whom with the father & holy
spirit be all Glory. Power dominion & praise for ever more.
Amen.

div.head: My son Robert Thornton preserved July: 25 1668.
div.p:
It pleased God to give my sweete Robin Thornton a very
great deliverance upon the 25 of July. In his play with
his Sister Kate & cosen willy Denton standing in the wind-
-ow in the Hay laith at Newton, which is above 4 yeards from
the Earth. he fell down in to the laine. near a great stone
which if he had light on might have killed him falling so
high. so that the danger was very great. & his deliverance also
& ought to be haad
[word] SiC ??? i.e., had. in remembrance with gratitude and
hearty thanks to the God of Heaven, which sent his Angell to
preserve my poor Child from death, or any harm save
a lumpe on his face.

The Glorious name of Jehovah, be praised & magnified
for his Life & the Preservations thereof from all casulties
, dangers, Sicknesses. dislocations. & Evils. And giving
him a compotent shaire of understanding, witt: memory
a loving & affable nature. with several other good guifts
tending to the accomplishment of his Person with naturall in-
dowments. but I doe adore the Lords name & mercy which
hath begun some dawning hopes of his grace in his heart
Appearing in his being affected with good instructions in the
knowledge & fear of God. & his desire to be informed of all
things concerning God. with notions of fear in hearing his
Judgments. with several pathaticall expressions of god &
his wayes. one day being about 4 years old he told me
of his own acord: That God was a pure, holy, wise,
& merciful Spritt. But the Deivill was a wicked lieing
malicious Spritt. was it not better to believe this holy
good God & serve him. then that wicked Evil Spirit which
would destroy us.; I must therefore with humble gratitud
take notice with comfort in his mercy which did not dispie the
prayers of his handmaid but given me a gracious answer
to my humble suplications, when I wanted a son. for this
blessing I begged of the Lord as Hanna did Samuell. And
has dedicated him to his service even all his days. further
craveing the continuance of his favour & Grace of his Spritt
upon my Sonn. Endowing his ??? from his Childehoode with all
Christian virtues, faith knowledge wisdom. & true under
standing. to guide & direct
265
him in his youth to his riper Age to follow him. & walk
in his wayes with a perfect heart even to his lives end.

Preserve him from the sins, & vanities, follies, evil inclinations
either of custome. Examples. or naturall habitts. which might
staine or polute his soul in thy sight. And from all temporall
Evils so far as shall seeme fit in thy wisdom to give him.
And finaly I beseech thee preserve him from Eternal
sorow & misery in the world to come. Thus consigning
this my child as a blessing to his Family. comfort to his
weak mother, & Relations. & an instrument of the Glory
of thee his Creator, in this Life. serving thee faithfully in
this generation in righteousness. And at the last may Joy-
fully praise thee in Heaven. All which I most humbly &
heartily beg for the lone sake of our dearest Lord & saviour
Jesus Christ his holy son. Amen & Amen.

div.head:
A relation of the Last sickness, and Death of my
dear & hon.red husband Will.m Thornton Esquire who
departed this life at Malton Sept. 17th 1668.
div.p:
While I am in this Vaile of Tears, & shaddow of Death
I must not desire, nor expect more comforts of this Life
& temporal mercies; then will preserve me from sinking
in sorrow, or despaire under the Cross. Even that shaire was
denied my Saviour the Captaine of our Salvation. when
he fainted under it. & almost dispaired by the sadder
loads of our Sins. well may I miserable Creature, take
up his Cup & pledge his love with love again. his Life
here had little, or no mixture, but gall & bitternesse. I
have the beames of his sweet influences. injoying some tim
the Sun shine of his favours behind the clouds of dispaire
& afflictions: fare be it from me to repine at the great &
wise disposer, the Lord of Heaven & Earths most infinitly
wise disposittion, or to grudge at his dealing with me. for
here I am Lord make me thine & doe what thou willt with
me either for life or Death. The Lord best knowes how to
propose & intermix Crosses with Comforts. Smiles with frownes.
266
To his Servants here as shall be the best for them in
proportion to their Etternal Happiness And not as they shall
thinke Fit, which are but of yesterday, but himself, who
sees not as man sees. having all things in Omnipotent
& Omnicient Power. and shall tend most to his own
Glory. & divine gracious pleasure.

No Sooner was my strength in part recruited, begin-
ing to return again After my dear Aunt Nortons
departure home. & my dear husbands going that day to
Mallton. when I was so weak that I kept my bed a week
before & since her going away. so about the 14th day of
september they going a way upon the 11th I got up beginning to
rejoice at my deliverance from the late weakness & ill-
-nesse both of the Plague of Slanderous Tounges & the
faintings abated something after Dafeny Lightfoote
came to see me.

But on that day when first I Arrose out of bed. I had the
sad newes of my dear & tenterly loving husbands
falling sick at Mallton brought to me in a letter to my
Brother Denton. Which so sudainly surprised my spritt
yet exceeding weak. That I fell to a great trembling
with excessive grief. & fears upon me for his life, and
safty. so that I went sick thereupon to my sorrowfull bed
Immediately Sending for Dr wittie to come to him. each
day & night posting thither to let me know how he did.

Nor could I possibly with out the loss of my life be carried
to see him albeitt they could not keep me from him till I
was brought so feeble by reason of an other accident
that befell me in my grief then was the grandest affliction
upon my heart that could be. under which I had surely
fainted as it was my desire rather then to have lost
my Joy & comfort; had not the Almighty Power & mer
cy of God miraculously upheld my spirit from sinking

On wednesday I sent my Brother Denton & Mr Comber
to my dear Joy at Malton. longing all that day to hear
from him, still earnestly desiring to have gon my self
but my friends would not let me. for fear of my.
267
Poor & miserable Life which yet I despisd in comparison
of him; so with much impatience. great fears, & some hope
I waited till night, when word was brought
me from Dr wittie
That I should be of good cheare & not cast away my Life
for I should have my dear husband home as well, as ever
I had him in my life.

So that I endeavoured to comfort up my hopes in God, the
Almightie. whose Power was infinite as his mercy &
sweetest Cleamency to us his poor Servants had bin often
showed. And powred out my Prayers & Tears abundan-
-tly that night. for the preservation of the Life & health of my
dear Husband with me. If it were the good will & plea-
-sure of our God. that the dear & sweet union & affectin
intire in our lives together: might not be broke. nor we
seperated by death. from the injoyment of each other. in him
If this might stand with the gracious pleasure of our gratious
God I made these. the requests of my soul to him.

That night was spent in somme little Slumbers but very
unquiett & full of fears trimblings & sad apprehensions
In the morning my Brother Denton came home & very
discreetely prepared me with good advice & counsel to
entertaine the Lords determinate will in all things with
Patience & submittion. If the worst should fall upon me
according to my fears. But with all said that God could raise
My Dearest Joy up again were he never so weak, as I
had Experience of. if he see it fit for us. Although indeed
my dear heart was then very weak. At which words my
faintings renewed with my exceeding sorrows for the fears of
being deprived of this my Sole delight in this world next
under God. The Lord pardon my impatience in this concern.
which had for the 3 last past years, bin weaning him, & my self
from this world, through great & manifold tribulations.

Thus betwixt hopes & fears I remained till the next messen-
-ger came. at 4 a clock on Thursday in the affternoone. at which
time I received the sad newes (for me) of my most Tirrable
Loss that any poor woman could have in being deprived of my
Seewet,
[word] Sic ??? i.e., sweet. & exceeding dear husbands Life.

Such was the violency of prevailing passion, & affliction
upon this change That I was almost changed with him
& ready to go into the grave. that as we had lived in holy
marriage almost 17 years, so I might be his faithful
spouse in life & death. Great was my sorow & extre-
-amity which had endured many sharpe Arrowes from the
Lord. but this exceeded the rest of all temporal losses. Crosses
& sorrows that ever befell me. Now being under a fresh
gaile of stormes & tempests. Bereaved of my head &
husband, my guide & support in this life left to be ttosed
with the waves of sorrows & billowes of sadnesse & discont
ent that usually attends the disttressed Estate of a discon-
-solate widow.

Oh the Lord has broken in upon me like a mightiey water
And powred upon me his indignation. great are my Cal-
Amities & temporal troubles. my Cup is full. with most
sad complaints may I bewaile. being bereaft of A most
dear & tender. vertuous & loving husband. which took
part with me all in my sorrows & sufferings. comforted me
me in sadnesses. we walked together. in dear love & union
his love was mine & I was his in sickness & health. & in his
sufferings I was afflicted how can it be that I can subsist
after his loss. O my Eyes run down with tears night &
day for the loss of this my Earthly delight. he being gon to
to our Heavenly Father has left me to lament his loss
from me & his poor fatherlesse Children. Weak in body
afflicted in Spirit. lowe in Estate. losses in my dearest
friends & Relations & Children. with the departure of other
comforts as dear as my life it self, And now to consumate
my full measure. my dearest Joy, here is with drawne

Oh that my sorrows were weighed. & that the Lord would
pittie my distress. I am still thy creature O Lord by Creation
Redemption. preservation. sanctification & suportation
from the Jawes of hell & the Grave.

Doe not despise thy handiworke. for thou didst make me.
I am thine. O give me understanding. to hear thy heavy
269
Rod & who that sent it. Let it be thy pleasure. since thou
still givest me life. that it may be for a blessing. giving me
understanding to serve thee with a perfect heart & willing
mind. to hear the Rod & who hath sent itt. is there any Evil
in a Cittie & the Lord has not don it. Is there not an appointd
time for man once to die. Oh that I may daily die to sin & live
in righteousness with God in Soul & Siritt
[word] SIC ??? i.e., spirit. loving him with
all my soul. I must be still. & know that it is God that ruleth
in Heaven & Earth. The Lord is his Name. & his mercy
is showed unto us. yea even in this his Vissittation. There
fore will I lay my mouth in the dust with humble submission
Considering that what ever he doeth is good.

Had he not in much mercy drawne my dear Joy to him
self & fitted him for this dissolution. he remembring the Lord
in the days of his youth & God I hope was found of him.
What although I now doe want those good & Pious prairs
which he put up for me & mine many years enjoyed from him
the benefit of. yet I will trust holy upon the sole mediation and
intercession of our blessed Christ. who ever livs to make in-
tercession for his widow & Orphans. And yet such is my
frailtie. if a deep affection be termed so that I can say
nothing but puts a fresh remembrance. & brings a new flood of
Tears. which I water my Couch with all & widdowed disconsolate
bed, for my self & Children. And yet my thinke I hear
him say as our Saviour to the women that wept after him.
weepe not for me me (that am now in Joy & bless) but weepe for
your self & little ones. I was in the world tormented with
pains. Crosses. losses sickness troubles on every side. But
now I am comforted in the bosome of my Father & thy father
which I longed after: & so shalt thou in his good time.
Is there not then no means to aswage thy immoderate grief
for this sad seperation. O yes. there is hope in the later end.
what although my poor ??? thou art deprived of his presence
doest thou not believe in God. that those Shall be blessed that believe
in him, & by the miritts of his redeemer he now injoyes the
incomprehensable Joys of the great God of Heaven. where all
Tears is wiped off from his eyes. all sorrows is departed from
him. & he is delivered from this Body of Death.

Oh my Soul let his hapinesse mittigate thy sorrows in his loss
270
Considering that what he now injoyes he would not Exchange.
for ten thousands worlds. & thy present loss is his Eternall
advantage. as St Paull saith for me to live is Christ but
to die is gaine. O desire to be made happy with him in the
Resurection. when we shall apeare together & be clothed
with Immortality, injoying the fruittion of that God head
as David Sayes in thy preasence is fullness of Joy. & pleasur
at thy right hand for ever more.

And I may say with Job. Although wormes consume this
body: yet with my Eyes shall I see God & beholding him
face to face. which this clayie body of dust cannot enjoy in
this vaile of flesh. till this vilde body be changed & made
like his & this mortall put on immortallity.

Oh that the Lord would now give me faith. & show himself to
his weak handmaid & servant making me to believe
what good things is laid up for them that love & fear him
And though great are the troubles of the Righteous here. yet
are they but in order to consigne them to a beter Kingdom
& he will deliver them out of all. Oh doe not then
repine or call in question the mercy & goodness of this
great wise. holy & gracious Father, for if thou belongest to
him he will give thee to know his mind. It is the Lord he
must doe what he will.

Although this dispensation is most bitter, as the cutting of
thy life. be silent, & doe not sin against him by impatience
or resisting his pleasure. has not the heavenly Potter power o-
over our Earthly clay, to doe what seemest him best.

What if flesh & blood cannot part so willingly. Remember
thou must live by faith. & say unfeinedly thy will be don.
in all things if ever thou expect salvation heereafter.
he was prepared for death. Thou art not, perhaps he has
some other work for thee to doe in this troublesom world. Pray
that thou might be assisted to performe his pleasure. and
keep thee in a continuall preparednesse. And that as we did
help in this Life to bear one another burdens. so may we
together Reigne with Christ in Glory who is the Author & finisher
of our faith. Daily panting & breathing after him. to be
271
Clothed upon with the garment of Righteousness & true
holiness. that Death might put on immortality. Spending
a few days here amongst thy Children in Piety & holiness
bringing them up in the fear & nurture of the Lord. That I may
deliver up my Charge to the great God of Heaven of my
Children's Souls he has given me. with Joy & not with grief
according to that saying I, & the Children thou hast given me
will serve the Lord.

That so in the End of my days I may receive the end of my
hope even the Salvation of our Souls. Where there shall be
no sighing. no weeping. for all tears shall be wiped from
our Eyes, to follow the Lambe where soever he goes. There is
love with out dissimulation, & hatred. Joy with out dimuinition
or sorrow: delight & satisfaction with out mixture of passion

The full fruittion of our hopes with out disapointments. Peace
with out anger, or impatience: Envie & hatred shall not enter
there. no caires, fears, or solicitudes shall interrup
[word] SiC ??? for interrupt. our com-
forts, our Beatitude: & that which makes the happenesse compleated
these injoyments are Eternal with out fears of losseing or
shadow of changing. For in heaven we must believe our Saviour
they are as the Angels: nay higher, being drawne nearer to
God united to divine nature in the Person of the word, in that Hipostati
call Union of our nature in Christ, who took upon him:
not the nature of Angels: but he took on him the seed of
Abraham. that he might bee like unto his brethren, that he might
bee a merciful & faithful high Preist. in things pertaining
to God. to make reconsciliation for the sins of the People:
Hebrews 2d v. 16, 17. This Privilidge the sons of men have by the
Second Person of the Blessed Trinitty. Even the Eternal Son
of God Blesed for ever. Shall we preferre drosse above
Gold. & the fading pleasurse of this pittifull life before Etterity
[word] SiC ??? i.e., eternity.
God for bid. let us lay aside all hinderances of this life
striving to fight this Battaile of the Lord being armed with
his weapons as St Paull has taught us against sin the world
& the Devill. for to him that over comes will I give freely to drink
of the waters of Life; And we know that if this Earthy: Taber
nacle be don away. we have a building, not made with hands
271
Eternal in The Heavens, whose Buillder & maker, is
God. O then how shoulld I not groane after, & long to
be cloathed upon. & enjoy that felicitie, & happiness
those Joys & Glory. which I doe hope & believe through
our dear Saviour. That now my dear husband is
made pertaker of in Heaven.

div.head:
Prayers; & Pettions upon this Sad Dispensation
of the death of my dear & hon.red husband.
div.p:
O most great; omnipotent, & everlasting Lord God
which doest what ever thou Pleasest both in Heaven and
Earth. that puttest breath in our Nostrills, & saith unto
man, return again into thy dust again. What am I
a vilde creature. sinful dust & Ashes. that I should take
upon me to speak unto thee, which am not worthy to live
or have my life given me, as at this day. Thou O Lord
art Sufficiently Glorious in thy Self, fearefull in thy Attri
butes, &, Essence without any addittion of us mortalls.
yet it is thy divine pleasure to condesend to our weak
capacities. & require. our uttmost services & obedience
as well active, as passive. I beech
[word] SiC ??? i.e., beseech. thy majesty, since I
am thine in being & existance. to accept the Powrings out
of my Soul in prayers & tears. although exceeding un-
worthy in their selvs, as of poluted & defiled lips, not da-
-ring to presume into thy most Dreadful Presence; for if thou
O Lord should butt marke what is don amisse, Allas
o Lord who is able to abide it. Therefore o grand Soveraine
of our Souls enter not into Judgement with thy servant O
Lord for no flesh is righteous in thy Sight.

But thou hast apointed thy Son Jesus Christ the Righteous
to be a propitiation for our sins in whom thou art well pleased
In whos
most holy & prevailing name. & mirritts I humbly addres
these weak. & imperfect requests. beseeching thee in him to
accept my Person & prayers, purefieing both, by his Precious
& all healing Blood. sed upon the Cross.

I humbly beseech thy Majesty as thou hast given me this
being. in this Earth & contineuing the same thus long. &
hast prolonged my Life, notwithstanding all my unworthines
& sins. That thou willt pardon what ever I have offended
in thy sight ever since I was borne. pittie my infirmitties &
strengthen my weakness, & humaine frailties, heal my
Soul & love me freely make me to understand thy word
& know thee to be a God hearing Prayer, & willt dwell in the
heart of those that are holy & humble, of a contrite heart. &
Trembles at thy word. thy, Power, & Attributes. Give me
grace to Glorify thy name & submitt chearfully to this
heavy dispensation to thy handmaid. serving thee, not
with a slaveish fear. but out of a true obedienciall &
filliall duty. Love & affection, knowing that thou dost not
afflict willingly. but even in this seperation did it (I hope)
for the happienesse of my husband, by freeing him from troubles
And that thou willt thereby drawe me nearer to thy thy self
by setting my affections more on heaven above & not on Earth;
I will also give thee the Glory & praise which hast kept me from
Presumtious sins, giving me a tender heart, (I hope) for the
least offence against thee, That may indanger a seperation
betwixt my Soul & God. O Lord take me now to thy own
more immeadiate keeping & Tuittion, who hast now taken my
head; whom thou gavest to be a comfort & a guide & for whom
I bless thy name, that I enjoyed him so long. And let me not
sin in resisting thy pleasure or disputing thy Providence, who
canst doe all things. I pray thee now O Lord, bless thy
servant in this desolate Condition, whom thou hast let to
see thy various trials & afflictions. & hast bestowed so
much pains upon. here I am: Lord what willt thou have me
to doe. I resigne my will, to thy Glorious pleasure either in
life or death. make me be free from this body of sin & Death.
to serve thee with perfect freedom, of mind will, & affections
that I may be holy in Soul, body & spirit. Though I be sick
let me be sound in thee. Teach me thy Laws, & I shall Live.

O Let my widdowed Condition be a Sanctified Estate.
yea even thou writting upon my heart Holiness unto the Lord
That I may be exempleary in my life & conversation to
thy glory & praise. My Children may be great instruments
of thy praise also. chosen vessells in this crooked Generation
Although my Afflictions be heavy & burdensome to this
weak body. yet I acknowledge them Just, as coming From
thee my strength. my hope. my Joy, & fortresse. who dost
with all make away for me to Escape.

Lord be to thy servant as thou wast unto David. who served
thee with a ready mind. Thou art. the guiver.
The guift is
thy self. O let thy Siritt
[word] SiC ??? i.e., spirit. dwell in me & mine Richly. let
my latter days be still a seperate condition from Evil.
the Evil of sin: & the Evil of punishment as much as thou sest fit
I beseech thee preserve me & my Family from dishonorable
walkeing. leading us in thy ways. & directing us in our
steps. Make me to walk as an Example before them in Grace
Patience, holiness, humblenes Chastietie, Piety, faith & Purity
meekenesse. & Charity. with a suplie of all other Christian
vertues & graces. necessary to lead my life, here & to
make me acceptable in thy sight. & follow my dear savi-or
in this Pilgrimage; towards that Heavenly Jerusalem where
I may forever glorify thy majesty for all. to all Eternity

All these humble requests & Petitions I crave for the only
mirritts & bloodsheding of my dearest Saviour Jesus
the Righteous, who interceadeth for poor sinners at the Throne
of thy Grace, even for me, & all those that love his appearing.
To whom with the Glorious Father & holy Spirit. Ever Blessed
& Infinittly Glorious Trinitty. be All possible praise.
addoration, & thanksgiving of men & Angels. hence forth
& for Ever more. Amen. & Amen.

My dear Husband, went to Malton to my Sister
Portingtons on friday the 11th of September 1668 being
in health much as of late pretty well of his infirmity.
he rid into that fair upon Satterday. to Church on Sunday
274
Upon Munday he was not well, and had Pills given him
as he used to have by my bro. Portington but they did
not work kindly & so had a glister givin him being the
Method ordered by Dr wittie.

On munday he sent for Mr Sinkler. and told him. That
he knew formerly he had bin in much trouble & sadnesse
for his Sins & walked uncomfortably for the want of the
sence of Gods favour, in great fears & doubtings.
But now the Lord was pleased to make himself known
to him to be a reconsiled Father in Christ Jesus. And that
he was at peace with him; he perceaving a great deal of
Joy & comfort inwardly in his soul & mind. Blessing
the Lord for this his infinite mercies. & hoped that he should
bless his name for ever more that he was had bin so troubled
for now he was reconsiled to him again. there, with many
such like expressions. to the great satisfaction of Mr Sinkler
who stayed a good while with him.

Then towards night this sweet Saint of God grew worse
& more heavy & drousie according to that distemper. and
they sent to me for the Dr which came to him on wednesday after
dinner. my dear was then very weak in body. but I
bless God perfect in mind & understanding. Mr Comber
going to see him. he took his leave of him and bid him to
Remember him to his dear wife. bid me be patient &
contented with Gods hand, & to submitt to his will. which he uttrd
as well as he could for his speach being taken. After which he
had his haire taken of by order, being the last remidie. & this
with his own consent. but Alass no remidies, or meadicine
nor Art could prevail. it being the determination of our God
to take him to himself. And yet to mixe this bitter Cup of
Death with the alay of a quiett frame & temper, free from
any torment or signes of pains lieing as if he were in a sweet
sleep. And by degrees growing colder at his feet. & so
dieing upwards, & drawing his breath shorter all the Thursday
morning. And towards Eleven a clock in the fore noone he
Fetcht one litle Sigh and so sweetely resigned up his spirit
in to the hands of his dear Saviour & Redemer Jesus Christ.

He departed on Thursday the 17th of September 1668.
betwixt the howers of 11 & 12 at noone. he being on the 2d
day of June (68) fortey fouer years of Age. we have
ing lived a dear & loving couple in holy marriage almost
seaventeene years.

My dear husbands body was brought home to Easte
Newton on friday the 18th of september in company of many of
our neighbours Gentrey, & other friends those that were about
us, And I did desire that his interment might be deferrd
till we could acquaint our remote friends & relations. But
the Dr told them that he had laid not long sick & taking
of Phisicke would hinder that. Those that were helpers to bear
his Corpes were of his kindred & relations.

My Brother Thomas Thornton, my Brother Denton.
My brother Portington. my Cosen will.m Ascough.
My Cosen Ralphe Crathorne. my Cosen John Craithorne.
My Cosen Bullocke. My Cosen Ed. Lassells.

There was a very great Congregation at that time he being
most generally beloved of his Countrey. A man of great
Piety, Peace. Honesty. There was a great lamentation
for him God having givn him much love & affection.

But my sorrows & laments cannot be weighed for him which
parted with the great & sole delight & comfort I esteed
[word] SIC ??? i.e., esteemed. of my
Life. the Lord grant me some measure of Patience to sustaine
that I may not displease the great Governer of heavn & Earth
but desire to submit for the Lord sake with resignation to his will
& in hopes of a Joyfull Resurection, at the last day, then to
be united in haleluiahs to the God most High. for ever.
My dearst heart was interred in his own Alley at stongrave
Church near his mother & two sweet babes. Christofer
& Joyce. buried on friday the 18th of september betweene 4
& 5. a clock. by Mr Thomas Comber. who Preached his
Funeral Sermon. The Text was in Ecclesiastes 12th v. 1st
Remember now thy Creator in the days of thy youth: &c.
applieing it fittly to that: cccasion.

epigraph.p:
Lord he loves thee the lesse. that loves any thing with
thee, which he loves not for thee. (St Austin).

div.head: The Widdowes Praieer. for her self & Children.
div.p:
O Lord our God, the God of our Salvation, who for our
Sakes wert wounded and didest Die, to Redeeme
our Souls from Hell; And wast pleased to lie in the
Grave, That our Sins might be buried by thee.
by an Act of Oblivion. but thou alone of all that ever died
were free amongst the Dead, to show thy Soveranity
& power over all; and of thy own Power didst arise
again with victory & Triumph over hell & the Grave;
O Powerfull, Allmighty, & Omnipotent Jehova, Look
down from thy Throne of Majesty, & Mercy, with a
gracious Eye of favour & compassion. And behold
me the unworthiest of thy Creatures; making my ad-
dresses at thy Throne of Grace: o holy Trinity I humbly
besech thee regard the powrings out of a weak fraile
despised handmaid of thine (yet whose heart is truly
fixed upon thy divine Beauties.) in desires & longings
to be made like thee in holiness & Righteousness for Ever
have mercy upon thy servant, whom thou has made
& preserved by thy might hither to. And behold Lord
lo thine indignation lieth hard upon me, & thou hast
vexced me with all thy Stormes; thy hand presseth me
Sore; My Soul is full of troubles & heavinesse by reason
of my Sins. & my life draweth nigh unto the Grave;

My body in distress my Soul under sader calamities
by the withdrawings of thy Presence. Hide not thou thy
Heavenly face face from me O Lord; unlesse to make me
seeke thee with greater Ardor & Zeale. Oh pardon thy
servants frailties & infirmities in too much sorrow &
greiving for the being deprived of my head & husband, &
let me acknowledge thy hand with submissivenesse & patience
it is thou Lord that art gracious & good to the Children of men
O restore me to thy favour again, to comfort me in my
Sorrows & sadnesses, & now I am brought into a forlorne
& widdowed condition. O Lord I beseech thee give me
277
A double proportion, of thy holy Spirit, to be my
Guide into the way of the truth, and an Illuminations of
my heart & stepes in thy ways, & a direction in this
my sadest Pilgramage; give me thy word to be a
Lanthorne to my paths, & a light unto my ways
that I tread not the stept of Death. Neither let me go down
into the darke, nor my life into the place where all things
are forgotten. Though thou hast pleased to afflict me soe
sore in the loss of my dear husband & the comforts I in
joyed in him yet let me plead thy gracious promise.
& be thou the husband to the widow & a Father to the
Fatherlesse Children; & desolate.

make me thankful for so long injoyment, as also
for those eminent gifts & Graces, which thou in mercy had
indowed him with; To thee be the Hon.or given, due unto thy
Name, & o Lord give me the power of thy grace, & strength
to immitate his virtues, which was called to thy service in
our youths, & from our youths by thy miraculous Provid
ence preserved from those inormities which hundreds comit
to their own perdittion. O give me therefore now thy
perservering grace to the end of my days; & that I may take
up thy Cross dailie & follow thee, being meeke & lowlie
in Spirit submissive with a true & Catholique resignation
to all thy wise dispensations seeme they to cross my
perverse will never so much give me patience through
out, in all the course of my Life, faith, true wisdom, hope
& Charitie. Let me not lacke, any thing, which may add
orne my Soul in thy Sight, making it lovely in the sight
of my Redeemer, who purchased it with his bloodshed
write in my heart a new name sequestred as much as
may be from this world. & all its delights & vanities.

Lord give me grace to continue a pure mind in a Chaste
body cleansed by thy precious blood. And if it be
thy good pleasure to continue me yet a while longer
to doe thee service here, give me my Life for a prey, & keep
me from sins of presumtion, that they never get dominion
over me I had miritted destruction long erre this.
278
but by the goodness & bounty I am yet remaining

O let me beg it of thy Majesty with out offence. that I
might be in a more prepared condition to meete thee
the sweet Bridegroome of my Soul being found doing
the work of my Lord. And in the intrime let me show forth
the loving kindenesse of the Lord amongst the Redeemed ones
in the land of the Living: for the living the living he shall
Praise thee & confesse thy holiness, & the mercies of thy
holy Name. O hide not thy face from me any more
but give me sufficient Sustentation & support to inable
with fortitude to indure thy fatherly chastisments. That
Thou maist have the Glory of all, & my Soul reape the beni-
fitt of thy Rod, by amendment of life, in better obedience
I humbly beseech thee o Lord my God to give me also a
healthy temper of body, To be the better inabled to doe my
duty which thou hast called me unto. As a faithful, &
cairefull mother & head of this Family, praing thee to
continue it still if it be thy pleasure for many Generations
to glorify thy Name on Earth, & made members of thy
Misticall body in heaven, of thy Church Triumphant.

Dear Lord I pray thee blesge
my three Children with all
blessings in order to Eternity. with Grace, wisdom & under-
-standing. be thou their Portions & inheritance for Ever
for whom thou blessedst they shall be blessed, O sanctify them
with thy Spirit from their youth, & preserve them by thy
Power from vicious humors & corrupt inclination of the
Old Adam. but putting on the Lord Jesus Christ. Neither let them
want any thing in this life with out the which they cannot
serve thee, nor let them be Rebellious or disobedient. To
their Spirittuall, Politicke, or naturall Parents. Make
them obedient to thy Laws & Precepts. Divine & morall
And teach thou me by thy Spirit, that I may instruct them
in those duties thou hast commanded; that so I may be
assisted to discharge a good conscience in all holy precepts
Give them also I beseech thee an obedient Eare and a
willing heart, in love and affection, & submitt to Those
instructions from thee. That they may be comforts to thy
servant in this her disconsolate condition.

Grant that each year, they may grow up in Grace & the
knowledge of our Lord, & that thou maiest be glorified in &
by them. I beseech thee let none of them be children of
Perdittion. but let their Souls be precious in their
Sight, for Ever more.

Indowe me thy handmaid with sutable qualifications
to serve thee in there Godlie & Religeous Educations.
And to serve thee the Searcher of hearts with Zeale & a
constant Reguler devotion. Restore, & preserve us in the
life of Righteousness, Sobrietie. & humilitie & Chastiety
in our words & Actions. Blessing me & mine with happy
opportunities of Religion, all our days & doing thee
faithful service that we are capable of in this Life.

That I may redeeme the time past; & by thy Grace may
grow Rich in good works alwaies abounding in the work
of the Lord; That when thou shalt demand my Soul
to be rendered up into thy hands. My Soul may not
be abhorred of thee, Nor suffer thy terrours, but may
feele an Eternity of blessings in the Resurrection of the
Just. And further my humble request is o Father. that
Thou wilt shed thy Spirit of grace into the hearts of
all my Children & my Self that we may be firmly uni
ted to thee & each other in the bands of faith & Charity

That it may not be in Satans Power, nor his instruments
to disunite our hearts from thee & each other, but that we
may continue for ever in Truth, unity, & Peace &
Concord that the God of Peace, may give us his Peace through
his holy Spirit of Sanctificattion. And all these most
humble requests I beg at the Throne of thy Grace, with
Pardon for my erroers
[word] SiC ??? i.e., errors. in these prayers & imperfect
requests, And heartely craveing them at thy most
gracious hand; with all things ellse in order to Eternity
both for our Souls & bodies. Even for our Lord Jesus
Christs his sake, the Righteous. To whom with the
holy Spirit, The Eternal & Glorious, And Incom-
prehensable Father, and for ever Blessed Trinity
be ascribed all Hon.or Glory Power, might. Majesty
280
Thanksgiving, Praise, Adoration & Dominion
by all Creatures & things in Heaven & Earth.
by the Tounges of men & Angels Arch-Angells.
Cherubims & Seraphimes both now & to all Eternity
Humbly concluding these my humble Pettions &
weak praires & praises in that Perfect forme of Prair
which the grand Bishop of our Souls taught us in his holy
Gospel to pray unto thee in Saying

Our father which art in Heaven:
&c. Amen. Haleluia.
Amen.
