div.head: Our Saviours command.
div.p:
Love not the World: nor the things of the world.
for the fashion of the world passeth away.
Set your affections on heaven above, & not on Earth.
for where your Treasure is there will your heart be also.
The Just shall live by faith.
Mr Thorntons motto & my own.

p.seg:
Nisi Christus Nemo:
Tour pour le' Eglize:

None but Christ.
All for the Church

div.p: Annagrame.

div.l: Christ and his Church, in love so well agr'eed.
That he for her, and She for him, has bl'eed.
Thus imitate thy Saviour, in his fervent love,
And then, thy Joys, my Soul will lasting prove.
Oh groundles deeps, O love beyond degree.
The offended dies, to set the offender free.
But now.
The Churches head to heaven is gon
Leaveing her, here on Earth alone.
Much like a Widow in disstresse
Washed in Tears, Tears that express.
her dailie greifes, with sighes, to be deprived.
Of her dear Soveraine; the world denied.
But what although thy Lord is gon.
To sitt in Glory, placed on his Throne.
Has he not left his pledge of love.
To thee his Loyall Spouse, his holy Dove.
Bequeathed Thee his Sanctifieing Spirit
For to conduct thy weary steps to inheritt.
Those Everlasting Joys he has prepared.
For thee. A Glorious Tabernacles Shaired.
Wherein no Sun needs Shine, for he alone.
Is all the Light in that vaste Horrizon.
What then if through a Sea of brinie Tears
Thou swime'st, hee'l free thee from all fears.
Of Sinking, canst thou but hold him fast
In Arms of faith, thou shallt come safe at last
Nay weart thou dead, yet shalt thou live
A Life much more Superlative.
Then heart can thinke, or tongue can tell
Those Glories all, they doth Excell.
He strive till Death; but shall my feeble strife
Be Crown'd. He Crown thee with a Crown of Life.

div.head: Against the fears of Death.
div.l: Since natures workes be good and Death doth serve
As natures work. why should we fear to die.
Since fear is vaine, but when it may preserve.
Why should we fear, that which we cannot flie.
Fear is more pain than is the pain. it fears.
Disarming humaine mindes of Native might;
While each conseipt an ugly figure beares
Which were not Evil, well vieued in reasons light
Our only Eyes, which dimm'd, with Passions be,
And scarse discerne the dawne of commeing day.
Let them be clear'd, and now begin to see,
Our life is but a stepe in dusty way.
Then let us hold, the blisse of gracious mind.
Since this wee feele. greatt loss we cannot finde.

div.p:
O Death I will be thy Death. O Grave I will be thy
Victory. thanks be to God: through our Lord Jesus Christ.

div.head: An inducement to Love Heaven
div.l: Leave me o love, which Reachest but to dust.
And thou my mind aspire to higher things
Grow rich in grace, which never taketh Rust:
What ever fades, but faiding pleasure brings.
Draw in thy beames, and humble all thy might.
To that Sweet yoake, where lasting freedomes be.
Which breakes the Clouds, and opens forth the light
That doth both shine, and gives us sight to see.
O take fast hold, let that light by thy guide
In this small course, which birth drawes out to death
And thinke how Evil become'th him to slide,
Who seeketh heaven & comes of heavenly breath.
Then fairewell world, thy uttermost I See.
Eternall love maintaine thy life in me.

div.head: A faire-well to the World.
div.l: Fairewell the gilded follies, pleasing troubles.
Fairewell the hon.red ragges the Cristall bubbles
Fame's but a hollow Eccho, Gold poor Clay.
Honnour the darling but of one short day.
Beauties chief Idoll, but a damaske skin
State, but a golden Prision to live in.
To vex free minds, imbroidred traines
And goodly Pageants, proudly Swelling veines
And blood alied to Greatnesse, is but lone,
Inheritted, not purchast not our own.
Fame, Riches, Hon.or, Beauty, State, Traines, Birth
Are but the faiding Pleasures of the Earth.
I would be Rich, but see man too unkind,
Diggs in the Bowels of the Richest Mine.
I would be great, but yet the Sun doth still.
Levill his beames against the riseing hill.
I would be fair, but see the Champion Proud
The worlds fair Eye, oft setting in a Cloud.
I would be wise, but that the Fox I see
Suspected guilty, when the Fox is free
I would be Poor, but see the humble grasse
Trampled upon, by each unworthy Asse.
Rich hated; Wise suspected; scornd if poor,
Great feared; fair tempted; high still envied more.
Would the world then adopt me for her Heir.
Would Beauties Queene intitle me the fair.
Fame speak me hon.nrs minion, & could I.
With Indian Angels, & a speaking Eye.
Command baire heads; bowed knees strike Justice Dumb
As well as blind & lame, & give a Tongue.
To stones by Epitaphs; be calld great Master,
In the last lines of every Poetaster:
Could I be more then any man that lives.
Great, Wise, Rich, Fair, All in Superlatives.
Yet I these favours would more free Resigne
Then ever fortune would have had them mine.
I count one minute of my holy Leasure
Beyond the mirth of all this Earthly Pleasure.
Wellcome Pure thoughts, wellcome my sadest Groves
These are my guests; this is the Joys I love.
The winged People of the Skies shall Sing,
Me Anthems by my Sellers gentle Spring.
A Prayer Book shall be my lookeing glasse
Wherein I will adorne Sweet Vertues Face.
Here dwells no heartlesse loves no pale fac'd fear
No short Joys purchast with Eternal tears
Here will I sit & sigh my weak youths folly
And learne to affect an holy Mallancholly.
And if contentment be a Strainger then.
He ne'er look for ill butt in Heaven again.
Ah foolish, faithlesse, fickle world where in.
Each mottion is a vice, and every act a Sin.
finis.

div.head: My faithful Soul's wish.
div.l: Oh; had I of his love but Part,
That chosen was, by Gods own heart.
That Princely Prophett David he,
Whom in the word of truth I see.
The King of Heaven so dearely loved,
As mercy beyond measure proved:
Then should I neither Gyant fear,
Nor Lyon that my Soul would teare.
Nor the Philistines, nor such friends.
As never, were true Christians friends.
No passions should my Spirit vexe
Nor sorrow so my mind perplex.
But I should still all glory give
Unto my God by whom I live.
And to the Glory of his Name
Through out the world divulge the same.
My walk should be but in his ways
My talke but onely in his Praise.
My Life a death, but in his love.
My death a life for him to prove.
My care to keep a Conscience cleane.
My will from vaine thoughts to waine.
My pain, and pleasure, travell, ease.
My God thus in all things to please
Nor Earth, nor Heaven should me move,
But still my Lord should be my love
If I am sick he is my health.
If I am poor. he is my wealth,
If I am weak, he is my strength,
If dead, he is my Life at length.
If scorne'd, he only is my Grace;
If banished, he my Resting place.
If wronged, he only is my Right.
If sad, he, is my Joy, & Soul's delight;
In Summe and all, All only he;
Should be all, a bove All to me.
His hand should wipe away my Tears,
His favour free me from all fears,
His mercy pardon all my Sinne,
His Grace my life anew begin.
His love my light to Heaven should be
His Glory thus to comfort me;
And as t'is writt such honour shall.
Even unto all his Saints befall.
finis.

div.head: Upon Rash Censorers
div.l: Judge not thatt feild; because ti's Stubble,
Nor her that's poor, and full of trouble
Though t'one look baire the other thin.
Judge not, their Treasure, lies within.

div.head:
A Recollection of Memmorable accidents, &
Passages. forgotten to be Entred into my Book.

div.note:
this must be placed In the first Place Page 8th before the
The mesels in 1629
div.head:
At Kirklington 1629
[+]
Upon my deliverance from death by a fall.
when I was 3 years old. when I cutt a great wound in my forehead of above an Inch long
div.p:
My Father, & mother, living at Kirklington;
where I was borne; & my brother Christopher also
The same maid servant attended upon him, and was
his dry nursse, (Sara Tomlinson) which kept me. after I
was weaned; being like wise both nurrsed by one
wett nurrse. tho upon having a fresh milk, she had
a Child betwixt the nuriseing my brother & my self
And having bin very good & cairefull of the first Child
my Parents saw it fit she should nurrse the 2d Child too.
discharging the duty so well to me. I heard it observed that
I was both a strong & healthfull child all a long. never
having had either the Ricketts or any other desease.
for which I most humbly & heartily give thanks to the
God of my salvation, which still had his gracious Eye,
of Providence over me both at my birth, when my
dear mother brought me forth in great Perrill of her
life she being weak. upon the birth of all her Children
having had seaven in all: 4 Sons & 3 Daughters.
Yet the Lord gave me a Sound healthfull body streight
Limbes & of a resonable understanding Praised be his
glorious name for ever.

Yet has his goodness bin more extended to me in this
& all other preservations That I might not forget his
mercies for ever. And that hath manny ways of the extent of
of his favours to young Infants in there deliverances
from death & destruction in this world besides that of sicke'n
esses & weakness of body. for if his divine Providence did
not send his Angels to keep & gaurd little Children They
could not continue not be preserved from all evil Actident-ts
287
And casultys, incident to That feble and weak
Estate of Infants & Childehoods:

For altho there innocency be not capable of offending
others. yet that Innocency & harmlessness is not able to
defend them from Injurious dealings from evil
Persons. neglects, & Brutishness of nurrses & caireles
ness of others. not to mention those infinite hazards
of over layeing; & badness of there food & evll milk
Added to the dreadful malice of Satan who doth
by all means Endeavour to destroy man Kinde.
setts on work all his engines against us by more
designs then we can see or be capable to understand
There fore am I for ever bound to bless the Eternal
name of God who hath sent his gaurdian
Angell to watch over me and mine for my good &
Preservation. ever since I was borne. The number
of his miraculous deliverances are past finding out
yet will I call to mind what I can that he might receav
receav the Glory of. All. There was now a most greatt
preservation to me when I was but a little Child &
was following my maid Sara watts Tomlinson
who caired
[word] I.e., carried. my brother Christopher in her Arms
& I took hold of her Cote. my weak hand being
but about 3 yers old could not go so fast after her
but my feet stumbled against the Thrashhold. &
fell upon the corner stone of the harth in the
Chamber called the Passage chamber which leades to
my dear mothers Chamber. At which time I
broke the Scull of my fore head in the very top.
against the said Rowbe. so greivously about an Inch
long insoe much that the skin of the braine was
seen & in great danger of death being like to
have bleed to death it being so desperate a
wound. But by the Providence of God & my dere
mothers skill & care of me she did make a
perfect Cure only a great scarre still remaines & will
never be gon. to putt me in fresh mind of my great
obleigation to &, deliverance, of Allmighty God for my
Life.

How hath my forget full soul let this mercy
slip out of mind & not remembred to give the Lord his
praises due to his name. But now o my soul return
Thy solomne thanks, & praises to this great & gracious
God who hath had mercy and compassion both on thee
when thou wast a poor weak Infant. & brought
Thee to these years through infinite more dangers.
To the Lord my God therefore doe I poure out my Soul
in humble gratitude for this great preservation in the
beginng of my days. beeseeching him to accept of me now
his handmaid. both to serve him & praise him for ever.
And with all my might doe I sing praises to his glorious
name, who hath had the same Pity, & compassion both
as a tender & dear Parent & Gardian. O let thy
Providence still go along with me all my days. &
that thy Angell Gardians may defend me with thy
sheild to preserve me from Precipic. or falls. or dislocation
incident to this life. who now growes in my later Age
even almost a Child, in strength leave me not
nor forsake me. who has non to depend on but thee the
God of mercies. who hath made & uppholden me evr
since I was borne. bring me into that state of Innocency
of Soul by a conversion, truly into the state of Grace.
That I may freely bear thy trials & belive thy Promise
That through them I may at the last be conducted into
the land of Eternal Rest. there to sing & praise thy
holy glorious name & holy Trinity for evr & evr.
Amen. & Amen.

div.head:
A great deliverance from drowning in Ireland
by a fall out of the coach as my mother & us Ch.
was going to Killdare.
October: 6th 1636. Riding by the coach
div.p:
As my dear mother (my hon.red Father) my self &
brrothers, George, Christopher, & John. was going in the
Coach to see Kildare after my father bought it there
was a narrow place we were to pass by a River Sid.
289
Joseph Browning being the coach man a vey
[word] SiC ??? for very.
cairefull man yet could not avoy
[word] SiC ??? for avoid? that way being
none other to take but for seeing the apparent
danger of falling, (by providence he rather chose to
throw the Coach on the right hand towards the dry
land Upon a banke side which did hurt some of us
Then to fall on the left hand there being a great
River close by the Coach, which if we had gon down
on that side it had bin impossible we could have
bin Saved any of us, but all in the Coach & horse
had bin utterly lost & Perished in that deep River
my father did ride on horse back but by reason
of the narrow way could not make any Assistance
nor his men to help us in that danger. but was
much affriged
[word] SiC ??? for affrighted? at that sudden accident.

But when he saw the Coach fell from the River
did much rejoice, & glorified God with us for all
Preservations: Glory be the holy name of our
great & gratious God for ever. for all our saftys
& in giving us our lives with my dear mother: we
was not worthy of thes infinite deliverance nor
all thy mercies o Lord to us. But praised by
Thy great name most high. who had pity on me
Thy poor Creature & young Child.

O Lord my God blessed be thy majesty for this
great deliverance & saving me from this death oh
let me live to Praise thy name for ever & accept
of my Soul & service All my days for Jesus Christ
his Sake Amen. Amen.

div.head:
A great deliverance from a 2d fall
at Sr Robert Merideths in Dublin
in Ireland 1637.
div.p:
My Lady Anne Wentworth. & Lady Arbella with
Cozen Anne Hutton, Mrs Anne Loftus & my self
being invited to dinner to Sir Robt. merideths to dine
The ladies ussing the costome to swing by the Arms
for recreation & being good to exercize the body
of Chilldren in growing, it was ordered by my Lady
Straford they should doe it moderatly & found good in
it: so that they used to swing each other gently to that
Purpose. They would make me being a young girle
doe the same with them & I did so & could hold very
well by the Arms as they did & had never got no hurt
by it. I bless god but found it did me good &

Butt at this time very unfortunately some of the
young Ladies bid one of the Pages (Calld don de Lan.)
a french boy That he should swing me being strong
[word] I.e., strong[er]
then they & they weary with Play. Butt I cryed out
desiring them not to bid him but could not get off so
soone from him & deliver my self from danger befor
he had came to me. He immediately Pushed
me so violently from him with all his force as I was
swinging by my Arms. That I was not able to hold
my hands on the swing. So that he throwed me down
me downe upon the chamber Bords. I fell down upon
my face fell to the grownd & light with such a violent
force with all my weight on my Chinn Bone uppward
That both thee chinn & chapp bones was almost brok
insunder & putt the bone out of its Place. And did
291
Raise a great Lumpe as bigg as an Egge under
my Chinn & throte, which sudainly astonished me
and took a way my breath in so much as I was
nigh death, they thought I had bin dead:
for a good space of time. till by the great mercy
& Power of my gratious God I came to my self
again upon the use of good means The whole
house was concerned for my distress & this sad accident
butt much more my dear Lady Anne that her Page should
doe so great a mischefe to me:

At length it pleased God I came to my Self again
but a long time ere I knew any body being in great
pain and extremity. Being kept there till night
before I could be able to go home.

But coming home to my dear mother she was
surprised to see that sad misfortune befallen to me
Tho bless God Almighty she applied such good means
as did recrute me after a long time being so bad.

But oh what great cause have I to cast my
self down at thee feet of the great & dreadful
Lord God who am but dust & Ashes. made by his
Power & preserved by his Providence ever since I was
borne & has delevred me this time so wonderfully
from a sudden & violent death eaven
[word] SiC ??? i.e., even. when I was
in a childish sport or play. or what ever it was thou O
Lord my God which did deliver me both now & at all
times of my life therefore will I give all thanks &
praise for ever with my Soul and body & speritt for evr
Alltho I was not willing to swing at this time yet
did thou delvr me Lord make me thankful for ever
& that I may never forget this mercy to glorify thy
great name And that I may still be preserved to live
to thy Glory in life & conversation for Jesus Christ his
sake to whom be praise for Ever more Amen & Amen.

div.head:
A dreadful fire in the Castle of Dublin.
1638.
div.p:
About 3 years before my noble Lord of Straford
his death there happned a great and dreadful
fire in the Castell of Dublin, which did go nigh to
have burned it down & destroyed it to the ground
had it not bin Prevented by Providence:

There being some up in the the other part of the Court
where Sir George Ratclifs lodging was. which saw it
it & cryed out for help being at the dead time of
the night it was very Terrible to be hold. It began
upon the account of a maid servant setting a
dust baskett of charcole Embers taken out of the
Chapell Chamber & cairlessly set under the Stairs
that went up to the Store house that night which kindled
of it self, burned down staires & that Roome calld
the Chapell Chambr above the Chapell. which was most
Richly furnished with blacke velvett imbroidered
with flouers of Silke-worke in Ten stich all fruit Trees
and flours & slips embroidred with gold twist &
It burned the statly Chapell built by my Lord & my
Laidies Lodging. with the young Ladies. But by the
great mercies of God prevented there destruction &
was awakned by the flame apeard on the other side of the
Court. & great help was made with speed to preserve
my Lady & the rest which was brought out of bed in blanks
[word] I.e., blankets? As in Anselment?
Blessed be the Great God of Heaven for these delvrincs
and all his glorious Providence to the Family & all the
Kingdom in them & to my father & his family Amen. Amen

Dec. 10 1640. My brother Christopher Wand.
being in the Church called Christs Church in
Dublin heearing the great & dreadful cry that
the Irish made at my dear fathers Funeral
was so frighted that he fell into the most greivos
fits of the Splen which much tormented him for many
years after & had like to have taken his life away
butt blessed be the gracious God by my dear mothr
excellent cairs. cost, & pains he was cured & becam
a very strong man. & livd to be the Fathr of that Fam
of which he was descended & was my beloved brother
living to the Age of 61 years & died at London
feb. 23d 1686.
buried at Kirklington by his Antien
ters

div.head:
Of the making; & Preservation of my dear
& hon.red Fathers Last will & Testament in
Ireland in the Rebellion. & by what Providenc
Date Octo 2
1640
it was found out & our destruction
thereby Prevented:
div.p:
This my dear fathers will was dated octber 2d 1640
Proved, & left on the file by Coz. william wandesford
an Executor. remaned on the file for several years
Till the year 1647. when my brother George wandesf
went into Ireland to get a true copy of it & not having
mony to discharge it The sad will was laid by in a Chest
by the Clarke who had writ it out & thes was sececd
[word] I.e., secured? for several
year of the sarre afftr my brother George died & non knew
what became of it.

Upon which great facte & troubles arose for the want of it
by Sir John Lowths bad counsell to my brothr Ch. wand. who
marrid his daughter & would have come into the Estate by the
Intaile.

But all
[word] I.e., 'att' ??? no tht eonly time she's forgotten to cross her t's. last by the Providence of the great God of heven this
said will was discovd & producd in the year 1653 which did
put an end of all the Troubles: This is fully related in my 2d Book

div.head:
A Grate full Remembrance of my being preserved
from the fury of the warres in the time of the scotts being
over the Poor Country in there madnes against
us when I was at Hipswell with my dear mothr
in 1643, 1644 &
div.p:
In this time after the Bataille of Hessom moore
when the blssed
[word] Sic ??? i.e., blessed. King Charles had by Treachery lost
the feild, & his two Generalls, Prince Rupert &
Lord of new Castle exposed all the brave white cots
foote that stood the last man till they were murthred
& destroyed. & that my poore brother G. wand. was
forced to fly to hide himself at Kirklington. &
brought my brother Christop. behind him after which time
we got to hipswell & livd as quiettly as we could for
the madnes of the Sotts
[word] SiC ??? for Scotts. who quartred all the County
ouer & insulted over this Poor Country, & English.

my dear mothr was much greivd to be abued
[word] I.e., abused.
by them in quarting them at her own house. yet could not
Posibly excuse her self Totally from their men & horses.
Tho she paid duble Pay & was at 01-6 a part
where
othrs at 09. only in a month.

She kept of the quarting Captane & commanders
& would nevr yeald to have them. At length there
came one Capt. Inness. which was ovr
[word] I.e., over [commander] that troope we had
in Town. & he coming on a surprise into the house
I could not hide my self from them as I used to doe.
But coming boldly into my mothrs Chamber whre I
was with her. he began to be much more ernest and
violent to have staid in the house & said he would stay in
his quarters but we so ended the matter that we got him out by
all the fair mean could be to got quit of him who was so
vild a bloody looked man that I trembld all the time he was
295
In the house. I calling to mind with dread that he was so
infint
[word] I.e., infinite. like in Person my Lord macguire the great Rebell
in Ireland was in a great Constrnatin
[word] I.e, consternation. for fear of him.

After which time this man impudantly toald my
Aunt norton that he would give all he was worth if
she could procure me to be his wife & offrd 3 or 4000l
& Lord of Adare shuld come to speak for him. She said it
was all in veine He must not presume to look that way
for I was not to be obtnd.
[word] I.e., obtained. And she was sure he might
not have any incoragnt
[word] I.e., encouragment. for I was resold not to mary.
& put him of the best she could. but writt me privite
word that my Lord of Adare & he would come to speak
to me, & my mother about it, & willed me to get out of
his way. It was not to furthr that desire in me who did
perfictly hate him & them all like a Todd in such a kind

And imeadiatly acquanted my dear mothr which was
supised
[word] I.e., surprised. & troubld for she feard they would burne her
house, & destroy all: wishd me to go whithr I would
to secure my self: & I did so forth with run into the
Toune, & hid my self privtly in great fear & a fright
with a good old woman of her Tennants. whre I bles
God I continud safely Till the vissitt. was over &
at night came home.

we was all joyfull to escape so. for my d. M
was forcd to give them the bst treat she could & said.
indeed she did not know where I was. & sent out
fewe a little to seeke me but I was safe from them

After which time this villaine Captaine did study
to be revenged of my d. M. & threatnd cruelly what
he would doe to her, becees
[word] I.e., because. she hid me Tho that was not
true for I hid my self. And about the time that the scotts
was to march into Scottland being too long here on us
whn my mothr paid offtr 25l & 30l a month to them.

This Scott in a bosting manner sent for his Pay & she
sent all she ought to him which he would not take from
her, but demanded duble monny, which she would nor
could not do, so one sundy moring he brought the
company & Threatned to breake the house & dores.
& was most vild, & Crewell in his oaths & sweaing
[word] SiC ??? i.e., swearing.
against her & me; And went to drive all her goods
in her ground having this delecate Cattell of her
own breed. I went up to the Leader to see whether he did
drive them a way & he looked up & thought it had bine
my d. m. Cursed me bitterly & wished the Deal bloew
me blind & into the Ayre. & I had bin a thorne in his
heele. but he would be a Thorne in my side. & drved the
Cattell a way to Richmd where Generall Lecsley was.

So my dear mothr was forcd to Take the Pay he
was to heve & carrid it to the General that laid at my
Aunt nortons & acquanited him how that Captane had
abused her & wronged her. which by mercy of God to
her, This G. Leceley did take notice of & took her
mony, & bid her not trouble her self for he would
make him take it or punish him for his Rudness.
he said more did Innis That if evr
[word] SiC for 'ever'. any of his
Country men came into England. They would burne
her & me & all she had. But yet she servd that God
which did deleir us out of the Irish Rebellion & all the
Blood shed in England, till this time And did now deler
her and my self & all we had from him:

This was a great delvrnce,
[word] I.e., deliverance. at last & Joyned with my
own single delivrance from this Beast. from being
destroyed & defloired by him. for which I have reason to praise
the great & mighty God of Mercy to me.

There was one of his men that I had cured of his
hand being cutt of it & lame. so that fillow did
me a signall return of gratitude for it. Thus
It was some times a refreshment to me after I
had sitt up mauch with my dear weak mothr in
her illnes, or writing, of letters for her. That she did
bid me walk out to Cowes with her maid to rest
my self so I used this some times. Butt this Captne
man who I curd came to me one day. Saying dere
Mrs I pray do not thinke much if I desire you for
God sake not to go out with the maides to Cowes. I
said why. he said again he was bound to tell me.
That his Capitaine did currs & sweare. That he
would watch for me & that very night he had desigd
[word] I.e., designed.
with a great many of his Camrades to catch me
at Cowes & force me on horsbacke away with thm
& God knowes what End he would make of me. I sad I
hopd God would delir me frm all such wickedness
and so I gave the man many thanks who was So
Honest to prseve
[word] I.e., preserve. me from there Plots. rewarding him for
his pains, & did nevr go abroad out of the House.
again but ford
[word] I.e., forced. to keep like a Prisonr while they
was here. Blssing the great God of heaen
[word] I.e., heaven. who
did not suffer me to fall into the hands of those
wickd man nor into the hand of Sir Jerimy Smith
son who could neer prevail by no means to
obtenie me for his wife. & I was thus delvd also fm
such a force by the discovry of Tom Binkes.

Lord make me truly thankful for preservation of
me thy poor handmaid And make me live to thy Glory Am

div.head:
My delivrance from Drowning in the River at midlam
when I went to be a wittness to my sister Danbys first
Francis Borne at Midlam Castle in the year 1644
div.p:
At that time Sir Thomas Danby was forced with my Sister
& Children to be in safty from the Parliament forces
he being for King Charles the first. to Midlam Castle
A garison under my Lord Lofftus. There she was delivrd
of her first Son Francis Danby. my sister having
got my Lord Lofftus, & my Lady H self with
annother Co.Branlen
for witness. I was forced to go over the River near
midlam calld swaileUre which had some stoops set up for
guides & if one had raised the Caucy they had bn
[word] I.e., been. erre-
-covrably lost. at that time I was very hearty & strong
& did venture to ride the same or ellse might have gon
back & rathr then she should be disapoynted did venture
over after my mo. servant who led the way but it
happned the Rivr proved deeper then we expected it
& I kept up my horse as well as I could. from standly
[word] Cf Anselment n256 ??? 'obscure' transcribed by him as 'stand[ing]', i.e., hesitating.
& so bore up a long time. But when we were gon so
far that I could not turn back The River provd past
Riding & the bottom could not be come to by the poor
maire which was an excellent maire of my poore brother
G. wandesfords So I saw my self in such aparnt danger
And beged of God to asset me & the poor Beast I rid on & to
be merciful to me & delivr me out of that death for J. Cht
his sake. And the poor maire drew up her fore feet & I
percved she did swime. I gave her the Reines & took of
the short Reines of the breech & gave her the head with all the
help I could & clasped my hands about her maine did
freely comit myself to my God. to do what he pleeced
[word] I.e., pleased. with me
And she did by mercy bear up her head & swimd out
aboue half a quarter of a mile crose that dreadful Rier & by
gods great mercies brought me ovr
[word] I.e., 'over', variant of o'er. that Rier in Safety. which delever
was so great & dread full that I can nevr forget to prace the god
299
And my great & gracious Lord God who had pity on me
at this time to spare me from this death & destruction
oh what shall I render to the great God of heaen who
has delivd me from Perishg by this water & caucd this poor
creature to bring me out safe all glory be to my gracious
God of heavn by all the Power of men & Angels for evr.
o let me live to thy glory & serve thy majety for Eer Amn.

A remembrance of a great deliverance I had
from drowning as I was going over the River
Swale to St nickolas to my Aunt Nortons. when
A flood came down on me, & Ralph J.anson.
in the yeere. 1646.

A very great deliverance of me as I was going over
the River at midlam when my Sistr Danby laid in of
one of her Sons calld francis & was at midlam Castle
in the year 1644

A great deliverance of me from being destroyd
with a cannon Bullett at weschester being besseged
by Sir will.m Brewertons Army they shift into the Town
of weschester and as I was at my prayers in the Tent
with the window open the waft shut the casnt
[word] I.e., casement? & I fell don
on my knees & took breath from me. but bled
[word] I.e., blessed. be the Lord I
was delivrd from death. at that time also to Praise his
holy name. For. Ever. 1647.

And was deleerd from that seige also by miracles
of mercy & brought us Safe into our own Country York
shere.

A great delivrance from the violence of a
Rape from Jerimy Smithson. Sir
Ierimys Heughs
Son who had sollicited me in marriage by
his fathr & uncle Smithson who woud hav
setled on him 200l a year if I would have
married him. but I would not, but avoyded
his company because he was debauched. And he
hired some of his own company to have stolen me
away from cowse. but Tom Binks discovrd it I bles God

item.surplus:
Upon the Reconsiling my 2 brothers G. W &
Christop. W. before his death

div.head:
Upon the reconsiling of my two Brothers
George & Christopher Wandesford. March
21 9
on Easter Eve - before my bro. G was lost
1651
div.p:
Upon Easter day & had a full satisfaction of there true love & affection to each
other & ever After to his death for which I doe bless & praise the God of Heaven for ever
It was no small grief & trouble to me that
the wickedness of my Eldest brothers servant
by idle stories to my deare Brother George
against my poore brother Christ. had so
fare prevailed with him as to make a very
great breach in there freindship so that the yonger
did Apprehend himself, much injured &
wronged there by to his brother George-
by them: & the other. Tho a very wise & under
standing Person; had bin highly incensed
at some lies which was told of his brother to
him, & by this means caused a very great
anger against each other; which proceeded to hy
& caused them to have such animossity as that
they neither could be satisfied to receive the
holy Sacrament:

But it pleased God to make me the happy
instrument to perswade, & intreat each of them
to such moderation & Charity, to aske each othr
pardon (& God in the first place) for what had bin
amiss & to freely forgive one another & put any
all former disgusts or displeasure. & to be Cordially
reconsiled for his sake who died for us. & with great
comfort I prevailed with them to recave this holy feast
of love to which we were to come & on the Eastrday. I blese
my God we did recave that holy Sacmt in Zeale & devotion.

head.l: Coelistiall fear, thy Sacred genious, brings
--------unto the Pallace of the king of Kings-----------

lg.l: G race seamed to waite on nature setting forth
E ven in thy native sence the hight of Worth
O h, that thy verteous life does well express
R elegius care, thy mind did well address.
G ods word to fear, as thy blest name may be
E ven but a type of what shines clear in thee.
W itt, Judgement, vertues learning, and the rest.
A tending true perfection chose thy Brest.
N ot hopeing for a higher seate since their
D esert they found transending all Compaire.
I mmortall faime, Crowned thy so noble Parts
S ounding thy praises due to thy deserts.
F orceing even envy to confess as much
O r burst with malice not dareing for to touch.
R enowne so rightly, placed as to thy Fame
D eath well may adde, but can't impaire the Same

div.l: Excuse my failings, since tis' reall love.
Moved my weak pen so weighty a taske to prove.
I must no more; nor truth could say no lesse
Vertue. & grace, did still thy brest posess.
Each muse so plyed her Ore, in thee deer Soul
Ambitious, which should most in thee, Controll.
Thy Faith, thy hope, thy Greatt Charity
In lively Coulers, shined, bright in thee.
Alltho thy Cruell Enimyes with hate:
Persue'd thy Life, Religion, & thy EState
Yet Providence preserved them all, intire.
And fill'd thy breast with holy fire:
From that blest Alter; which on the day before
Thou power'd thy offrings out, him to adore.
And reconciled, thy self, to God; and Man.
Prepared for thy great change before it Came
What, tho thy death was sudden (to our Eyes).
Yet thou being ready (for that Lord) t'was no surpris
Thou, changed Earth, for Heaven, foes for frends
Then begin thy Joys that Never End:

But who can speak the Sorrows thatt
spread oprest
Each Bleeding heart, & Eye and Breast.
at this sad object struck with horror Dumb,
To see thrice galant Wansfords mare. mortum
ore Run its Bankes. That Antient River Swale
By this sad fortune, did a Currse Intaile.
Not only on its' Self, which now did fall
But on that noble family we Call.
In him. that Name was blessed by succession
Of Brave Heroicke Persons in Possession.
See how it droopes, & falls, & almost Dead
To see this dreadful Loss of this it's head.
Could all our Sighs, & grones, & tears.
Prevail, to Call thee back again; our fear
-would bee that non could keep thee here
The worst of Enimys did be-waile:
The loss of so much hon.or in him failed.
Since he was dead, the most of worth was gon
The Country did cry out; in him, t'was, Oh, Alone:
Oh what meant that Rash flood. by one wave to Throw
A ruin on its own fame. & us too;
So brave A vessell & so Richly Fraught.
That guilty River has to Ship-Rack Brought
As bank-rupts all over Contry; No man here
So unconsernd. but must let fall A Teare
Whilst the sad murmur of those Waters Call.
On Every Passenger to mourn his fall
What tho three days Submertion did intomb
All that was mortall of him in the Womb.
Of a Regardless Eliment we know.
Our great Redeemer, from the Parts-Below
Did by divine Power, on the third day Rise.
To open A nerer way to Paradise.
To that blest Place my Soul desires to Flie
Lord then prepare me for it Ere I Dye.
Make me to Repent, to watch and Pray.
That so I may be Ready for that Day.
When thou shalt call this Soul from me.
With Joyfull hope. Il'e come to thee: Amen.
